sp.l: I cannot go yet; lead me to my Chamber;
I fear I shall grow ill.

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.p: How, how!

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Prithee peace.

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.l: Why, what, a God's name, hath this young Fellow done?
What is he gone and left you?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing; prithee along, I faint.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: Hey day, what doings there's within!
Signior Brancadoro has lost his Mistress;
By this time they are hunting on a cold scent,
Or else have quite given her over.
I wonder my Mistress had not the wit
To run away, and hide for good and all,
From her old Caterpillar.
Hark, there's a new Noise within, Noise within.
And louder too than ever; I'm a Villain
If I don't fansie I hear Taccola's shrieks
A note above them all; what shou'd this mean?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: O, Bottolo, did'st thou see my Mistress? As I live and breathe,
I never took more pains a Squirrel-hunting,
Than I have done in seeking her;
I would give any thing in reason to any
That could but bring Tale or Tidings of her.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.p: That reasonable Reward would prove a Julio.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: Come, Bottolo, prithee come and help to look her.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: I had rather help to hide her from such
A covetous vapouring Coxcomb.
How now!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O Bottolo, Bottolo! run, run, Bottolo.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.p: Whither, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Any whither; run, run, fetch a Physician quickly.
O, my Daughter, my Daughter!
What, art thou here yet?

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.p: Why, what ails my Mistress?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Dying, dying; she fainted suddenly,
And lies without a sign of life.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: A pretty Wedding towards; poor Soul,
Who can blame her to be afraid to be clasp'd by an old Ivy,
Whose embraces never suffer any thing to prosper?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Art thou not gone yet? Run quickly, Sirrah,
To Leonardo the Phycisian; make all the haste thou canst.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: I knew there wou'd no good come of this Wedding,
First or last. I go, Sir, I go.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: O mischief! No hearing of my Niece!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: My Daughter, my Daughter's going.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: And my Niece is quite gone:
Every corner has been search'd, but no finding her.
Oh, oh, what a sad day is this!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Never a hopeful Morning so o'recast!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: O my Mistress! O my Niece! Undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Let's in and advise together;
I have sent Bottolo for a Physician.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: There's yet some hopes; the subtle Politician,
That cannot reach his ends in peace, throws all
Into disorder.
He snatches others first from their enjoyments,
And that makes way for his designs.
I find we are alike; for Peace must be
More fatal than Love's Civil War to me.
What a world of thoughts now offer
Their troublesom service to me!
Wou'd my Man Baptista were come:
Heaven prevent mischance; I cannot doubt his truth:
I trusted him to help my Sister's flight to the Nunnery;
No way was left at last but that,
To cozen Brancadoro of her:
The Fool had almost flown her to a Mark.
O Cialto,—I have strange News to tell thee.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: Your looks express as much.
I thought sorrow and wildness
Had hung upon no brow but mine.
Where have you been? What is the Wedding finish'd?
Why are you thus confus'd?—ha!—where's Samira?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Not married to Brancadoro, nor ever shall.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: O, my best Friend, pardon my fears;
How safe I am in thee! But where is she?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You shall know presently;
I appointed my man Baptista
To wait my coming to this place;
But an accident has brought me sooner than I thought.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: Bless me! What accident?
In thine eyes appears
A strange disorder.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No, no, no great matter; we may be friends, Sir,
Now at your own rate; I am turn'd Lover too.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: Why, 'tis impossible! Who Miranzo •
He that us'd to brag his heart was fortifi'd
With scorn and chearfulness!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O, Sir, I rejoyce you are in such perfect memory;
But see, Baptista is return'd. Now,—what News?

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: As you directed, Sir, I found an opportunity
That favour'd the design your Sister had:
The idle Persons, that had no business
But to mind others Actions, I got
Into the Cellar, whil'st she made her escape.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: To the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.p: Thither she told me she would go.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: How! to the Nunnery! she may be willing to stay there,
'Tis probable; for nothing here below
Is worth her Love: I find I cannot yet
Submit; my Passion will resist,
Though Heaven it self does prove my Rival.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Cialto, friend Cialto; he's gone.
Hey day, how Love tumble •• s about!
Yet I admire not now at this distraction▪
For mad men wonder not at one another.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: The fair Emilia, with her old Governess,
Is fled to the Nunnery too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: How! is't possible?

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: 'Tis certain, Sir; and to that purpose
She left a Note upon her Table:
All the House is in an uproar,
And fancy 'twas a Plot between the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Above my hopes she then has kept her word,
Not to bestow her self; but what a Devil
Does she do at the Nunnery?
That may be worse than th' other; if she shou'd
Turn Nun now; like enough; when people are cross'd
And vex'd, they grow Religious presently.
I must do something.—How my thoughts work, He studies.
Heaving like labouring Moles within the Earth!
Ha, Baptista.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Hast thou not told me thou hast a Brother is a Friar?

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.p: I have, Sir, in the next Convent.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Cou'dst thou not prevail with him to lend me
A little of his holiness?

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nay, I mean none of his Prayers nor Meditations;
At this time I have no use for a good thought:
'Tis his Habit only for a few hours; I'le not abuse it,
On my honour; Thou dar'st trust me, dar'st not?

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: You cannot doubt that, Sir; and I am sure
My Brother's thoughts of you are as mine are:
I'll try presently, if you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come, I'le go along with thee;
For my design requires some haste:
Thy care and love shall be requited.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Worse and worse; my Daughter, my Daughter!
Couzen'd, abus'd and cheated!
Signior Castruccio, Brancadoro, where are you?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Oh, my Daughter! gone, fled, run away,
With her old Beldame.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: How, fled and gone!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Gone, gone.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: My Mistress shew'd her the way.
Villerotto shall let him alone now,
If I cou'd but find him. No Wedding, no Killing.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: How now? any News yet?
Where's my Nephew Miranzo?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He's not in the House, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: We are all abus'd and cheated.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I am couzen'd too of my Mistress▪ but as long
As I can keep my Money, the care's the less.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: It is in vain longer to vex our selves;
Let's in and consult; then, if we judge it 〈◊〉 ,
We'l go together to the Nunnery,
And there make our demands,
You for your Daughter, I for my Niece.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: You advise well; come, let us not delay:
Signior Brancadoro, you must along too.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: With all my heart; I long to see
What the meaning of these tricks are:
Every body's couzen'd, as well as I.

div.head: SCENE. VI.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: We are marvellously kept on duty; not one Allarm yet?

sp.speaker: 1 Com.
sp.l: Our Scout is watching for Intelligence;
To say truth, the Gentleman takes a world of pains.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Wou'd he wou'd take less; he pays well,
And 'tis no matter how long 'tis doing.

sp.speaker: 2 Com.
sp.p: What are you squeamish still, Captain?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Pox on't, I can't conceal my villainous apprehensions
From these Rascals; without doubt the Rogues
Are as timorous as I am, though they hide it better.

div.stage: Enter Villerotto with another, and pulling in Samira.
div.p: How now? what's here to do?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Nay, do not seem angry:
This is strange rambling on your Wedding day.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Impudent Rascal, unhand me:
How dare you assumethe boldness to examine me?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Spoil not your good face with frowns;
'Tis to no purpose; You must be my pris'ner.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Your Prisoner, Slave!

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Yes mine, till I know
In what condition you have left my Master;
Your flight's suspicious; perhaps y'ave murther'd him.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: No, the Fool's alive to thank you
For your officious rudeness.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: If he be not, your life shall satisfie.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: 'Tis not in our bargain to deal with Women.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: There's something more than ordinary;
For guilty persons use such flights;
Here, take her away.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What, will you murder me? help, help.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Stop your mouth, or I'll spoil the passage to't, He sh • ws a Dagger.

And make an hole to let your Clam ••••
•••
By th' way, before they climb up to your Throat.
What have we here? more Quarry ••••• wing?
How the Covie's scatter'd?
Sure 'tis she; 'tis, 'tis Emilia.
Here has been some mischief practis'd▪
I'll seize her too, else •• other will want company.
Stay, who are you?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Ah me!

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Whither this way so •• st?
May be you cannot speak for want of A •• ,
I'll give you vent.—I thought so,—'tis she.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Oh, I am ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Troth, like enough; and possibly you have deserv'd it.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Pray stop me not; but rather, if you have pity,
Conduct me to the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: O, do your mischiefs prompt you to a refuge?
I'll find you out a place of safety.
Two of you come along with me;
Bring them along too.

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.p: Rascal, what dost thou mean to do with us?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Nothing with your Antiquity.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Conduct us to an Officer of Justice;
We dare appear, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Stop her mouth; I'll consider what to do with you;
Bring 〈…〉 long, I say.
A • inu •• brings me back.

div.stage: Exeunt with the Women Villerotto, and the second Companion.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why, this is horrible Injustice;
We must only it seems do the worst work.
Why, methinks one might serve this unconscionable stomach:
But it may be we, like Serving men,
May be permitted to fall to after him.
This plunder though ought to be divided
Among us that did the duty.

sp.speaker: 1 Com.
sp.l: 'Tis but reasonable; perhaps he thinks
That full temptation cannot live
In our hunger-starv'd bodies.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Before I saw these sprightly Wenches
I thought so too; but I am not hungry now:
A Man has never any stomach
When he is over-heated.

div.stage: Enter Villerotto hastily, with the second Companion.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Whist, whist; this way, this way:
Now bravely seize the prey, he's coming directly to you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Pox o' th' News: Now have I no mind
To the Wenches neither; this fear can lay that Devil,
That will obey nor hunger, nor poverty.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Come, follow me; thrust home and sure.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I, I, so we might.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Doubt not your full reward.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Enter Miranzo in a Friars Habit, with a Friar and Baptista.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thanks, holy Sir; and pray be confident
That I have no design nor thought
Which may abuse this habit.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: You are too noble.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: In that rest assured; now Sir retire,
I need no farther your protection.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Heavens direct and send you peace of mind.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thanks, holy Father.
Baptista, wait at my Uncle's House till you hear from me;
I shall need nothing now but an old Shooe cast after me.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I will not fail, Sir. This is strange!
He uses not to be so disturb'd.

div.head: SCENE VIII.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: Love's constant diet is not hope, I see;
For mine wou'd then be starv'd; but it is still alive,
And strangely on despair knows how to thrive.
Yet think, Cialto, how preposterous 'tis
To fear the loss of that which 'twere unworthy
In thee now to wish.
But though the Sun must at a distance shine,
It would beget an horror in Mankind,
Shou'd they but fear he wou'd for ever set.
Though in this place she rises a degree
Up towards Heaven, yet she sets to me. Enter Villerotto, Montalto, and two Companions, with their hands on their Swords.
Ha! who are these, whose dismal looks
Are seconded by their postures!—
Which is your way, Gentlemen?
You stare as if you had lost it.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: No, we know our way, 'tis to thy heart,
And thus we force it.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: 'Twill be hard to find.

div.stage: As they fight, enter Miranzo in his Friars Habit; he snatches a Sword from one of them, and by his help the Assailants are beat off.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What horrid Act is this! How, Cialto!

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Villains, make up; sure I have sped him.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: So bold, Sir?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Bold as your self, Sir.—It is in vain;
Hell take these Rascals.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What caus'd this foul play, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Holy Sir, you know as much as I.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: How do you feel your self?

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: Hurt, Sir; but not to any danger, as I guess;
Yet I bleed: Your timely aid
Makes my life yours; I shou'd not have expected
Such a relief from any in your Habit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How, Cialto, do you not know me?—not yet?
Look again; sure if you lov'd me,
There's no disguise cou'd hide Miranzo from you.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: How, Miranzo! O, my Friend, what means this Habit?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You bleed; I dare not spend the time to tell you.
All my story; I doubt here was foul play.
One of these Villains I know to be Brancadoro's Servant:
But whither were you going?

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: To the Nunnery; but pret hee satisfie my longing,
What's to be done in this disguise?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A very pious work, I can assure you;—why,—
I am going to confess my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Thy Mistress!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You may remember my Uncle was in a fair way
To Marriage.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Why, is he not married?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I frighted his Mistress away, and in this Nunnery
She has taken Sanctuary; her I am going to confess;
I should be abominably out of Countenance—

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: At what, Man?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why, if she shou'd confess, amongst her sins,
That she lov'd me, for one.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: You wou'd absolve her, wou'd you not?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes, and her Penance shou'd be to continue in her Sin;
But we trifle here, forgetting thy condition.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Pish, I scarce feel my hurts.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come, our Adventures lie together; lean on me;
Nay, yet more; counterfeit enough, 'twill move the more
Pity; thy Wounds and my Habit will without doubt
Open these charitable Gates.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: What is your business, Father?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I am sent from Father Vincentio, unto the Lady Emilia.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: Here's no such person.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: How! 'tis not the Custom of holy places to deny truths.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: Nor is it now practis'd.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why her Father sent away Father Vincentio,
Immediately to dispatch some holy Man,
To reconcile her troubled Spirit,
Which caus'd her to fly hither.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: She came not to this place.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Nor Samira, Castruccio's Niece?

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: By all that's holy, neither.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I dare not but believe you,
Pardon me for pressing you so far.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: All Peace dwell with you.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: How, not here! did you not mistake, Miranzo?
And have forgot, and sent her to some other place?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I am amaz'd!

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Do not wonder; you cannot lose your Sister, sure.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Not lose her!

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: I hope so; for 'tis probable she knows your mind.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I scarce understand yours, nor do you know your own;
If you do, 'twill be ingenuous to speak it plainer.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: If I shou'd be jealous, or dislike any thing,
'Twou'd seem ridiculous; such humours
Are only fit for those that either hope,
Or else are in possession.—Farewel.—
I wish your Sister happy.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Stay;—consider this is the second time
That you have started into mean suspicions:
You will repent.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: I do repent that I pursu'd your Sister
With a Passion that hath out-liv'd all my prosperity,
As if a Ghost shou'd love; for 'tis not I,
But 'tis Cialto's shadow that you gaze on.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis indeed his shade, or something less,
That bears no shape of him, nor of his mind.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: I know it but too well;—yet perhaps
You may have so much Friendship left, at my request,
To give it out that I am dead.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What's your design in that report?

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: You will not do it then.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I wou'd know why.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come, your humour shall have its course,
I'll do't without a question:
But why shou'd I report that you are dead?

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: You said you wou'd not ask me; nor need
You fear to give out an untruth; it may be shortly so:
In the mean time I must disguise my self,
As from henceforward I shall every day
Resemble less and less what once I was.
Things running to decay grow every moment
More unlike themselves; and so do I.
That at the last the name of Friend
Will not fit you or me; for I shall be decay'd,
Never to be repair'd again; and we must part
Still more and more, till at the last our distance
Will grow so great that none will guess
We ever were united: So Lines
Both from one Centre drawn, still more and more divide,
Till for the World at last they grow too wide.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I forgive thee, poor Cialto; for I am sensible
What a distraction governs thee, by the confusion
That throws my thoughts into as much disorder;
For I have rais'd a War where Peace still flourish'd,
In the calm Empire of Emilia's Breast;
And she is fled from me back to her peace.
—Yet— He studies.
What is the meaning that my Sister fails?
I know not what to think; I stand like one has
Lost his way, and no Man near him to enquire it of.
Yet there's a Providence above that knows
The roads which ill Men tread, and can direct
Enquiring Justice: The Passengers that travel
In the wide Ocean, where no paths are,
Look up, and leave their Conduct to a Star.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Montalto, and his two Companions.

sp.speaker: 1 Com.
sp.l: TRoth, Captain, I did not perceive
That daring Valour you talk of.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Thy fears blinded thee, else thou might'st have seen
What furious thrusts I exchang'd with that Devil
In a Friars Habit. You are a Courteous Gentleman,
To lend your Sword at such a time.

sp.speaker: 2 Com.
sp.l: He came behind me on the sudden,
And wrench'd it from me:
Who wou'd have suspected a Friar for such tricks?

sp.speaker: 1 Com.
sp.l: All our reward is lost; if we might have it,
I think we shou'd be asham'd to ask it;
He that hir'd us was hurt himself.

sp.speaker: Mont▪
sp.l: Why, 'twas his own cause, and his own fault;
As for Example, I'll shew you what he shou'd have done;
Observe me.— Enter Miranzo, and Baptista following at a distance.
How now—what Apparition's this, as a Friar?
I hope, 'tis not another fighting Friar.
'Slid, 'tis he; my villainous apprehensions
Go as true as a Sun-dial.
What an unlucky posture he has found me in,
Wou'd my Sword were up to th' hilts in him
Or a Dunghill, or any thing that wou'd but hide it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What, more mischief towards? I am provided for them now;
They are those very Rascals:—I know that blustring
Fellow again: Now Heav'n prosper my designs;
I have a fair occasion to improve them.
How now, Gentlemen? What means a Weapon drawn?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: We, Sir, are Men that have been us'd
To handle Swords; when there's no War to imploy them,
We play with 'um in Peace: I hope 'tis no offence
To have a kindness for our best Friends.
Sure he knows us not.—

sp.speaker: 1 Com.
sp.l: Alter your Countenance as much as possible,
Captain; perhaps he may not know us.

sp.speaker: 2 Com.
sp.l: I'll seem blowing my Nose, and so hide my face.—
'Slid, I have no Handkerchief to do it with.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: You stare as if you did not know me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Know you? how shou'd we know you?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No? that's strange; one of you was so civil
To lend me a Sword lately;
Can you yet call me to remembrance?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: We know not what you mean; if we were Friends,
We are not now at leisure to answer idle questions.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nay, you must stay; come, no blustring;
I am provided now, look you— He shews a Sword under his Gown.
I shall not trouble you for a Sword again.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Wou'd he had mine, where I cou'd wish it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I am sorry I have an unpleasant question to ask you;
But yet it must be answer'd.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Must!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes, must; and you will do it calmly,
For all your stormy looks.
Bladder, if thou continuest thus to swell,
I'll make an hole to let out your vain humour.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: 'Tis well you are a Man of Peace, or else—

sp.speaker: 1 Com.
sp.p: Not half so much as he is.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Never at peace with Murtherers; Impudent Villains,
Who hir'd you to that damn'd act
Of murthering the generous Cialto?
Had not your feet been nimbler than the Sword,
I'd paid you your just hire, Sir—Come, confess.

sp.speaker: 1 Com.
sp.l: We are undone.—Lord, how our Captain looks big,
And trembles all at once!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: We do not understand you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Well, I cannot stay to parley;
Here, take away these Rascals Swords.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How, our Swords!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come, come; nay, it must be so;
I know your gentle natures.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Why, Sir, I deny nothing to one of your Coat,
Or else—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: You wou'd deliver them however.

sp.speaker: 1, 2 Com.
sp.p: Good Sir, disgrace us not.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Pox on't, wou'd that were the worst;
How the Rogues stand upon their credit?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Disgrace you! is that possible? Come, deliver, deliver,
Or you shall have ours, d' see, where you do not wish them.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Well, our Religion obliges me to this; but it shall be upon
Condition you use it well till you return it;
'Tis a good Blade.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: If the Blade be good, you shall have a Knife out of it,
'Tis your only Weapon, this was not well mounted.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you are merry, and we take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O, by no means; you must deliver your selves up too.
Here carry these Gentlemen Murtherers
To Cialto's Kinsman; these are the Rogues
He has been looking for; I leave them to his Examination.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: O, good Sir, we will do any thing.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A way with them; I'll follow at a distance,
If they stir; and d' hear—

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.—Come, my Masters.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: What say you Friends? umh—
This was a good Bargain; we shall never have such another:
How plaguily you guess'd! we are not likely
To live to make another: What say you
To a Dialogue with Fear and Conscience?

sp.speaker: 1 Com.
sp.l: Why, if we hang we shall be in no more wants,
And you'll be in no more frights, Captain.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Come along, Gentlemen of the peaceable Blade:
But, d' hear? if you can yet be honest,
And confess truly and penitently,
You may 'scape, I'll undertake it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: We will confess all we know, Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Com.
sp.p: Yes, and more too, if that will do't.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.p: Come, despair not then.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter, as to the Nunnery, Castruccio, Moreno, Brancadoro, and Bottolo.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: If they be here, we'l fetch them out with a vengeance;
Knock, Bottolo, break the Gate down.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.p: They are deaf, or else at Prayers.

sp.speaker: Bran
sp.l: I, so they had need, to ask forgiveness
For all their tricks. How out of Countenance, Uncle,
Will my Mistress be when the sees me?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: And my Mistress too, Nephew.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why there's one comfort yet, they did not run
After other Men; I'd have made any Man smoak
That shou'd have been so bold to have ventur'd
On my Mistress.—What, no body come yet?—Knock again;
These be sine tricks.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: Not a distressed Damsel yet appears
Out of the sacred Castle:—Now one bolts; Enter Nun.
We shall have a godly Exhortation,
Whether we get any Women, or no.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: What means this earnest knocking at the Gates?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: What a foolish question's that? we wou'd come in.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: Our Laws forbid that men shou'd enter here.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Fiddle faddle, I'll come in, and fetch others out too;
See who shall say me nay,

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Use no rude force, 'twill be a disrespect
To Heaven, as well as want of manners:
Is there a cause for all this passion?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Yes, that there is; here you shelter every Run-away;
Bring 'um out, or I'll seeze you.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.p: Why he'l beat her; 'tis a fierce Hector.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: What is it you demand, or whom?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why, we demand Samira and Emilia;
Here is her Uncle, and the others Father:
My Name's Signior Brancadoro; you have heard on't,
I warrant you, e're now.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: I know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: 'Tis true, holy Maid, such we have lost,
And hicher they are fled.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Certainly, Sir, there are none such here.
But I'll go in and ask the truth.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: We thank you.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: 'Slid, if she had not left her tricks and denials,
I wou'd have hit her a dowse in the chops.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: Like enough; perhaps he ne'r struck any body in his life,
And now wou'd flesh himself upon a woman.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: Here are no such persous as you enquire for.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: How, how! why my Daughter Emilia left a Letter
Upon her Table, expressing she fled hither,
For some trouble she had within her.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: There's some abuse in this; for but e'en now
There was a Friar that enquir'd for these Ladies;
He held a Gentleman seem'd hurt to death:
He was earnest, as you are; but he was satisfi'd,
As you may please to be.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: No, it does not please us to be satisfi'd,
Nor will we be satisfied; let's in and search.
—That hurt Gentleman was Cialto, without question.
—Now if I cou'd but find my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: I hope you do not mean to be injurious.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I hope you do not think it lawful
To conceal Children from their Parents; this wou'd be
The refuge then of every wilful Child.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Pray believe you are not now abus'd;
By our best hopes there are no such Persons
Within our Walls; we wou'd not for a world deny a Truth.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: This is strange; but we must believe.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: But we may chuse whether we will or no.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Heaven restore all you have lost,
And then preserve it to you.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: We thank you.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I'll not thank her; a pox of her truths;
I'll not be couzen'd by any holy Jugler of them all.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Come, let's not neglect to enquire some other way;
'Tis vain to linger here.
Signior Brancadoro, what course take you?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I'll go about a little business, and presently
Set some to enquire; if she be above-ground, I'll have her.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Farewel, Signior; we'l lose no time neither;

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Some comfort yet, that I have such fair hopes:
Cialto's dead; now I shall keep my Estate quietly;
And if I cou'd but find my Mistress, I shou'd have her too.
Now the roaring Lion's dead, I dare look after my Prey.
Well,—what's best to do? let me consider.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: What, is he studying; why the Devil
Does he thus seem to search for prudent thoughts,
That has not lodging in his Brains for one?
Yet he studies; something is in the matter.
Fortune, that brought those beauteous Prisoners under
My power, prosper me now in driving of my Bargain.—Sir.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: How now?—O Villerotto, come just in the nick;
I want thy advice and help; my Mistress
Is not here at the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: How, Sir! not at the Nunnery! why, you told me that
Emilia had left a Note upon her Table,
That she was fled hither; and is neither here?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: Pox of her Note; neither she nor Samira are here.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Who told you this?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: Why, a little harlotry Nun.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: She lyed sure.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I said so; I was going once to hit her a Cuff o'th' Ear,
But that she told me some good News.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: What was that?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: She told me a Gentleman was dying, and a Friar
Has carried him away; that's you know who.
Hast heard any News?

sp.speaker: Vil
sp.p: Yes, your Enemy is dead.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: For certain?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: So 'tis reported generally.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why, I have nothing then to fear but his Ghost;
And if that shou'd be troublesom, I'll quiet him,
If Christendom can afford a Conjurer.
Now if I cou'd but find my Mistress.—But Villerotto,
If any of the Rogues shou'd be taken that know thee.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: I hope not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Hope!—is't come to that? Art not sure,—ha?
Now shall not I sleep one wink this Night;
I shall do nothing but hink and dream,
And dream, and think of Judges, Serjeants, Bars,
And Hangmen; wou'd I had ne'r medled with it.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: There is a way, Sir, to secure you.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: Name it, name it, good Villerotto.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: I must go plant, Sir, in another Country;
Then you are safe.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why, faith and troth I shall be loth to part with thee;
But what must be, must be; Friends must part.
—Wou'd I were well rid of him. Aside.
If thou think'st it • it, I shall be rul'd.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: And consent I shall be gone.

sp.speaker: Bran
sp.l: But against my will, as I'm an honest man;
For let the worst come to the worst, I know thou woud'st not
Betray me,—wou'dst thou, Villerotto?—ha?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Nay, I cannot tell what operation
A Rack and Torture might have on me; I am flesh and blood.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: So am I too, I know it by my shaking.
This was a bugs word;—wou'd he were gone. Aside.
Nay, Villerotto, 'tis for thy safety too as well as mine,
That I consent; when wou'dst go?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Soft, Sir something is first to be consider'd on.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: What's that? what's that?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: First tell me, Sir, is there no news of the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: No, no; neither tale nor tidings.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Have Signior Castruccio nor Moreno
Heard nothing neither?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: Not a syllable; I have told you all.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Are not the old Gentlemen much troubled?
You bear your Losses pretty well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I have took on too, that I have,
As much as the best of 'um; it has made me
Ready to hang my self; but while my Money's le • t
I shan't part with this World easily; yet I wou'd give somewhat
More than I'll say, to get my Mistress once again.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: What wou'd you give, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Nay, nothing, unless I were sure to have her,
And then sure she wou'd not run away agen.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: What wou'd you give to marry her?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I, I, that's the business that I am to look after;
I must get some Heirs quickly,
For fear the Brancadoro's Race shou'd cease.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: That were pity.— Aside.
But if I cou'd be instrumental, nay, the only means
To find your Mistress out, and then marry her to you; what then?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: Why, she may run away afterwards, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: But what if I shou'd put you to Bed together? after that
'Twill be too late for her to take her flight.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: I marry, Sir; do this, and I'll give thee twenty Crowns.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: I thought so.—You are wondrous bountiful:
But not to trifle longer, look you, Sir,
If you sign this for my comfortable Subsistence, I'll be gone; He shews a Writing.
'Tis to secure you in a certain Safety:
And into the Bargain I'll help you to your Mistress;
You shall wed her, and Bed her.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: What is't? let's see.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: There's the Sum, Sir.

div.stage: He points in the Writing. Brancadoro reads it.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: How! Two thousand Crowns a year!
I'll give two thousand of my Teeth as soon.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Why then, Sir, take your chance, and I'll take mine:
I must not starve, nor will I.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: But if thou shou'dst not help me to her.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Then I'll be gone, and forfeit my Reward.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I wou'd fain have her; but I wou'd fain keep my Money:
But if I don't, he'l betray me, or cut my Throat; Aside.
'Tis a terrible dogged Fellow.
Well, Villerotto, I'll think on't; come along, we'll go try
If we can drive a Bargain:—But dost know where she is?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: That I do not tell you; 'tis enough, I'll run the venture.
Hark you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ha!—'tis he; 'tis Brancadoro and his Rascal,
That did attempt Cialto's Life: Fortune sure
Has offer'd them thus fairly to me, to make some use of:
I hope they know me not; I'll try:
Save you, Gentlemen;—may it not appear rude to ask you
If you know one call'd Signior Brancadoro?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: Yes, I know him as well as I know my self.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I have a little business with him, Sir,
And wou'd be glad to know where I might find him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why, did I not tell you I knew him as well as my self?
That's as much as to say, I am he, if you mean
The Honourable Brancadoro, Son
And Heir to Brancadoro, who was lately
The great rich Senator.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis he, Sir, I mean, whose known worth
Made it a duty in me to acquaint him
Of a black Scandal some wild Tongues have cast upon him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: What's the business? if they talk of me,
I'll make 'em hold their Tongues.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: How's this!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: It will deserve your Ear, Sir:
The cause that made me knowing of your wrongs,
Such I dare call 'em, was by some discourse
That happen'd of the unfortunate Cialto's Death;
There 'twas reported, that an idle Fellow,
Who takes on him the Title of a Captain,
Gives out that he was hir'd by a Servant of yours
To murder him; and they talk as if the Captain,
And his lewd Companions, had been secur'd,
At least search'd after, by the direction of a Friar,
But what Friar I cou'd not hear.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Plague on that holy Rascal.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: Hey, hey, a Friar! what Friar, Villerotto?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Why the Devil do you ask me? I know no Friar.
O the damn'd Coxcomb!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: They grow concern'd; it works.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Villerotto, d' hear? if thou cou'dst be sure to help me
To Samira, and then woud'st be gone into another Country,
I wou'd sign the Writing.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: I'll do it, Sir; nor shall you set your hand to't,
Till I have shew'd you I can do it:—But hark you, Sir,
If you shall then refuse it, I'll betray all.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: Like enough; I must do't.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Ha,—a lucky Fancy mingles on the suddain
Among my crouding Thoughts; 'tis excellent;
This Friar may be a • it person,—I'll try him.—
Let me see,—'tis right.—If I joyn Brancadoro to his Mistress,
That way my Fortune's gain'd; and to be safe,
This Friar shall make Emilia mine;
That done, her Friends will ne'er endure to see
Her Husband hang'd; though Brancadoro share part of the Feast,
Yet by his leave I'll taste both Dishes first.—Sir,
Pray give me leave to ask this honest Friar
Some Questions in relation to your Service.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You cannot tell, Sir, whether these Rascals
Are yet in Custody, or not?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Nor cou'd you hear what Friar this is?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I am almost a Stranger in Sienna.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I like that.— Aside.
You have exprest a great Kindness and Respect
For my Master Brancadoro; possibly, Sir,
I cou'd propose a Service you might do him.
That might deserve a large Reward.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I shou'd be glad to have that in my power, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Perhaps men of your Profession may scruple
To do a thing in private, without the allowance of all Parties.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Hark you, a word in private.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Let me alone, Sir, to make good the Title,
And fit the Party ready for possession.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: O happy Accident! I am ravish'd with my good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What means all this? I'll try the bottom of it.

sp.speaker: Vill
sp.l: Come, Sir, be chearful, and be confident. To Brancad.
In a few hours, I'll make you safe and happy.
If your Occasions, reverend Sir, permit you
To undertake what I have mention'd to you,
I'll shew you suddenly your Clients.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I am ready, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: You must engage to Secrecy.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Upon my holiness.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Nay, you have forsworn that already in your discourse.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Upon my life, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Come, Sir, to your House then, there you shall see
What I will do in order to my promise.—Sir,
I hope this reverend person shall receive
Rewards proportionable to that Service
He is engag'd to do you:—but—
When we come there you must be pleas'd to use
A little patience, till I have brought together
The persons you must tye in sacred Bonds.
I'll on before, Sir,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I shall observe all you direct.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: What does he mean, trow?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I cannot guess; but I believe 'tis something
In order to your Service.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis a notable Fellow; and you wou'd say so,
Did you know as much as I:
As cunning as my Mistress is, he'l go near
To hunt her out, let her make as many Doubles as she will.
Come, Sir, I'll bid you Welcom at my House;
'Tis not the worst in Sienna; you shall take a full View of it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: You oblige me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: So, now to my Prisoners:
A single Beauty cou'd not have the power
To keep my Blood thus at high Tide; if one
Permits my Veins to find but the least Ebb,
The other makes 'em rise, and so kept always
Flowing by one or t'others Eyes:
And like my Blood, my Flames find no retreat:
—I must allay my Fires,—or waste—
In this expence of Heat.—Come forth, come forth, Enter Samira, and Emilia, and Taccola
My Lady Brides, you shou'd have made such Fools
Of Men.—'Tis not amiss to give you Joy.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What means the Villain?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: O give him gentle words, his Looks are dreadful.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Give him Rats-bane.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O speak gently to him! when I was a Girl
They us'd to frighten me with such a one.—I tremble.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Fear not, Emilia; the Villain dares not wrong us.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: But the Villain dares revenge his Wrongs.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Who has injur'd thee?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: He that did it will do so no more,
I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Why, this Wound, as shallow as it is,
Was Fathom'd by Cialto's Sword,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Pish.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: 'Tis true indeed; but I was more bold with him,
And put in farther; he had no time
To make a Will; I doubt he left you nothing.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What dost thou mean,—Screech-Owl?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Oh, you have no mind to understand;
This 'tis plainly, Cialto's dead;
I kill'd him in my own Defence.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Villain thou lyest, in every thing thou lyest;
He cou'd do nothing basely; nor could thy power
Reach his generous Life.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Why, in good truth, 'twas he that stir'd my Blood,
And made this Hole to let it out at; but
As Luck wou'd have it, 'twas not deep enough:
I saw his Errour, and did rectifie it;
I thrust my Sword two or three Inches deeper,
And that laid him to rest.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: O Heaven protect us.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Why now you run on that Mistake again;
No help can come so quickly as you'l want it.

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.p: Thou dost not mean to ravish us, dost thou, Varlet?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Us! canst thou be ravish'd, old willingness?

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.l: How do you know, Jackanapes,
Whether I am willing or no? you never try'd yet.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Nor ever will: This she Devil will ravish me.
Be quiet, or I'll slit your Tongue; d'see this.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: O for some help! I'll tear the Villain.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Peace, pray peace, let me beg again;
Good Sir, let's go, why do you fright us so?
You dare not be so wicked as you talk.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Pretty; their different tempers bring to my enjoyment
Variety of Bliss; in her Embraces
I shall enjoy a Calm, and childish Innocence;
In th'other, loftiness of Mind and Spirit,
As if kind Nature had presented now
All that she cou'd produce for me to rifle.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Do you not hear me, Sir? I pray release us:
You have no cause to keep us Prisoners;
Yet we will pay a Ransom.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Why, so you shall before you go,
Pretty one; is't more unjust for you to be my Prisoners,
Than me to be your Slave?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Our Slave!

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Nay, put not on a scornful look;
I shall not beg your pity.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: But we are willing to beg yours, good gentle Sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Beg not so meanly, he dares not injure us.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: O, by no means; why that Frown?
Those Storms shall cast away no Heart of mine;
I'll force my way to harbour in your Arms.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I mean to make my self as Fortunate
As Man can be in his full-crown'd Wishes;
I will enjoy you both.

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.p: Which two d'you mean?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Pox on thee, wou'dst thou be one?—
Nay wonder not, nor bless your selves, unless
It be in Admiration of my Justice,
Shew'd to the equal power of your Beauties;
You may see the Image of it every day;
'Tis in the labouring Bee, that gathers sweetness
From every Flower that contends in Beauty.

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.l: By that Smile he should go near
To venture on us all.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Monster, dar'st thou entertain a Thought of such a Villany?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Alas, 'tis past that, I am almost ready for Action;
Yet for all that you shall be honest Women
When I have done.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: For Heavens sake, Sir, what mean these dark Expressions;
I hope they include no Evil.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Not any; perhaps you may scruple it
A little at the first; but I'll allow you
Some small time to consider on't:
What an excellent Contrivance 'twill be!
You shall have all Love's stolen and sweetest Joys,
And yet be honest; come prepare.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: For my embraces.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: For those of Snakes first.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: O, mine are gentler far.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Villain, thou—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Pray peace, and let me beg once more,
Upon my Knees; 'Pray, Sir, do not affright us,
I know you cannot mean the thing you threaten;
You are too wise, by our unhappiness
To bring on your own ruine.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Ha, ha, why you will not publish your own shame;
This will not do; no, if I were sure
That death waited for me, as soon as I had crown'd
My Passion and Revenge, I wou'd think it
A good bargain, to chop a little time for so much satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Be merciful, and kill us.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: That's to be cruel to my self—but I trifle time,
A little business calls me; be wise, and meet
My embraces willingly; if not, know your doom;
For by those Powers that govern me, Love and Revenge,
I'll sacrifice both your enjoyments to them,—
So ponder till I return.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Die, Emilia.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: When, Madam?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Presently.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Alas, I tremble at your naming it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Why do you shake? you must dye one day?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I know it, by that time I may be willing;
Old Age, or a Disease may make it welcome,
At least more gentle, than it now appears
By an approaching violence—but—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O rather with a juster apprehension
Recount the lingering Torments a Sickness
Or old Age may bring on; a violent Feaver
May make the Body a Furnace for the Soul
To suffer, not to live in; or old Age
May take away our Reason, and the use of Sense and Faculties,
And rob the Body and Soul both of their Eyes: this way
A minute's pain assures felicity for ever.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Which way shou'd we do it?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: See, this I had still about me in all my fears She draws a short Dagger.
Of being forc'd to be made Wife to Brancadoro:
Why do you wink? the brightness of it shines
Most lovely in my Eyes, when I but think
What service it may do in sending us
To a perpetual Peace.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Can a Soul be carried through a stream of Blood,
To peace in t'other World? is't not a Sin to destroy Life?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: 'Tis to avoid a greater sin we do it:
Dare you, nay, can you live stain'd with this—
I tremble more to name or think on that,
Than on the death that will prevent it.
But I have given you my Opinion,
And will afford you my Example:
If you stay behind me you will repent,
Among those miseries that I am freed from.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Oh! do not speak of leaving me behind you,
To the rude passions of this horrid Villain;
I know not how to live without you,
Nor dye, but as you teach me;
Pray blame me not, nor take it ill of me:
Sick Men, though they are told, and do believe
That health is offer'd in a bitter potion,
Shrink at the taking of it; 'tis no more in me:
I know, at last I shall chuse death, rather than shame;
—Yet I know not how I shall endure to hurt my self,
I have cryed when I have but cut my Finger.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: That only was, because 't was unexpected;
Your resolution now for a just cause
Will make this welcome, and prepare you for it.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I fear I shall hardly strike home,—
Then I may suffer all that shame and mischief
I would avoid; pray therefore grant me one thing.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: To kill me first.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: That were to commit Murder.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why, have you a better title to your own Life,
Than unto mine? you purchas'd one no more
Than you did t'other; there is no contract, or permission,
Granted from Heaven, that allows the difference.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: But alas, my sweet Emilia,
I never shall endure to hurt thee.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Nor your self neither, did not that vertue prompt you
Which bids me beg it, and then the Argument's the same for me.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Pretty reason'd; but it will be needless
To dispute this; I know my fair Example,
In dying first, will arm thy feeble hand,
With double strength, to force a passage
For thy unstained Soul to fly with mine,
Where every thing is in perpetual lustre.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Shall we know one another there?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: No question of it, else this bad World
In something might exceed the best.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: You have confirm'd me, Madam, pray forgive
My simple, if not unbeseeming fears;
'T was no dispute my vertue did admit of,
But a confusion brought upon me suddenly,
By nature, and still flattering hope, Reasons, and Vertues Enemies.
Come, dear Emilia, we'll prepare our selves,
And make the circumstances of our Death
Familiar to us; for 'tis practice only
Takes the sharp nature off from things,
And gives them new ones, that at the last
We shall be so much strangers to the thoughts,
Or the desires of Life, that all will seem
Already done, which we resolve to try,
And we shall both seem dead before we dye.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: WHY do I still pursue, what still must fly,
And what I dare not wish to overtake?
It seems like the pursuit of night, which follows day
In the same track, and yet can never reach it;
That distance nature did for them decree,
And honour has design'd the same for me:
Yet still there is a mutiny within
Against those Laws which honour strictly makes;
And Passion like a cunning Traytor sets
The name of liberty on its own Rebellion.

div.stage: Enter Baptista, Montalto, and his two Companions.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: Ha, Baptista!

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: A word, Sir, in your Ear—My Master, Sir, by chance
Has lighted on the Villains that attempted you;
He thought it fit that you shou'd first examine 'em,
As Kinsman to your self, and to that end
Has sent them to you; farther, he bid me tell you
That in a little time you will perceive
You wrong'd him in your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.l: Prethee say no more;
My thoughts have so much disproportion in them,
That they are neither just nor equal unto my self, or him;
Has he not sent his Pardon by thee?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: He can take nothing ill of you, Sir,
Perhaps he did admire a little.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.l: He is a perfect Friend, and can love one
Whose Mind is lost, as well as Fortunes.
—Now, Gentlemen, have you received your Wages?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: For what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: For killing my Kinsman Cialto.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: We hope he is not dead.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.l: D' you hope so, Rascals; Come confess
Every Circumstance, how it was done,
And who hir'd you to't; if you miss a tittle—or—

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: This Gentleman told us,
If we did confess, we shou'd not suffer.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.l: Well, if you do it truly, and afterwards
Perform all I enjoin you, I will make good his word:
Come, who hir'd you?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: It was an ill minded Man, Sir.
One that belong'd to Signior Brancadoro.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: Was it his Masters instruction?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I, no doubt on't, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: Did he say so?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yes, and more too.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: What more?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Why, he told us, it was an honourable action,
And therefore wou'd share in't himself;
And accordingly he said his Master shou'd reward us.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: You know him when you see him?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: I Com.
sp.p: Good Sir, let us not suffer, we have your word.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Trust to it; have you any more to say?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir, of any consequence.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: Wel, what trivial thing have you?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: When we were waiting, Sir,
For that worthy and unhappy Gentleman, Cialto,
A couple of silly Women by chance came by, and the Rascal
Snatch'd them up too; all was Fish that came to his Net.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: How, Women? what Women? speak, quickly, ha—

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Why does your Worship grow angry?

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: Speak, Dogs, what Women?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: What a Rogue was I to name them,
'Slid, 'tis he himself.

sp.speaker: I Com.
sp.p: You must be over-doing it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Plague on you, did not you advise to tell all?
Nay, more than all if need were?

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: It may be it was Samira and Emilia: Rogues, what Women?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Good Sir, we know not;
But he talk'd of their running away
Upon their Wedding day,
And took them, as he said, upon suspicion
Of Murdering his Master Brancadoro.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.l: It must be they, the circumstance assures it.
O you Dogs, did you help take them! I'll send
Your mischievous Souls to that Devil that instructs them.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: O good Sir, we hope you are the Gentleman,
And there's no hurt done, O good Sir,

sp.speaker: I Com.
sp.p: Remember your promise, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: We have more to confess, Sir;
Or if you please, we'll unconfess it all again.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: I had forgot to ask, what did the slave do with them?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: He sent them Prisoners to his Master's House, as we think.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.l: O Heavens! Rogues, Prisoners! Come along with me;
For if I find you tell me any lyes,
I'll spoil your Throats from venting any more.
Come, good Baptista, help guard the Rascals;
If they but offer to stir, kill 'em.
I'll carry back to the Slaves heart
All these intended mischiefs,
And break upon them like a Whirl-wind,
Wrapping them up together into nothing.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Come, come, Emilia, dry those tender Eyes,
We are not going to be miserable,
But to be safe from miseries.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Wou'd it were past; I am willing to reach
My journeys end; yet I start like one
That travels in the night, in unknown ways;
For we must through darkness,
Wander in places, from whence none that went
Ever return'd to tell us what they were.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O do not shake thy vertuous resolution
With feeble apprehensions; 'tis a journey
That we must one day take: All the dispute
Which can be rais'd is only from the loss
Of some uncertain time, which yet perhaps
May prove so full of miseries, you'd wish
That Fate which now you wou'd so much decline.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: My resolution's firm; for all my shakings
They are but starts which sometimes nature makes;
As Wolves kept tame may now and then
Provok'd by appetite, or some displeasure,
Start into actions like their usual wildness,
Before they were reduc'd to an obedience;
So 'tis with me, though I have brought my nature
To a tameness, and submission:
Yet at the unwelcome prospect that it takes
Of my intended dissolution.—
It starts within me, and wou'd fain break
Those severe Fetters, Vertue and Reason tyes them up with.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Here take thy choice then; She shews a Knife and a Dagger.
This Knife by chance
Taccola had about her: which will you have?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: The Dagger, if you please; that seems the sharpest,
And will be best for my weak hand.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Nay do not weep that we shall dye;
But smile to think how we shall live in Fame.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I must weep, since I must part with you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: We shall meet again so quickly,
Thy tears will be but thrown away:—
Now hide that fatal Friend unto thy honour,
And when I strike, strike too, that we may sail
In one anothers Arms, and go to rest together.
—See, the Monster comes, be resolute.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Fear me not.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: How fare my beauteous Prisoners? what is't,
Sadness, or modesty that fixeth thus
Your down-cast Eyes? come, come, I'll be more ingenuous,
And acknowledge the happiness I shall enjoy;
But you must be bashful; go in, go in,
And there I'll hide your blushes, that if you please,
You shall unseen blush that you were unwilling.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Sure thou canst not be such a prodigious Monster;
Hast thou neither fear of earthly punishment,
Nor Heavens vengeance?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Pish, I'll not trifle, nor defer my joys They draw their Dagger and Knife.
A minute longer: Thus, I'll force you two—how!—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Are you amaz'd? were you so unacquainted
With all good, nay, with any thought of it,
That you could never think there might be Women
That wou'd prefer their death before dishonour?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Indeed I have read of a foolish Lucrece;
But I believe the story otherwise
Than perhaps you may do; yet if you have
A mind to imitate that willful Matron,
Kill your selves as she did, when you know what was done.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Stop thy lewd breath, thou Monster;
We need not to be told when we shou'd dye,
We are prepar'd, but not as your damn'd tongue
Directed us.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: And this you think will stop me;
No, your Romance trick will not do:
I know you dare not venture to hurt your selves;
And therefore—thus—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Strike, Emilia, strike home be sure.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Hold excellent Ladies, hold;
Pardon my cruel curiosity, that led me
To make this tryal of you; you have shew'd
There is a vertue, which I thought impossible
To live with Women; I have call'd back to me
The Opinion of your Sexes stedfast goodness,
Which has been so long banished from me.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Can this be real!

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: You see it must be so; 'tis no faint repentance,
Charm'd from your tears, or sad expressions,
Which might be feign'd in Women; but my conversion
Comes from the real knowledge of a vertue
That wou'd have shook Mans Faith to think in Woman.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: This amazes me.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Why do you wonder? is't not possible
A Man may once grow good? why do you mistrust?
Are you not in my power still? take heed, fair Saints,
Of sharing any guilt, that seems like mine,
So slowly to believe goodness in Man,
As I have done in Woman: you know what Virtue is;
I scarce knew it till you taught it me;
And you will be more guilty than I was,
If you believe as slowly as I did.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Sure 'tis real?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: You then will know it, when I have restor'd
You to your liberty, as you have done
Me to my long-lost goodness.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: If this be real, we shall believe our selves
As much preserv'd by you, as if another
Had been the intended Ravisher; for 'tis greater
Virtue to rescue us thus from your self,
Than from another; as much as 'tis harder
To overcome our Passions, than an Enemy:

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: I glory much in that high Character
You raise me to; pray give me leave to seal
My Pardon on your fair hands? nay, permit They offer their left hands.
My most ambitious Lips to receive it
Upon those noble hands that were to write
The horrid Tragedy, with your vertuous Blood.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ha, deceived?

div.stage: He offers to kiss their right hands, and so snatches away their Weapons.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Ah me?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: I cann't but laugh to think how we have cousen'd
One another; did you believe I was turn'd virtuous?
Troth I never thought you were so foolish to be so really.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Dost thou take pains to appear Devil?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: No, not at all; I do it easily:
The truth on't is, I fear'd you might have acted
Some pretty odd phantastical Scene,
Perhaps to let a little blood out, and then
Talk sinely, whilst the purple drops distill'd;
Calling your selves, your Virtues Martyrs;
Then, in a tone most neatly counterfeited,
Fall into high notions of meeting in Elysium,
And walking in perpetual springing Groves,
Or some strange imagin'd pleasure;
Perhaps all the while believe as much as I:
But by this means you might have lost some of that blood,
Which I have so much use of for to stir you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Monster, Devil, wilt thou not permit us a way to dye?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Kill us, Sir, and yet we will believe you gentle.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: After I have done, you may do what you please.
—Come.—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Tac.
sp.p: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Plague of this clap of thunder;
I'll dispose of you,
And spoil the spring of your chops.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Some help, good Heaven.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Let's stop our breaths,
Or tear the Devils Throat out.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: No help left us!

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Who shou'd help you? I have gag'd
Your foul mouth'd hound, she can fill up the cry no more:
Yield quietly, or I'll drag you—thus—

sp.speaker: Sam. Emil.
sp.p: Help, help, murder, murder!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What noise is this; blast me! are my Eyes true?
Or is that blessed shape ever before them?
It was their cryes. Hold, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Ha, who wanted your sacred Company
Before your time.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I heard a noise, Sir, and I did not know
Whether you might not be in danger.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: You see I am not;
Wait where I told you, till I send for you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Then 'twas the Ladies, Sir, cry'd out, it seems.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: What then?
Is it a usual call for you when Women squeak?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: O Sir, for Heavens sake help us: we shall be—

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Stop your mouth, or I'll stop it for you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Good Sir, use no violence; perchance the Ladies
May be a little frightned from reason,
If you but give them time.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O Heaven! are all Men ill? under that habit
Can there be hid the love of sin?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Well, be gone;
I want not your advice, nor your assistance yet.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: If you please, Sir, I will endeavour to perswade them:
I can prove that necessity may excuse many things,
That wou'd be sinful, uncompell'd—if you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: No, no, be gone; you grow impertinent.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: But if you please, Sir, to hearken to my opinion.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Hang your opinion;
I do not like this Fellow; I'll trust him no more.
Ha,—what noise is this.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: A seasonable interruption.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Villerotto, why where have you been, Man?
I have been looking you up and down all the House:
Here's Bottolo come from his Master,
And has strange news for me, he says:
I told him I car'd not a farthing what 'twas.
—But for all that, I wonder what it should be?
—How now, what here, Villerotto?
Ha—hast got her? hast got her i'faith? prethee let me—

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: You had best spoil all, Sir, and destroy
The pains I have taken for you?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Nay, prethee, I will but—

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Come, you shall not But; have not I been careful,
And dare you not trust me now? Come along with me.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: What, I must salute her first, Man, in good manners.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: You must not, 'tis unseasonable;
I have not wrought her yet enough—Nay▪—

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: But why thy Sword, drawn Man?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: You shall know the reason suddenly:
Come, be quiet, and I'll perform all I promis'd.
—Hell—how I am troubled with him: Come, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Push me no pushes; I will not go;
And see who dares make me.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Come, you must, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: 'Slid, whose Master? You or I? take heed of my fury.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Good Signior Brancadoro, help us; hear us.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: To be fool'd again;
You have not a mind to be cousen'd
Once more, have you?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What's that to you? I will hear 'em.
'Slid, I will stay, and I will not go yet.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: I'll betray all, if you play the Fool thus:
Come, you must go now; Bottolo stays for you.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I will not, I say.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Go, go.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I'll follow him, and get some help.

div.stage: Exit Brancadoro. The Friar offers to go out too.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, you my worthy spiritual Counsellor;
Stir not, nor attempt to come near the door;
If you do—no more but so:
Within there, ho!—You Rascals, how came this Friar in? 2 Appear.
He told us you appointed him when he heard a noise,
That he should come.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Pox on your credulous Coxcombs; now remember
You hear me say, if he offers to come out, let me
Find him dead: Stir not, but guard the door;
He has robb'd our Masters:—If you fail, I'll cut your throats.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yet I am pleas'd that I am brought to die before her. Aside.
That with my last breath,
Which seldom unsuccessfully Petitions,
I may at once beg of the fair, and wrong'd Emilia,
Forgiveness, and belief;—yet I wou'd know
A little more, if it were possible.
My Passion makes me vainly inquisitive.
I must do't; yet it is but an idle curiosity
To ask for news the minute I must die.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: What means this Friar? does that Habit harbour
An Instrument sitted for that vile Monster?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Was there not a great noise, Ladies,
Something like Womens Cries?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: They were our Cries, Sir.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: If you cannot help us to live with Honour,
Help us to die; we had two Weapons:
Arm us but again, he has yet not disarm'd our Minds.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Wou'd I knew how; wou'd you accept it
As a true witness of my sorrow, if I die first
In the opposing that mischief I know not which way to prevent?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Ah me, we do not ask of you to die,
But to help death to us.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Strangle us then. Why do you turn away your tread?
It is a Charity to grant it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Alas, I need not say I must deny; you will believe it
When I let you know you ask it of Miranzo.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Miranzo!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: My Brother.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Fair Emilia, 'tis the criminal Miranzo,
That loves Emilia still.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O Miranzo! I blush to think how you encrease
My sense of Dangers, while you are mingled with 'em.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I see I am to blame in all Conditions,
To wish your Kindness; I but strive to nourish
A Sickness that sends Infection to your Peace.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: What must become of us?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thus naked as I am, I will defend you;
And with my Breast I'll dull his Sword, perhaps his Cruelty.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O do not talk more cruelly; Death is gentler,
Which you may help us to.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Ah Brother, be not so rash, do not deceive your self;
A thousand Lives lost in our Defence
Would not give stop to his lewd Purposes:
Heaven sure will send some Remedy. O Brother! O Cialto!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Forgive me dearest Sister, I had forgot
To tell you, Cialto lives; though this Villain was one
Of them that did attempt his Murder.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O do not flatter me, for I shall grow
As much out of love with Death, as even now
I was with Life.—Is there no hope?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The Villain has appointed them to murder me,
If I attempt but to go forth.—Ha,—
Now I think on't, it was the Friar
He gave them charge of: I am none; I'll try
If they will let me out; so I may call He takes up his Disguise.
Some help.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: O take heed!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis but attempting.—But first
I'll set the Friar in the best posture I can.
Here, Sister, support my Shape a little,
To countenance my Design;—nay, no trifling.— He sets his Habit on his Sister.
So—now to your Prayers,—within there, ho:—
• . How now, who are you?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A Friend of Villerotto's, who left me to
Stay a little while for your Assistance:
Now I am going, have the greater Care
Of the Friar there; he may venture to escape,
For he has robb'd your Master.
We warrant you: Sir Friar, you had not best try to bolt.

div.stage: Miranzo goes out, and returns back suddenly.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I have done ill, I dare not venture
Them a minute; Honour and Reason turn me back—
Blest Opportunity,—Rogue— He strikes up one of their Heels, t'other sights a little, and runs out with a noise; he gets a Sword from one of them.
How now, what do you mean, Sir.
Help, help.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: So, I have something now to frame an Argument
For my self with, and to Dispute a little.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Now you may kill us; you have got a Sword▪

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Dear Emilia, do you believe, I know not how Emilia weeps.
To make a better use of such a Weapon?
—Pray weep not, do not unman me now.
Hark, a Noise.

div.stage: Enter Villerotto with him that run out, and another.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Ha, Miranzo, are you Metamorphosed from a Friar?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Do you stare Monster? is a Sword bright Metal?
The Mirrour that can only shew
Th' affrighting shapes of thy unheard of Villanies.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Alas, I have not been afraid a long time;
I have forgot what 'tis.—Hark, a Noise. A Noise within.
Dispatch him quickly, you shall tell no News, Sir.
—Ha, who is this new Face for?

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: This shall tell thee, Villain.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Hold—

div.stage: Miranzo drives out the two men, comes back and parts them.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.l: Miranzo, rob me not of that Revenge,
Which only can belong to me
—Hark, a noise,—guard the Passage, or we may all be lost. A noise still.
Nay, trifle not;—hark, the Noise encreases, dispatch.
—Now, Sir, do you stare to see Cialto,
Whom you hir'd Rogues to Murder?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: I do not stare, nor am I frightned:
What, y'are not dead it seems?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: O, Cialto!

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.l: Ha, since thou hast given me cause
To view thee with a strict survey, my Eyes
Are grown clear sighted,
And find thee not the Villain which thou seem'st,
But what thou art; the base Borazzo.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: 'Tis well, we know one another then.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.l: Excellent Rascal, has your hot Revenge
Been rak'd up all this while?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Cou'dst thou expect less from me, whom thou hast disgrac'd
And ruin'd, by Cashiering me from my Command?

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.l: And what canst thou expect, Villain,
But that Fate thou didst design for me?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: My Sword says no.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Hold, hold, I command you hold, Cialto:
Hold, Sir, I will engage for your Forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: My Forgiveness! this is my Indemnity.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.l: Do not hang upon me, unless you mean
To have me murder'd in your Arms.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Nay, I think I may drive this through your Shield.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: For Heavens sake let me go.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: And Heaven protect you.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Now, Sir, what think you?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: That I shall presently be quiet, and think no more. Help, help.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: 'Tis vain to call, no man has Charity
Left for thee; trouble not thy Throat,
Unless thou hast some Devil to call upon.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Let me embrace my dear Cialto,
For whom still ready Victory spreads her Wings,
When e'er his wav'd Sword gives her but the sign.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: Can Miranzo forgive all those distracted Jealousies
My miseries begot within me?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: You injure me to ask it; go dry Samira's Eyes.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: I dare not now approach you, fair Samira,
But as I wou'd those Powers (I durst not hope to reach
With any thing but Prayers:) Permit me to receive forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: For pursuing you with all my miseries.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: If you lov'd me as well as you profess,
My kindness wou'd infuse such joy into you,
As wou'd admit no sense of your Misfortunes.
Cannot my Love and Passion for you, have as much power as a little sleep,
To render you insensible of Miseries,
To which you only give afflicting Natures?

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: Fool that I was, to think that I cou'd be wretched,
Whilst you were kind; forgive me dear Samira:
Permit me, fair Emilia, to kiss your hands too.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Generous Sir, I owe an equal Obligation to you.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Now spare me a minute.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What means he?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: Signior Brancadoro, I think Miranzo told me once,
You did engage to fight with me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Now I guess; peace, this will be good sport.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: I, that was when I was married to Samira. But not else.

sp.speaker: Clia.
sp.p: Wou'd marriage make you Valiant?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: When I have try'd, you shall know my mind.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: By no means, Signior; I shall forbid the Banes:
But I must have your Answer now; look ye,
Here are two Swords, take your choice.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What does he mean?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Nay, stand still.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bran
sp.l: 'Tis neither here nor there, I'll not fight
With any man that has a less Estate
Than my self; such a one ventures nothing.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Troth, you will hardly fight then

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why, what care I; if there be no body fit
To fight with me I hope they know nothing yet.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: But, Sir, as I remember, you have something
Did once belong to me; are you not weary of it?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: It's no matter whether I am or no.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Pray let me have't again.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: So you shall, when I have nothing else to do with it.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: You are severe, Sir; I will assign you your Money
That you lent, to receive it of the Senate.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: No, do't your self, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: I'll fetch others to perswade you:
Miranzo, pray look to the rich Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What is the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I guess now, you'l perceive all presently.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Oh! Mir. How is it?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Too well; I have life enough to spend in Curses.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O Devil!

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: He makes me tremble still.

div.stage: Enter Cialto and Baptista, with Montalto, and his two Companions.

sp.speaker: Cial
sp.p: Now, my most wealthy Signior, do you know these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bran
sp.l: Not I; 'tis not likely that I should be acquainted
With such Ragamuffians.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Do you know them, angry Sir?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Yes, I know them to be rascally Cowards;
Ten such would not venture to cut one Throat.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Why, you need not be angry; they have not had their full hire.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: They deserv'd none, they did not do their business.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I know the Rogues now: He whispers.
Why, Villerotto, thou wilt not betray me, I hope.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: What was that business they shou'd have done?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Why, cut your Throat.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: Brave Villain! D'you see, Signior?
These were your Pensioners; the confidence it seems
Of their performances, made you so bold,
To promise when you were married to fight with me;
That was after I was dead, as you believ'd.
But now, Sir, the Hangman shall end our Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Good Sir, speak softly? I vow, that Villain perswaded me,
And told me I should never keep my Land
In quiet else, nor ever have my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Compound, Signior; 'tis your best way.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: What say you, noble Undertakers?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Why, Sir, we must confess—

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: 'Tis needless, Sir, 'tis needless; I will do any thing.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Offer him his Estate again; you are rich enough besides;
You'l cheat somebody else in a little while of as much more.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: No, Sir, I am not wise enough to do't;
My Father's gone, peace be with him; he perhaps
Might have given a say to some such matter.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Are you willing? you may hang else.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: No, I can't endure that I'm sure, nor hardly th'other.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come, Cialto; Signior Brancadoro,
So he may have your Friendship, is content.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: To restore your Estate again.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: Well, I love peace; he shall have an Assignment
To receive his Money from the Senate.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: That I shall never get; but I must consent.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Fear not, Signior; you have the Publick Faith for't.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: Now, Samira, I can forgive my self, if I presume
With my restor'd Fortunes too.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Take heed, Sir; for if you name it,
That generous cause that forc'd me to declare
I lov'd you, will urge me to despise you.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: I am charm'd.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: I hope, noble Signior, you will forgive Villerotto too.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd, Sir, 'tis not Villerotto;
'Tis Borazzo. an ancient Friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Pray forgive him, Sir; he may repent.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Yes, I do repent.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: That's well said; of what?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Why, that I did not rifle those Treasuries,
And leave you nothing to enjoy, but what
I feel, the Torments of a vexed Soul:
I shou'd have sitted them for your Embraces,
And wou'd have taken care you shou'd have known it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Bold impudent Dog,

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: He was still furnish'd with too great a Courage;
So much boldness was not fit to have been trusted
But in a Frame where it was ballanc'd with much Vertue.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Come, we'l force him to be good.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: I think it must be forc'd.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: He will die snarling.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: I would die biting.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: Wou'd he had been hang'd before he bit me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Here, come hither, you that were once his Creatures;
Take him up, that he may be deliver'd from us,
Into the hands of the severest Justice.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.l: Do you believe my Spirit will endure
Tamely to wait upon a formal Sentence,
And stay till you shall force it out of doors?
No, I will hear these Wounds so wide,
I'll make it room enough to go, if it be willing.

div.stage: Enter Bottolo, after him Castruccio and Moreno.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Bot.
sp.l: What, no Body to be found in the house?—
Hey day, what's gather'd together! My Master! my Mistress!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: See, Emilia, your Father, and my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: Gentlemen, no words; you remember our Bargain.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.p: Doubt us not.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: O, my dear Father, are you still as ready to forgive me as you were wont?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: If I were angry, the sight of thee
