Wou'd bring a Joy enough to force it from me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Your pardon, Uncle, joyn'd to this, will make me and Emilia happy▪

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Is't so? was this the Trick on't? Well, well,
What must be, must be; I am Friends, Nephew;
I was partly in the Fault my self; I dare swear
I made thee half in love, with praising her.
Well,—I am glad all troubles are at an end:
But she shall still be so much mine, that I may give her to thee.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: You honour me, to own a Title in me.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: One Pardon more, Sir, for me, that in
No other thing will ever disobey you.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: What say you, Signior Brancadoro?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: I say any thing, Sir.—God's my life, I can scarce hold from crying.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: Many things, Sir, may seem strange to you;
But you shall know it all at better leisure.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Come, no more; but let forgiveness
Dwell in every Breast: Back to the Nuptials now again;
This will scarce seem an interruption:
Come, let's away; our Meat is hardly cold yet.

sp.speaker: Cial.
sp.l: The God of Love, if he can borrow Eyes,
Will be more pleas'd with this new Sacrifice;
Since by that change which he himself has made,
More equal Hearts are on his Altar laid.

div.p: THE COMMITTEE, A COMEDY. Written by the Honourable Sir ROBERT HOWARD.
LONDON, Printed for Henry Herringman, and are to be Sold by R. Bentley, J. Tonson, F. Saunders, and T. Bennet. M DC XCII.

div.head: Dramatis Personae.

list.item: Mr. Day, the Chair-man to the Committee.

div.p: SCENE LONDON.

lg.l: TO cheat the most Judicious Eyes, there be
Ways in all Trades, but this of Poetry:
Your Tradesman shews his Ware by some false Light,
To hide the Faults, and slightness from your Sight.
Nay, though 'tis full of Bracks, he'll boldly swear
'Tis excellent, and so help off his Ware.
He'll rule your Judgment by his Confidence,
Which in a Poet you'd call Impudence;
Nay, if the World afford the like again,
He swears he'll give it you for nothing then:
Those are words too a Poet dares not say;
Let it be good or bad, you'r sure to pay.
—Wou'd 'twere a pen'worth;—but in this you are
Abler to judge than he that made the Ware:
However his design was well enough,
He try'd to shew some newer fashion'd Stuff.
Not that the name Committee can be new,
That has been too well known to most of you:
But you may smile, for you have past your doom;
The Poet dares not, his is still to come.

div.head: ACT I.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Day, Mrs. Arbella, Mrs. Ruth, Colonel Blunt, and a Hackney-Coachman. Mrs Day enters brushing her Hoods, and Scarfs.

sp.speaker: Mrs Day.
sp.l: NOW out upon't, how dusty 'tis;
All things consider'd, 'tis better
Travelling in the Winter; especially for us of the better sort,
That ride in Coaches; and yet to say truth, warm weather is
Both pleasant and comfortable: 'tis a thousand pities
That fair weather should do any hurt. Well said, honest
Coachman, thou hast done thy part: My Son Abel
Paid for my place at Redding, did he not?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Yes, and please you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Well, there's something
Extraordinary to make thee drink.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.l: By my Whip, 'tis a Groat of more
Than ordinary thinness.— Aside.
Plague on this new Gentry, how liberal they are. Farewel,
Young Mistress; farewel, Gentlemen: Pray when you come by
Redding let Toby carry you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Why how now Mrs. Arbella?
What, sad? why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Arbel.
sp.p: I am not very sad.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Nay, by my honour you need not;
If you knew as much as I. Well—
I'll tell you one thing, you are well enough, you need not fear
Who ever does; say I told you so,—if you do not hurt your
Self: for as cunning as he is, and let him be as cunning as
He will, I can see with half an eye, that my Son Abel
Means to take care of you in your Composition, and will
Needs have you his Guest: Ruth and you shall be Bed-fellows.
I warrant that same Abel many and many a time
Will wish his Sisters place; or else his Father ne'r
Got him: though I say it, that shou'd not say it, yet I do
Say it—'tis a notable Fellow.—

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I am fallen into strange hands,
If they prove as busie as her tongue—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: And now you talk of
This same Abel, I tell you but one thing,
I wonder that neither he nor my Husband's Honour's
Chief Clerk Obadiah, is not here ready to attend me: I
Dare warrant my Son Abel has been here two hours
Before us 'Tis the veriest Princox;
He will ever be a galloping, and
Yet he is not full one and twenty, for all his appearances:
He never stole this trick of galloping; his Father
Was just such another before him,
And wou'd gallop with the best of 'em: he and Mistress Busie's
Husband were counted the best Horse-men in Redding, I and
Berkshire to boot. I have rode formerly behind Mr. Busie,
But in truth I cannot now endure to travel but in a Coach;
My own was at present in disorder, and so I was fain
To shift in this; but I warrant you, if his Honour, Mr. Day,
Chair-man of the honourable Committee of Sequestrations,
Shou'd know that his Wife rode in a Stage-Coach, he
Wou'd make the House too hot for some.—Why, how is't
With you, Sir? what, weary of your Journey?

sp.speaker: Col. Bl.
sp.l: Her tongue will never tire— Aside.
So many, Mistress, riding in the Coach
Has a little distemper'd me with heat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: So many, Sir? why there were but six.—
What wou'd you say if I should tell you,
That I was one of the eleven that travell'd
At one time in one Coach?

sp.speaker: Col. Bl.
sp.p: O the Devil! I have given her a new Theam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Why, I'll tell you—Can you guess how 'twas?

sp.speaker: Col. Bl.
sp.p: Not I truly. But 'tis no matter, I do believe it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Look you, thus 'twas;
There was, in the first place, my self,
And my Husband, I shou'd have said first; but his Honour
Wou'd have pardoned me, if he had heard me;
Mr. Busie that I told you of, and his Wife;
The Mayor of Redding, and his Wife;
And this Ruth that you see there, in one of our Laps—
But now, where do you think the rest were?

sp.speaker: Col. Bl.
sp.p: A top o'th' Coach sure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Nay, I durst swear you wou'd
Never guess—why—
Wou'd you think it;
I had two growing in my Belly,
Mrs. Busie one in hers, and Mrs. Mayoress of Redding
A chopping Boy, as it proved afterwards in hers;
As like the Father as if it had been spit out of his mouth;
And if he had come out of his moth, he had come
Out of as honest a Mans Mouth as any in forty Miles
Of the head of him:
For wou'd you think it,
At the very same time when this same Ruth was sick,
It being the first time the Girl was ever coach'd,
The good Man Mr. Mayor,
I mean, that I spoke of,
Held his Hat for the Girl to ease her Stomach in.— Enter Abel and Obadiah.
—O are you come,
Long look't for comes at last.
What,—you have a slow set pace,
As well as your • ally scribble sometimes:
Did you not think it sit, that I shou'd have found
Attendance ready for me when I alighted.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: I ask your Honour's pardon; for I do
Profess unto your Ladiship I had attended sooner,
But that his young Honour, Mr. Abel,
Demurr'd me by his delays.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Well, Son Abel,
You must be obey'd,
And I partly, if not, guess your business;
Providing for the entertainment of one I have in my eye;
Read her and take her:
Ah, is't not so?

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: I have not been deficient in my care, Forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Will you never leave your Forsooths?
Art thou not asham'd
To let the Clerk carry himself better,
And shew more breeding than his Master's Son?

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: If it please your Honour, I have some business
For your more private ear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: What a lamentable condition has
That Gentleman been in, faith I pity him?

sp.speaker: Arbil.
sp.p: Are you so apt to pity men?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Yes, men that are humorsom,
As I would children that are froward;
I wou'd not make them cry a purpose.

sp.speaker: Arbel
sp.l: Well, I like his humor, I dare
Swear he's plain and honest.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Plain enough of all conscience;
Faith I'll speak to him.

sp.speaker: Arbel.
sp.p: Nay prithee don't, he'l think thee rude?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Why then I'll think him an Ass.—
How is't after your Journey, Sir?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Why, I am worse after it.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Do you love riding in a Coach, Sir?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: No, Forsooth, nor talking after riding in a Coach.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: I shou'd be loth
To interrupt your Meditations, Sir:
We may have the fruits hereafter.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: If you have, they shall break loose spite of my teeth;
This Spawn is as bad as the great Pike.

sp.speaker: Arbel.
sp.p: Prithee peace: Sir—We wish you all happiness.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: And quiet, good sweet Ladies,—
I like her well enough.—
Now wou'd not I have her say any more, for fear she
Shou'd jeer too, and spoil my good opinion;
If 'twere possible, I wou'd think well of one woman▪

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Come, Mrs. Arbella, 'tis as I told you,
Abel has done it; say no more: take her by the hand, Abel.
I profess she may venture to take thee for better, for worse:
Come, Mrs. the honourable Committee will sit suddenly.
Come, let's along. Farewel, Sir.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: How, the Committee ready to sit. Plague Manet C. Blunt.
On their Honours; for so my honour'd Lady,
That was one of the eleven, was pleas'd to call 'em.
I had like to have come a day after the Fair:
'Tis pretty, that such as I have been, must compound
For their having been Rascals.
Well, I must go look a Lodging, and a Solliciter:
I'll find the arrantest Rogue I can too:
For, according to the old saying,
Set a Thief to catch a Thief.

sp.speaker: C. Careless.
sp.l: Dear Blunt, well met,
When came you, Man?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Dear Careless, I did not think to have met thee
So suddenly. Lieutenant, your Servant;
I am landed just now, man.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Thou speak'st as if thou had'st been at Sea?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: It's pretty well guest, I have been in a storm.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: What business brought thee?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: May be the same with yours:
I am come to Compound with their Honours.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: That's my business too;
Why, the Committee sits suddenly?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Yes, I know it;
I heard so in the storm I told thee of.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: What storm, Man?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Why, a Tempest as high as ever blew from
Woman's breath: I have rode in a Stage Coach, wedged in
With half a dozen; one of them was a Committee-man's
Wife; his Name is Day:
And she accordingly will be call'd,
Your Honour, and your Ladiship; with a tongue that
Wags as much faster than all other womens, as in the
Several motions of a Watch, the hand of the minute
Moves faster than that of the hours▪ There was her
Daughter too; but a Bastard without question;
For she had no resemblance to the rest of the notch'd
Rascals, and very pretty, and had wit enough
To jeer a man in prosperity to death.—
There was another Gentlewoman,
And she was handsom, nay very handsom;
But I kept her from being as sad as the rest.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Prithee, how man?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Why, she began with two or three good words,
And I desired her she would be quie •
While she was well.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Thou wei't not be so mad?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: I had been mad if I had not,—
But when we came to our Journey's end, there met us two
Such formal and stately Rascals,
That yet pretended Religion,
And open Rebellion ever painted:
It was the hopes,
And guide of the honourable Family, viz.
The eldest Son,
And the chiefest Clerk-rogues—
———————And hereby hangs a tail.
This Gentlewoman I told thee
I kept civil, by desiring her to say nothing,
Is a rich Heir of one that di'd in the
King's Service, and left his Estate under Sequestration.
This young Chicken has this Kite snatch'd up,
And designs her for this her eldest Rascal.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: What a dull Fellow wert thou,
Not to make love, and rescue her?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: I'll woo no Woman.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Woud'st thou have them court thee?
A Soldier, and not love a Siege!
How now, who art thou?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: A poor Irishman, and Christ save me, and save you all;
I prithee give me Six-pence, gad Mastero.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Six-pence? I see thou wou'dst not lose any thing
For want of asking. Here, I am pretty near,
There's a Groat for thy confidence.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: By my troth it is too little.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Troth, like enough:
How long hast thou been in England?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Ever since I came hither, i'faith.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: That's true; what hast thou done
Since thou cam'st into England?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Serv'd God and St. Patrick, and my good
Sweet King, and my good sweet Master; yes indeed.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: And what do'st thou do now?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Cry for them every day, upon my soul.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Why, where's thy Master?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: He's dead, Mastero, and left poor Teg;
Upon my soul, he never serv'd poor Teg so before.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Who was thy Master?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: E'en the good Colonel Danger.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: He was my dear and noble friend.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Yes, that he was, and poor Teg's too, i'faith now.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: What do'st thou mean to do?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: I will get a good Master, if any good Master wou'd
Get me; I cannot tell what to do else, by my soul, that
I cannot; for I have went and gone to one Lilly's;
He lives at that house, at the end of another house,
By the May-pole-house; and tells every body by one
Star, and 'tother Star, what good luck they shall have;
But he cou'd not tell nothing for poor Teg.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Why, man?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Why, 'tis done by the Stars;
And he told me there were no Stars for Irishmen:
I told him he told two or three lies upon my soul;
There were as many Stars in Ireland as in England,
And more too, that there are; and if a good Master
Cannot get me, I will run into Ireland, and see
If the Stars be not there still; and if they be,
I will come back i'faith, and beat his pate,
If he will not then tell me some good luck, and some Stars.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Poor fellow, I pity him; I fancy he's simply
Honest: Hast thou any Trade?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Bo, bub bub bo, a Trade, a Trade! an Irishman a Trade!
An Irishman scorns a Trade, that he does; I will
Run for thee forty Miles; but I scorn t'have a Trade.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Alas, poor simple fellow.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: I pity him; nor can I indure to see any miserable
That can weep for my Prince, and Friend. Well, Teg, what
Sayest thou if I will take thee?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Why, I will say thou wilt do very well then.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Thy Master was my dear friend; wert thou with
Him when he was kill'd?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Yes, upon my soul, that I was, and I did houl over
Him, and I askt him why he would leave poor Teg;
And i'faith I staid kissing his sweet face, till the
Rogues came upon me and took away all from me;
And I was naked till I got this Mantle, that I was:
I have never any Victuals neither, but a little Snuff.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Come, thou shalt live with me; love me
As thou did'st thy Master.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: That I will i'faith, if thou would'st be good too.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Now to our business; for I came
But last night my self; and the Lieutenant and I
Were just going to seek a Sollicitor.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: One may serve us all; what say you, Lieutenant,
Can you furnish us?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Yes, I think I can help you to plough
With a Heifer of their own.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Now I think on't, Blunt, why did'st not
Thou begin with the Committee-man's Cow?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Plague on her, she lowbell'd me so,
That I thought of nothing,
But stood shrinking like a dead Lark.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: But hark you, Gentlemen, there's an ill-tasting dose
To be swallowed first; there's a Covenant to be taken.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well, what is that Covenant?
By my soul I will take it for my new Master,
If I cou'd, that I wou'd.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Thank thee, Teg—A Covenant, sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Well, where is that Covenant?—

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: We'l not swear, Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: You must have no Land then.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Then farewel Acres, and may the dirt choak them.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: 'Tis but being reduc'd to Teg's equipage;
'Twas a lucky thing to have a fellow that can
Teach one this cheap diet of Snuff.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Come, Gentlemen, we must lose no more time;
I'll carry you to my poor house, where you shall lodge:
For know, I am married to a most illustrious person,
That had a kindness for me.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Prithee, how did'st thou light upon this good fortune?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Why, you see there are Stars in England,
Though none in Ireland: Come, Gentlemen,
Time calls us; you shall have my story hereafter.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Plague on this Covenant.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Curse it not, 'twill prosper then.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Come, Teg, however I have a Suit of
Cloaths for thee; thou shalt lay by thy Blanket
For some time: It may be thee and I may be
Reduc'd together to thy Country fashion.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Upon my Soul, Joy, for I will carry thee
Then into my Countrey too.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Why, there's the worst on't,
The best will help it self.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Day, and Mrs. Day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Welcome, sweet Duck; I profess
Thou hast brought home good Company indeed;
Money and moneys worth: if we can
But now make sure of this Heir, Mrs Arbella,
For our Son Abel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: If we can? you are ever at your (Ifs;)
You'r afraid of your own shadow; I can tell you
One (if) more; that is (if) I did not bear you up,
Your heart wou'd be down in your Breeches
At every turn: well,—if I were gone,
There's another If for you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: I profess thou sayest true,
I shou'd not know what to do indeed;
I am beholding to thy good counsel for many
Good thing; I had ne'r got Ruth
Nor her Estate into my Fingers else.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Nay, in that business too you were at
Your (Ifs:) Now you see she goes currantly
For our own Daughter, and this Arbella shall be
Our Daughter too, or she shall have no Estate.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: If we cou'd but do that, Wife?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Yet again at your Ifs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: I have done, I have done; your counsel,
Good Duck; you know I depend upon that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: You may well enough, you find
The sweet on't; and to say truth, 'tis known too well,
That you relied upon it: In truth they are ready
To call me the Committe-man: they well
Perceive the weight that lies upon me, Husband.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Nay, good Duck, no chiding now,
But to your counsel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: In the first place (observe how I lay a design
In Politicks) d'ye mark, counterfeit me
A Letter from the King, where he shall offer you great
Matters to serve him, and his Interest under-hand.
Very good, and in it let him remember his kind
Love and Service to me: This will make them look
About 'em, and think you some body: then promise them
If they'll be true Friends to you, to live and dye
With them, and refuse all great offers, then whilst 'tis warm
Get the composition of Arbella's Estate into your own power,
Upon your design of marrying her to Abel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Mark the luck on't too, their names sound alike;
Abel and Arbella, they are the same to a trisle,
It seemeth a providence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Thou observest right, Duck,
Thou canst see as far into a Milstone as another.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Pish, do not interrupt me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: I do not, good Duck, I do not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: You do not, and yet you do;
You put me off from the concatenation of my discourse:
Then, as I was saying, you may intimate
To your honourable Fellows, that one good turn
Deserves another. That language is understood amongst you.
I take it, ha.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we use those Items often.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Well, interrupt me not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: I do not, good Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: You do not, and yet you do;
By this means get her composition put wholly into your hands,
And then no Abel, no Land,—but—in the mean time
I wou'd have Abel do his part too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: I, I, there's a want I found it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Yes, when I told you so before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Why, that's true, Duck, he is too backward;
If I were in his place, and as young as I have been.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: O you'd do wonders; but now I think on't,
There may be some use made of Ruth;
'Tis a notable witty Harlotry.
—You were so, when I told you
I had thought on't first,—let me see, it shall be so:
We'll set her to instruct Abel in the first place;
And then to incline Arbella, they are Hand and Glove;
And Women can do much with one another.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: Thou hast hit upon my own thoughts.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Pray call her in;
You thought of that too, did you not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: I will, Duck; Ruth, why, Ruth.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Your pleasure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis my Wife's desire that—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Well, if it be your Wife's, she can best tell
It her self, I suppose: d'ye hear, Ruth, you may
Do a business that may not be the worse for you:
You know I use but few words.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: What does she call a few?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Look you now, as I said, to be short,
And to the matter, my Husband and I do design this
Mrs. Arbella for our Son Abel, and the young
Fellow is not forward enough you conceive, prethee give
Him a little instructions how to demean himself,
And in what manner to speak, which we call address,
To her; for Women best know what will please Women;
Then work on Arbella on the other side, work, I say,
My good Girl, no more but so: you know my custom
Is to use but few words. Much may be said in a little,
You shan't repent it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: And I say something too, Ruth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: What need you, do you not see it all
Said already to your hand, what sayest thou, Girl?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: I shall do my best.—I wou'd not lose
The sport for more than I speak of.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Go call Abel, good Girl. By bringing this
To pass Husband, we shall secure our selves
If the King shou'd come; you'l be hanged else.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Oh good Wife, let's secure our selves
By all means, there's a wise saying, 'Tis good to have a
Shelter against every storm. I remember that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: You may well, when you heard me say it so often.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: O Son Abel, d'ye hear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Pray hold your peace,
And give every body leave to tell their own tale.—
D'hear, Son Abel, I have formerly told you
That Arbella wou'd be a good Wife for you;
A word's enough to the wise: some endeavours must
Be used, and you must not be desicient. I have spoken
To your Sister Ruth to instruct you what to say,
And how to carry your self; observe her Directions as
You'll answer the contrary; be consident, and put home.
Ha Boy, hadst thou but thy Mother's pate. Well,
'Tis but a folly to talk of that that cannot be;
Be sure you follow your Sister's directions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Be sure, Boy.—
Well said Duck, I say.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Now, Brother Abel.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Now, Sister Ruth?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Hitherto he observes me punctually, Aside.
Have you a Months mind to this
Gentlewoman, Mistress Arbella?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I have not known her a Week yet.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: O cry you mercy, good Brother Abel.
Well, to begin then, You must alter your posture,
And by your grave and high demeanour make your self
Appear a hole above Obadiah; lest your Mistress
Should take you for such another scribble scrabble as he is,
And always hold up your head as if it were
Bolster'd up with high matters, your hands join'd
Flat together, projecting a little beyond the rest of your
Body as ready to separate when you begin to open.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Must I go apace or softly.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: O gravely by all means, as if you were loaded
With weighty considerations so.—Very well.
Now to apply our prescription: Suppose now that I
Were your Mistress Arbella, and meet you by
Accident; keep your posture so, and when you come
Just to me, start like a Horse that has spy'd
Something on one side of him, and give a little gird
Out of the way on a sudden; declaring that you
Did not see her before, by reason of your deep
Contemplations: then you must speak, let's hear.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: God save you, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: O sie Man, you shou'd begin thus; Pardon,
Mistress, my profound Contemplations, in which I was so
Buried that I did not see you: And then as she answers proceed.
I know what she'll say, I am so us'd to her.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: This will do well if I forget it not.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Well, try once.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: Pardon, Mistress, my profound Contemplations,
In which I was so hid, that you cou'd not see me.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Better sport than I expected. Aside.
Very well done, you'r perfect: then she will answer,
Sir, I suppose you are so busied with State-affairs,
That it may well hinder you from taking notice
Of any thing below them.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: No forsooth, I have some profound
Contemplations, but no State-Affairs.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: O sie, Man, you must confess, that the weighty
Affairs of State lie heavy upon you; but 'tis a burthen
You must bear, and then shrug your shoulders.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Must I say so, I am afraid my Mother will be angry,
For she takes all the State-matters upon her self.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Pish, did she not charge you to be rul'd by me;
Why, Man, Arbella will never have you;
If she be not made believe you can do great matters
With Parliament Men, and Committee Men;
How shou'd she hope for any good
By you else in her composition.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I apprehend you now, I shall observe.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: 'Tis well at this time, I'll say no more;
Put your self in your posture so:
Now go look your Mistress;
I'll warrant you the Town's our own.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: I go.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Now I have fix'd him, not to go off
Till he discharges on his Mistress. I cou'd burst with laughing.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What do'st thou laugh at, Ruth?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Didst thou meet my Brother Abel?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: If thou hadst met him right,
He had played at hard head with thee.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What do'st thou mean;

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Why, I have been teaching him to wooe,
By command of my Superiours, and have instructed
Him to hold up his head so high, that of necessity he must
Run against every thing that comes in his way.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Who is he to wooe?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Even thy own sweet self.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Out upon him.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Nay, thou wilt be rarely courted;
I'll not spoil the sport by telling thee any
Thing beforehand; they have sent to Lilly,
And his learning being built upon knowing what most
People wou'd have him say:
He has told them for a certain, That Abel shall
Have a rich Heir, and that must be you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Must be.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Yes, Committee-Men can compel more than Stars.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I fear this too late;
You are their Daughter, Ruth?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: I deny that.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Wonder not that I begin thus freely with you,
'Tis to invite your confidence in me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: You amaze me.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Pray do not wonder, nor suspect,—
When my Father, Sir Basil Throughgood, died, I was
Very young, not above two years old: 'tis too long
To tell you how this Rascal, being a Trustee,
Catch'd me and my Estate, being the sole Heir unto my
Father, into his gripes; and now for some years
Has confirm'd his unjust power by the unlawful
Power of the times: I fear they have designs as bad as
This on you: You see I have no reserve, and endeavour
To be thought worthy of your friendship

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I embrace it with as much clearness,
Let us love and assist one another.—
Wou'd they marry me to this their first-born Puppy?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: No doubt, or keep your composition from you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: 'Twas my ill fortune to fall into such hands,
Foolishly enticed by fair words and
Large promises of assistance.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: Mrs. Ruth, my Master is demanding your company,
Together, and not singly, with Mrs. Arbella;
You will find them in the Parlor:
The Committee being ready to sit,
Calls upon my care and circumspection to set in order
The weighty matters of State,
For their wise and honourable inspection.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: We come; come, dear Arbella, never be perplex'd,
Chearful Spirits are the best Bladders to swim with:
If thou art sad, the weight will sink thee:
Be secret, and still know me for no other than what
I seem to be, their Daughter. Another time
Thou shalt know all particulars of my strange story.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Come, Wench, they cannot bring us to compound
For our humours; they shall be free still.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: I' Faith my sweet Master has sent me to a
Rascal, now that he has; I will go tell him so too:
He ask'd me why he could not send one
That cou'd speak English. Upon my soul, I was going
To give him an Irish knock; the Devil's in them all,
They will not talk with me; I will go near to
Knock this man's pate, and that man, Lilly's One cries Books within. Enter.
Pate too,—that I will: I will make them
Prate to me, that I will. How now,
What Noises are that?—

sp.speaker: Book-sel.
sp.l: New Books, new Books, a desperate Plot
And Ingagement of the bloody Cavaliers: One cries Books without.
Mr. Saltmarsh's Alarum to the Nation, after having
Been three days dead, Mercurius Britannicus, &c.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: How's that? now they cannot live in Ireland
After they are dead three days!

sp.speaker: Book-sel.
sp.l: Mercurius Britannicus, or the Weekly Post,
Or, The Solemn League and Covenant.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: What is that you say?
Is it the Covenant, have you that?

sp.speaker: Book-sel.
sp.p: Yes, what then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Which is that Covenant?

sp.speaker: Book-sel.
sp.p: Why, this is the Covenant.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Well, I must take that Covenant.

sp.speaker: Book-sel.
sp.p: You take my Commodities?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I must take that Covenant, upon my soul now, that I must.

sp.speaker: Book-sel.
sp.p: Stand off, Sir, or I'll set you further.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well, upon my soul, now I will take
That Covenant for my Master.

sp.speaker: Book-sel.
sp.p: Your Master must pay me for't then?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: I'faith now, they will make him pay for't
After I have taken it for him.

sp.speaker: Book-sel.
sp.p: What a Devil does the fellow mean?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: You will make me stay too long, that you will;
Look you now, I will knock you down upon the ground,
If you will not let me take it?

sp.speaker: Book-sel.
sp.p: Stand off, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I'faith I will take it now.

div.stage: He throws the fellow down, and takes away the Paper, and runs out.

sp.speaker: Book-sel.
sp.l: What a Devil ails this fellow?
He did not come to rob me certainly,
For he has not taken above two
Penniworth of lamentable Ware away;
But I feel the Rascal's fingers; I may light
Upon my wild Irish again, and if I do,
I will fix him with some Catchpoles that shall
Be worse than his own Country Bogs.

div.stage: Enter C. Careless, C. Blunt, and Lieutenant Story.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And what say you, noble Colonels, how and how
D'ye like my Lady? I gave her the Title of Illustrious
From those Illustrious Commodities which she deals in,
Hot Water, and Tobacco.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Prithee how com'st thou to think of Marrying?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Why, that which hinders men from those
Venereal Conditions, prompted me to Matrimony,
Hunger and Cold, Colonel.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Which you destroyed with a fat Woman,
Strong Water, and stinking Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: No, faith, the Woman conduc'd but little,
But the rest cou'd not be purchas'd without.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: She's beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: For all your mocking she had been ruin'd
If it had not been for me.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Prethee make but that good?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: With ease, Sir, why look you,—you must
Know she was always a most violent Cavalier,
And of a most ready and large Faith; abundance of
Rascals had found her soft place, and perpetually
Wou'd bring her News, news of all prizes,
They would tell her news from half a Crown, to a
Gill of hot Water, or a Pipe of the worst Mundungo:
I have observ'd their usual rates; they wou'd borrow
Half a Crown upon a story of five thousand Men up
In the North; a shilling upon a Towns revolting,
Six pence upon a small Castle, and consume hot Water
And Tobacco, whilst they were telling news of Arms,
Convey'd into several parts, and Ammunition hid
In Cellars; that at the last, if I had not married,
And blown off these flies, she had been absolutely consum'd.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Well, Lieutenant, we are beholding to you
For these hints; we may be reduc'd to as bad: See
Where Teg comes. Goodness, how he smiles. Enter Teg smiling.
Why so merry, Teg?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I have done one thing for thee now, that I have indeed.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: What hast thou done, Man?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: I have taken the Covenant for thee,
That I have upon my Soul.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Where hadst it thou?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Hadst it thou; I threw a Fellow down, that I did,
And took it away for thy sweet sake; here it is now.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Was there ever such a fancy? why didst thou think
This was the way to take the Covenant?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Ay, upon my Soul that it is; look you there now,
Have not I taken it; is not this the Covenant?
Tell me that then I prethee.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: I am pleased yet,
With the poor Fellows mistaken kindness;
I dare warrant him honest to the best of his understanding.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: This Fellow I prophesie will bring me into
Many troubles by his mistakes: I must send him on
No Errand but, How d'ye; and to such as I wou'd have
No answer from again:—Yet his simple honesty
Prevails with me, I cannot part with him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, some calls; how now, who's this?

div.stage: Enter Obadiah, with four Persons more with Papers.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: I am a Rogue if I have not seen a Picture
In hangings walk as fast.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: 'Slife Man, this is that good Man of the Committee
Family that I told thee of, the very Clerk;
How the Rogue's loaded with Papers; Those are
The winding sheets to many a poor Gentleman's Estate:
'Twere a good deed to burn them all.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Why, thou art not mad, art? well met Sir;
Pray do not you belong to the Committee of Sequestrations?

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: I do belong to that honourable Committee,
Who are now ready to sit for the bringing on the work.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: O Plague, what work, Ras—

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Prethee be quiet, Man; are they to sit presently?

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: As soon as I can get ready, my presence being material.

sp.speaker: C Car.
sp.l: What, wert thou mad; wou'dst thou have beaten
The Clerk when thou wert going to compound
With the Rascals his Masters.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: The sight of any of the Villains stirs me.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Come, Colonels, there's no tristing;
Let's make haste, and prepare your business, let's not lose
This sitting, come along, along.

div.stage: Enter Arbella at one Door. Abel at another, as if he saw her not, and starts when he comes to her, as Ruth had taught him.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What's the meaning of this, I'll try to steal by him.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: Pardon, Mistress, my profound Contemplations,
In which I was so hid that you cou'd not see me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: This is a set Form,—they allow it
In every thing but their Prayers.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Now you shou'd speak, Forsooth.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Ruth, I have found you;
But I'll spoil the Dialogue. Aside.
—What shou'd I say, Sir?

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: What you please, Forsooth.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why, truly, Sir, 'tis as you say; I did not see you.

div.stage: Enter Ruth as over hearing them, and Peeps.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: This is lucky.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: No, Forsooth, 'twas I that was not to see you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why, Sir, wou'd your Mother be angry if you shou'd?

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: No, no, quite contrary,—I'll tell you that presently;
But first I must say, that the weighty affairs lie
Heavy upon my Neck and Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Wou'd he were ty'd Neck and Heels? Aside.
This is a notable Wench; look where the Rascal peeps too;
If I shou'd becken to her she'd take no notice;
She's resolv'd not to relieve me.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Something I can do, and that with some body;
That is, with those that are some bodies.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Whist, whist, Beckons to Ruth, and she shakes her head.
Prethee have some pity?
O unmerciful Girl.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: I know Parliament-men, and Sequestrators;
I know Committee-men, and Committee-men know me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: You have great acquaintance, Sir?

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Yes, they ask my opinion sometimes.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What weather 'twill be; have you any skill, Sir?

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: When the weather is not good, we hold a Fast.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: And then it alters.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Assuredly.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: In good time—no mercy, Wench.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: Our profound Contemplations
Are caused by the constervation of our Spirits
For the Nations good, we are in labour.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: And I want a deliverance. Hark ye, Ruth,
Take off your Dog, or I'll turn Bear indeed.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: I dare not, my Mother will be angry.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: O hang you.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: You shall perceive that I have some power,
If you please to—

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: O I am pleased! Sir, that you shou'd have power;
I must look out my Hoods and Scarfs, Sir, 'tis a most time to go.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: If it were not for the weighty matters of State
Which lie upon my shoulders, my self wou'd look them.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: O by no means, Sir, 'tis below your greatness:
Some luck yet; she never came seasonably before.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Why how now, Abel got so close to Mrs. Arbella,
So close indeed; nay then I smell something:
Well, Mr. Abel, you have been so us'd to secresie
In Council and weighty matters, that you have it
At your Fingers ends: Nay, look ye Mistress, look ye,
Look ye; mark Abel's Eyes: ah, there be looks.
Ruth thou art a good Girl, I find Abel has got ground.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: I forbore to come in, till I saw your honour
First enter; but I have o'r heard all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: And how has Abel behav'd himself, Wench, ha?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: O beyond expectation: if it were lawful, I'd undertake
He'd make nothing to get as many Womens good
Wills as he speaks to; he'll not need much teaching,
You may turn him loose.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: O this plaguy Wench!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Sayest thou so Girl, it shall be something
In thy way; a new Gown, or so, it may be a better penny:
Well said, Abel, I say, I did think thou wou'dst come
Out with a piece of thy Mothers at last:—
But I had forgot, the Committee are near upon sitting.
Ha, Mrs. you are crafty; you have made your
Composition before-hand. Ah, this Abel's as bad
As a whole Committee: Take that Item from me;
Come, make haste, call the Coach, Abel; well said, Abel, I say.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: We'll fetch our things and follow you. Exit Mrs. Day and Abel.
Now Wench, canst thou ever hope to be forgiven:

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: The matter; coud'st thou be so unmerciful,
To see me practic'd on, and pelted at, by a Blunderbuss
Charg'd with nothing but proofs, weighty affairs,
Spirit, profound Contemplation, and such like.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Why, I was afraid to interrupt you; I thought
It convenient to give you what time I cou'd,
To make his young honour your Friend.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I am beholding to you, I may cry quittance.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: But did you mark Abel's Eyes?
Ah, there were looks!

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Nay, prethee give off, my hour's approaching,
And I cann't be heartily merry till it be past:
Come, let's fetch our things,
Her Ladyships Honour will stay for us.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: I'll warrant ye my Brethren, Abel is not in order yet,
He's brushing a Hat almost a quarter of an hour,
And as long a driving the lint from his black Cloaths,
With his wet Thumb.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Come, prethee hold thy peace,
I shall laugh in's Face else when I see him come along:
Now for an old Shooe.

div.stage: A Table set out. Enter the Committee as to sit, and Obadiah ordering Books and Paper.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: Shall I read your Honours last Order, and give you
The account of what you last debated?

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: I first crave your favours to communicate an
Important matter to this honourable Board, in which I shall
Discover unto you my own sincerity
And zeal to the good Cause.
Proceed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: The business is contained in this Letter, 'tis from
No less a Man than the King; and 'tis to me, as simple as I sit
Here: Is it your pleasures that our Clerk should read it?
Yes, pray give it him.

lg.l: We have received good intelligence of your great worth,
And ability, especially in State-matters; and therefore thought
Fit to offer you any preferment, or honour, that you shall desire,
If you will become my intire Friend: Pray remember my
Love and Service to your discreet Wife, and acquaint her
With this; whose wisdom I hear is great: so recommending
This to her and your wise consideration, I remain

sp.l: C. K.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: I, that's for the King.
I suspect who brought you this Letter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: O fie upon't, my Wife forgot that particular.—
Why, a Fellow left it for me, and shrunk away when he had
Done, I warrant you he was afraid I shou'd have laid hold
On him: You see Brethren what I reject; but I doubt not
But to receive my reward: and I have now a business
To offer, which in some measure may afford you an occasion.
This Letter was counterfeited certainly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: But first be pleased to read your last order.
What does he mean that concerns me?

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: The order is, that the Composition arising out of
Mr. Lashley's Estate, be and hereby is invested and allow'd to
The honourable Mr. Nathaniel Catch,
For and in respect of his sufferings and good service.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: It is meet, very meet, we are bound
In duty to strengthen our selves against the day of trouble,
When the common Enemy shall endeavour to raise
Commotions in the Land,
And disturb our new built Zion.
Then I'll say nothing, but close with him, we must
Wink at one another; I receive your sense
Of my services with a zealous kindness. Now, Mr. Day,
I pray you propose your business.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: I desire this honourable Board to understand,
That my Wife being at Redding, and to come up in
The Stage Coach: It happened that one Mrs. Arbella,
A rich Heir of one of the Cavalier Party, came up also in,
The same Coach; her Father being newly dead, and her
Estate before being under Sequestration: My Wife, who
Has a notable pate of her own; you all know her;
Presently cast about to get her for my Son Abel;
And accordingly invited her to my House; where, though
Time was but short, yet my Son Abel made use of it:
They are without, as I suppose; but
Before we call them in, I pray let us handle
Such other matters as are before us.
Let us hear then what Estates besides
Lies before us, that we may see how large a
Field we have to walk in.
Read.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: One of your last Debates was upon the Plea
Of an Infant, whose Estate is under Sequestration.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: And sit to be kept so till he comes of Age,
And may answer for himself; that he may not
Be in possession of the Land till he can promise
He will not turn to the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: Here is another of almost the like nature;
An Estate before your Honours under Sequestration:
The Plea is, That the Party died without any—
For taking up Arms; but in his Opinion for the King:
He has left his Widow with Child, which will
Be the Heir; and his Trustees complain of wrong,
And claim the Estate.
Well, the Father in his Opinion was a Cavalier.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: So it is given in.

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.l: Nay, 'twas so I warrant you, and there's a young
Cavalier in his Widows Belly; I warrant you that too;
For the perverse Generation encreaseth; I move
Therefore that their two Estates may remain in the hands
Of our Brethren here, and Fellow Labourers,
Mr. Joseph Blemish, and Mr. Jonathan Headstrong,
And Mr. Ezekiel Scrape, and they to be accountable
At our pleasures; whereby they may have a godly
Opportunity of doing good for themselves.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Order it, order it.
Since it is your pleasures, we are content
To take the burthen upon us, and be
Stewards to the Nation.
Now verily it seemeth to me
That the work goeth forward, when Brethren
Hold together in Unity.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Well, if we have now finish'd, give me leave
To tell you, my Wife is without, together with
The Gentlewoman that is to compound: She will
Needs have a Finger in the Pie.
I profess we are to blame to let Mrs. Day wait so long.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: We may not neglect the publick for private
Respects. I hope Brethren, that you please to cast the
Favour of your Countenances upon Abel.
You wrong us to doubt it, Brother Day.
Call in the Compounders.

div.stage: Enters Mrs. Day, Abel, Arbella, Ruth, and after them the Colonels, and Teg; they give the Door-Keeper something, who seems to scrape.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Come, Duck, I have told the honourable Committee
That you are one that will needs endeavour
To do good for this Gentlewoman.
We are glad, Mrs. Day, that any occasion brings you hither.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: I thank your honours. I am desirous of doing
Good, which I know is always acceptable in your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: Come on Son Abel, what have you to say?

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: I come unto your Honours, full of profound
Contemplations for this Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: 'Slife, he's at's lessen, Wench.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Peace, which Whelp opens next?
O the Wolf is going to bark.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: May it please your Honours, I shall presume
To inform you, that my Son Abel has setled his affections
On this Gentlewoman, and desires your Honours favour
To be shewn unto him in her Composition.

sp.speaker: 2. C.
sp.l: Say you so, Mrs. Day? why the Committee have taken
It into their serious, and pious consideration; together
With Mr. Day's good service, upon some knowledge
That is not fit to communicate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: That was the Letter I invented.

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.l: And the composition of this Gentlewoman is consign'd
To Mr. Day, that is, I suppose, to Mr. Abel, and so consequently
To the Gentlewoman. You may be thankful, Mistress,
For such good fortune, your Estate's discharg'd,
Mr. Day shall have the discharge.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: O dam the Vultures!

sp.speaker: C. Care.
sp.p: Peace Man.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I am willing to be thankful when I understand the
Benefit. I have no reason to compound for what's my own;
But if I must, if a Woman can be a Delinquent,
I desire to know my publick censure,
Not be left in private hands.

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.l: Be contented, Gentlewoman, the Committee does this
In favour of you; we understand how easily you
Can satisfie Mr. Abel; you may, if you please, by Mrs. Day.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: And then good night to all.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: How, Gentlemen! are you private marriage Jobbers,
D'ye make markets for one another?

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.p: How's this Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: A brave noble Creature.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Thou art smitten, Blunt; that other Female too,
Methinks shoots fire this way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: I desire your Honours to pardon
Her incessant words; perhaps she doth not imagine
The good that is intended her?

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.l: Gentlewoman, the Committee for Mrs. Day's sake
Passes by your expressions; you may spare your pains,
You have the Committees resolution, you may
Be your own Enemy if you will.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: My own Enemy.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Prethee peace, 'tis to no purpose to wrangle here;
We must use other ways.

sp.speaker: • . C.
sp.p: Come on, Gentlemen, what's your case?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Arbella, there's the down-right Cavalier
That came up in the Coach with us.
—On my Life there's a sprightly Gentleman with him.

sp.speaker: C. Care.
sp.l: Our business is to compound for our Estates. While they speak, the Colonels pull the Papers out and deliver 'em.
Of which here are the particulars,
Which will agree with your own Survey.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: The particulars are right.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Well, Gentlemen, the rule is two years purchase,
The first payment down, the other at six months end,
And the Estate to secure it.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Can you afford it no cheaper?

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.p: 'Tis our rule.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Very well, 'tis but selling the rest to pay this,
And our more lawful debts.
But, Gentlemen, before you are admitted,
You are to take the Covenant;
You have not taken it yet, have you.

sp.speaker: C. Car
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Upon my Soul but he has now; I took it for him,
And he has taken it from me, that he has.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: What sport are we now like to have?

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.p: What Fellow's that?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: A poor simple Fellow that serves me. Peace, Teg.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Let them not prate so then.

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.l: Well, Gentlemen, it remains
Whether you'll take the Covenant?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: This is strange, and differs from your own Principle,
To impose on other Mens Consciences.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Pish, we are not here to dispute, we act
According to our instructions, and we cannot admit any
To compound without taking it; therefore your answer.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Why was it for no matter then that I have taken
The Covenant. You there, Mr. Committee,
Do you hear that now?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: No, we will not take it, much good may it do them
That have swallows large enough;
'Twill work one day in their Stomachs.

sp.speaker: Cl. Bl.
sp.l: The day may come, when those that suffer for their
Consciences and honour may be rewarded.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: I, I, you make an Idol of that honour.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Our Worships then are different, you make that
Your Idol which brings your Interest;
We can obey that which bids us lose it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Brave Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: I stare at 'em till my Eyes ake.

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.l: Gentlemen, you are men of dangerous Spirits,
Know, we must keep our rules, and instructions, lest we
Lose what providence hath put into our hands.

sp.speaker: C Care.
sp.p: Providence, such as Thieves rob by?

sp.speaker: 2. C.
sp.p: What's that, Sir, Sir, you are too bold?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Why in good sooth you may give losers
Leave to speak; I hope your Honours out of your bowels of
Compassion, will permit us to take over our departing Acres.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: It is well you are so merry.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: O, ever whil'st you live, clear souls make light hearts;
Faith, wou'd I might ask one question?

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.p: Swear not then.

sp.speaker: C Car.
sp.l: Thou shalt not covet thy Neighbours Goods;
There's a Rowland for your Oliver; my question is only,
Which of all you is to have our Estates: or will you
Make Traitors of them, draw 'em, and quarter them.

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.p: You grow abusive.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: No, no, 'tis only to entreat the honourable persons
That will be pleased to be our House-keepers, to keep them
In good Reparations; we may take possession again
Without the help of the Covenant.

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.p: You will think better on't, and take this Covenant.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: We will be as rotten first as their hearts
That invented it.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: 'Slife, Arbella, we'l have these two men;
There are not two such again, to be had for love nor money.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Well, Gentlemen, your follies light upon your
Own heads; we have no more to say.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Why then hoist Sails for a new World:
D'hear, Blunt, what Gentlewoman is that?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: 'Tis their witty Daughter I told thee of.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: I'll go to speak to 'em, I'd fain convert
That pretty Covenanter.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Nay, prithee let's go.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Lady, I hope you'l have that good fortune,
Not to be troubled with the Covenant.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: If they do, I'll not take it.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Brave Lady, I must love her against my will.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: For you, pretty one, I hope your Portion will
Be enlarged by our Misfortunes; remember your benefactors.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: If I had all your Estates,
I cou'd afford you as good a thing.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Without taking the Covenant?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Yes, but I would invent another Oath.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Upon your Lips.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Nay, I am not bound to discover.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Prithee come, is this a time to spend in fooling?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Now have I forgot every thing.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Come, let's go.
Gentlemen, void the Room.

sp.speaker: C Car.
sp.l: Sure 'tis impossible that Kite
Shou'd get that pretty Merlin.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Come, prithee let's go; these Muck-worms will have
Earth enough to stop their mouths with one day.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Pray use our Estates husband-like, and so our
Most honourable Bailiffs, farewel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: You are rude: Door-keeper, put 'em forth there.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Come forth, ye there; this is not a place for such as you.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Ye are a Rascal, that you are now.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: And please your Honours, this profane Irish-man swore
An Oath at the door, even now, when I
Wou'd have put him out.

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.p: Let him pay for't.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Here, you must pay, or lye by the heels.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: What must I pay, by the heels? I will not pay by
•• h ••• s, that I will not, upon my soul

sp.p: Here, here's a Shilling for thee, be quiet.—

sp.l: Well, I have not curs'd you now, that I have not:

〈…〉
〈…〉 I had cursed then?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: That had been Six-pence.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Upon my soul now, I have but one Six-pence, that I

•
• ave not: Here, though, I will give it thee for a Curse; there
Mr. Committee, now there is Six-pence for the Curse before-hand,
Mr. Committee, and a Plague take you all.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Hark ye, Arbella, 'twere a sin not to love these men.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I am not guilty, Ruth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Has this honourable Board any other Command.

sp.speaker: 2 C.
sp.l: Nothing farther, good Mrs. Day: Gentlewoman,
You have nothing to care for, but be grateful
And kind to Mr. Abel.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I desire to know what I must directly trust to,
Or I will complain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: The Gentlewoman needeth not doubt, she shall
Suddenly perceive the good that is intended her,
If she does not interpose in her own light.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: I pray withdraw; the Committee has pass'd their
Order, and they must now be private—

sp.speaker: 2 Com.
sp.l: Nay, pray, Mistress, withdraw—So, Brethren, we have
Finish'd this day's work; and let us always keep
The Bonds of Unity unbroken, walking hand in
Hand, and scattering the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: You may perceive they have Spirits never to be
Reconcil'd; they walk according to Nature, and are
Full of inward darkness.

sp.speaker: 2 Com.
sp.l: It is well truly for the good people, that they
Are so obstinate, whereby their Estates may
Of right fall into the hands of the chosen, which
Truly is a mercy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: I think there remaineth nothing farther,
But to adjourn till Munday: Take up the
Papers there, and bring home to me their
Honours Order for Mrs. Arbella's Estate: So,
Brethren, we separate our selves to our
Particular endeavours, till we join in
Publick on Munday, two of the Clock;
And so Peace remain with you.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Col. Careless, Col. Blunt, and Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: BY my faith, a sad Story: I did apprehend this Covenant
Wou'd be the Trap.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Never did any Rebels fish with such Cormorants; no
Stoppage about their throats; the Rascals are all swallow.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Now am I ready for any Plot; I'll go find some of these
Agitants, and fill up a blank Commission with my Name.
And if I can but find two or three gather'd together,
They are sure of me; I will please my self, however,
With endeavouring to cut their throats.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Or do something to make them hang us, that we may
But part on any terms: Nothing anger'd me but that
My old Kitchen-stuff-acquaintance look'd another
Way, and seem'd not to know me.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: How, Kitchen-stuff acquaintance!

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Yes, Mrs Day, that commanded the Party in the
Hackney-Coach, was my Father's Kitchen-maid, and in
Time of yore called Gillian. How now, Teg? Enter Teg.
What says the Learned?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well then, upon my Soul, the Man in the great
Cloak, with the long Sleeves, is mad, that he is.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Mad, Teg!

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Yes i'faith is he; he bid me be gone, and said I was sent
To mock him.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Why, what didst thou say to him?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Well now, I did ask him if he wou'd take any Counsel.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: 'Slife, he might well enough think thou mock'st him.
Why, thou shou'dst have ask'd him when we might have
Come for Counsel.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well, that is all one, is it not? If he wou'd take any
Counsel, or you wou'd take any Counsel, is not that all one then?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Was there ever such a mistake?

sp.speaker: C Bl.
sp.l: Prethee ne'r be troubled at this; we are past Counsel:
If we had but a Friend amongst them, that cou'd but slide
Us by this Covenant.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Hark ye, Colonel; what if you did visit this translated
Kitchen-maid?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Well, how is that? a Kitchen-maid? where is she now?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: The Lieutenant advises well.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Nay, stay, stay; in the first place I'll send Teg to her
To tell her I have a little business with her, and desire
To know when I may have leave to wait on her.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: We shall have Teg mistake again.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: How is that so? I will not mistake that Kitchen-maid?
Whither must I go now, to mistake that Kitchen-maid?

sp.speaker: C Car.
sp.l: But d'hear, Teg? you must take no notice of that, upon
Thy Life; but on the contrary, at every word you must say,
Your Ladyship, and your Honour; as for Example, when you have
Made a Leg, you must begin thus; My Master presents
His service to your Ladyship, and having some business with
Your Honour, desires to know when he may have leave
To wait upon your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well, that I will do: But was she
Your Father's Kitchen-maid?

sp.speaker: C Car.
sp.p: Why, what then?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Upon my Soul I shall laugh upon her Face, for all
I wou'd not have a mind to do it.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Not for a hundred pounds, Teg; you must be sure to
Set your Countenance, and look very soberly before you begin.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: If I shou'd think then of any Kettles, or Spits, or
Any thing that will put a mind into my head of a
Kitchen, I shou'd laugh then, shou'd I not?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Not for a thousand pounds, Teg; thou mayst undo us all.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well, I will hope I will not laugh then? I will
Keep my mouth if I can, that I will, from running
To one side, and 'tother side: well now, where does
This Mrs. Tay live?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Come, Teg, I'le walk along with thee, and shew thee
The house, that thou mayest not mistake that however;

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Prethee do, Lieutenant, have a care, Teg,
Thou shalt find us in the Temple. Now, Blunt, have I
Another design.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: What further design canst thou have?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Why by this means I may chance see these women
Again, and get into their acquaintance.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: With both, man?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: 'Slife thou art jealous, do'st love either of 'em?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Nay, I can't tell, all is not as 'twas.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Like a man that is not well, and yet knows
Not what ailes him.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Thou art something near the matter: but I'le
Cure my self with considering, that no woman can
Ever care for me.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: And why prethee?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Because I can say nothing to them.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: The less thou canst say, they'l like thee the better▪
She'l think 'tis Love that has ham-string'd thy tongue:
Besides man, a woman can't abide that any thing
In the house shou'd talk, but she and her Parrot;
What 'tis the Cavalier girle thou lik'st?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Canst thou love any of the other Breed.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Not honestly,—yet I confess that ill-begotten
Pretty Rascal never look'd towards me, but
She scatter'd sparks as fast as kindling Charcoale;
Thine's grown already to an honest flame: Come,
Blunt, when Teg comes we will resolve on something.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Come now, a word of our own matters; how do'st
Thou hope to get thy Estate again.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: You shall drink first; I was just going to ask you,
How you would get yours again; you are as fast as if
You were under Covert-barne.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: But I have more hopes than thou hast.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Not a scruple more; if there were but scales
That could weigh hopes; for these Rascals must be hang'd
Before either of us shall get our own; you may eat and drink
Out of yours as I do, and be a sojourner with Abel.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I am hamper'd, but I'le intangle my self
With Mr. Abel's conjugal cords: nay—I am more
Hamper'd than thou thinkest; for if thou art in as bad
Case as I (you understand me) hold up thy finger.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Behold, nay, I'le ne're forsake thee, if I were not
Smitten, I wou'd perswade my self to be in love,
If 'twere but to bear thee company.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Dear girl, hark ye, Ruth, the composition day
Made an end of all; all's ago.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Nay, that fatal day put me into the condition
Of a Compounder too; there was my heart brought
Under sequestration.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: That day, wench?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Yes, that very day with two or three forceable
Looks 'twas driven an inch at least out of its old place;
Sense or reason can't find the way to't now.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: That day, that very day, if you and I should like
The same man?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Fie upon't, as I live thou mak'st me start;
Now dare not I ask which thou lik'st.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Wou'd they were now to come in that we might
Watch one anothers eyes, and discover by signs;
I am not able to ask thee neither.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Nor I to tell thee; shall we go ask Lilly which 'tis?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Out upon him; nay, there's no need of Stars;
We know our selves if we durst speak.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Pish, I'le speak if it be the same, we'l draw cuts.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: No, hark ye, Ruth, do you act them both,
For you saw their several humors, and then watch my
Eyes, where I appear most concern'd;
I can't dissemble for my heart.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: I dare swear that will hinder thee to dissemble
Indeed,—Come have at you then, I'le speak as if I were
Before the honourable rascals: And first, for my brave
Blunt Colonel, who hating to take the Oath, cry'd out
With a brave scorn (such as made thee in love I hope)
Hang your selves, rascals, the time will come when those
That dare be honest will be rewarded; don't
I act him bravely, don't I act him bravely?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: O admirably well, dear wench, do it once more.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I must do the 'tother now.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: No, no, this once more, dear girle, and I'le
Act the 'tother for thee.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: No forsooth, I'le spare your pains, we are right,
No need of Cuts, send thee good luck with him I acted,
And wish me well with my merry Colonel
That shall act his own part.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: And a thousand good lucks attend thee;
We have sav'd our blushes admirably well, and reliev'd
Our hearts from hard duty—but mum, see where the Mother
Comes, and with her, her Son, a true exemplification or
Duplicate of the original Day. Now for a charge.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Stand fair, the Enemy draws up.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Well, Mrs. Arbella, I hope you have consider'd
Enough by this time; you need not use so much consideration
For your own good; you may have your Estate, and you
May have Abel, and you may be worse offer'd.
Abel, tell her your mind, ne're stand, shall I, shall I—
Ruth, does she incline, or is she wilful?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: I was just about the point when your Honor
Interrupted us.—One word in your Ladiships ear.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: You see forsooth that I am some body, though you
Make no body of me, you see I can prevail; therefore
Pray say what I shall trust to;
For I must not stand, shall I, shall I.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: You are hasty, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: I am call'd upon by Important affairs;
And therefore I must be bold in a fair way to tell you that
It lies upon my spirit exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Saffron-posset-drink is very good against
The heaviness of the Spirit.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Nay, forsooth, you do not understand my meaning

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: You do, I hope, Sir; and 'tis no matter,
Sir, if one of us know it.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Well, know? who are all you?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What's here, an Irish Elder come to examine us all.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Well know, what is your names, ever one?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Arbella, this is a Servant to one of the Colonels; upon
My life, 'tis the Irishman that took the Covenant
The right way.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Peace, what shou'd it mean?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Well, cannot some of you all say nothing?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.l: Day. Why how now sauce-box? what wou'd you have?
What have you left your manners without? go
Our and fetch 'em in.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: What shou'd I fetch now?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Day D'you know who you speak to, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well, what are you then? upon my soul
In my own Countrey they can tell who I am.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: You must not be so saucy unto her Honour.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Well, I will knock you, if you be saucy with me then.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: This is miraculous.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Is there none of you that I must speak to now?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Now, wench, if he shou'd be sent to us.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Well I wou'd have one Mrs. Tay speak unto me.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Day. Well, Sirrah, I am she: what's your business?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: O so then, are you Mrs. Tay?
Well, I will look well first,
And I will set my face in some worship; yes indeed that I will;
And I will tell her then what I will speak to her.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: How the fellow begins to mould himself.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: And tempers his Chops like a hound that has lap'd
Before his meat was cold enough.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: He looks as if he had some gifts to pour forth;
Those are Mr. Day's own white eyes before he begins
To say grace: now for a speech ratling in his kecher,
As if his words stumbled in their way.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well, now I will tell thee, I'faith my Master
The good Colonel Careless, bid me ask thy good Ladiship—
Upon my soul now the laugh will come upon me.

div.stage: He laughs alwayes when he says Ladiship or Honor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Sirrah, sirrah, what were you sent to abuse me?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: As sure as can be.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: I'saith now I do not abuse thy good Hon. I cannot
Help my laugh now, I will try agen now; I will not
Think of a Kitchin then: my master wou'd know
Of your Ladiship—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Did your Master send you to abuse me, you
Rascal: By my honor, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Why do'st thou mock thy self now joy?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: How, Sirrah, do I mock my self?
This is some Irish Traytor.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: I am no Traytor, that I am not; I am an Irish
Rebel; you are couzen'd now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Sirrah, Sirrah, I will make you know who
I am, an impudent Irish Rascal.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: He seemeth a dangerous Fellow, and of a bold and
Seditious Spirit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: You are a bloody Rascal, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: You are a foolish brabble bribble Woman, that you are.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: Sirrah, we that are at the head of affairs
Must punish your Sauciness.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: You shall take a knock upon your Pate, if you are
Saucy with me, that I shall; you Son of a Roundhead, you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Ye Rascally Varlet, get you out of my Doors.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Will not I give you my Message then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Get you out, Rascal?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I prethee let me tell thee my Message?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Get you out, I say.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well then I care not neither; the Devil take
Your Ladyship, and Honourship, and Kitchenship too: there now.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Was there ever such a Scene? 'tis impossible
To guess any thing.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Our Colonels have don't, as sure as thou livest, to
Make themselves sport; being all the revenge that is in
Their power: look, look, how her Honour trots about,
Like a Beast stung with Flies.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: How the Villain has distemper'd me!
Out upon't too, that I have let the Rascal go unpublish'd,
And you can stand by like a Sheep: run after him then, and
Stop him; I'll have him laid by the heels, and
Make him confess who sent him to abuse me:
Call help as you go, make haste I say.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: 'Slid Arbella, run after him, and save the poor
Fellow for Sakes sake; Stop Abel by any means,
That he may scape.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Keep his Dam off, and let me alone with the Puppy.

sp.speaker: Ruth
sp.p: Fear not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: 'Uds my Life, the Rascal has heated me.—Now I
Think on't, I'll go my self, and see it done: a saucy Villain.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: But I must needs acquaint your Honour with one thing
••• st concerning Mrs. Arbella.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: As soon as ever I have done. Is't good news, Wench?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Most Excellent; if you go out you may spoil all;
Such a discovery I have made, that you will bless
The accident that anger'd you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Quickly then, Girl.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: When you sent Abel after the Irish-man,
Mrs. Arbella's Colour came and went in her Face, and at last
Not able to stay, slunk away after him for fear the Irish-man
Shou'd hurt him: she stole away and blush'd the prettiest.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: I protest he may be hurt indeed; I'll run my self too.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: By no means, forsooth; nor is there any need on't;
For the resolv'd to stop him before he cou'd
Get near the Irish-man; she has done it upon my Life;
And if you shou'd go out you might spoil the kindest
Encounter that the loving Abel is ever like to have.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Art sure of this?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: If you do not find she has stopt him,
Let me ever have your hatred; pray credit me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: I do, I do believe thee; come, we'll go in where
I use to read: there thou shalt tell me all the particulars,
And the manner of it: I warrant 'twas pretty to observe.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: O, 'twas a thousand pities you did not see't,
When Abel walk' • away so bravely, and foolishly after this
Wild Irish-man: She stole such kind looks from her
Own Eyes; and having rob'd her self, sent them after
Her own Abel; and then—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day
sp.l: Come, good Wench, I'll go in, and hear it all at
Large; it shall be the best tale thou hast told these two days.
Come, come, I long to hear all. Abel for his part needs
No News by this time, come, good Wench.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: So far I am right; Fortune take care for future things.

div.stage: Enter C. Blunt as taken by Bayliffs.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: At whose Suit, Rascals?

sp.speaker: 1 B▪
sp.p: You shall know that time enough.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Time enough, Dogs; must I wait your leisures?

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: O you are a dangerous Man; 'tis such Traytors as you
That disturb the Peace of the Nation.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Take that, Rascal: if I had any thing at liberty
Besides my Foot, I wou'd bestow it on you.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: You shall pay dearly for this kick before you are
Let loose, and give good special Bail: Mark that, my
Surly Companion; we have you fast.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: 'Tis well, Rogues, you caught me conveniently;
Had I been aware I wou'd have made some of your scurvy
Souls my special Bail.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: O, 'tis a bloody-minded Man; I'll warrant ye this
Vile Cavalier has eat many a Child.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: I cou'd gnaw a piece or two of you, Rascals.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: How is this! Blunt in hold! you Catchpole,
Let go your prey, or—

div.stage: Draws, and Blunt in the scu ••• e throws up one of their heels, and gets a Sword, and helps drive them off.

sp.speaker: 1 B▪
sp.p: Murder, Murder.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Faith, Careless, this was worth thanks, I was fairly going.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: What was the matter, Man?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Why, an Action or two for Free Quarter, now made
Trover and Conversion: Nay, I believe we shall be sued
With an Action of Trespass; for every Field we have
Marched over, and be indited for Riots, for going at
Unseasonable hours, above two in a Company.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Well come, let's away.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Now upon my Soul run as I do; the Men in red
Coats are running too, that they are, and they cry, Murder,
Murder, I never heard such a noise in Ireland, that's true too.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: 'Slife we must shift several ways.
Farewel, if we scape we meet at night; I shall
Take heed now.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Shall I tell of Mrs. Tay now?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: O good Teg, no time for Messages.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: This way, this way; Oh Villains, my Neighbour
••• sh is hurt dangerously;
Some good Souldiers, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: I am quite out of breath, and the Blood Hounds
Are in a full cry upon a burning scent: Plague on 'em,
What a noise the Kennels make? what Door's this
That graciously stands a little open? what an Ass am I to ask?
Teg, Scout abroad; if any thing happens extraordinary,
Observe this Door; there you shall find me: be careful,
Now by your favour, Landlord, as unknown.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: It was well observed, Obadiah, to bring the
Parties to me first, 'tis your Master's will that I shou'd, as I
May say, prepare matters for him; in truth, in truth
I have too great a burthen upon me: yet for the publick
Good I am content to undergo it.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: I shall with sincere care present unto your Honour
From time to time such negotiations as I may discreetly
Presume may be material for your Honours inspection.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: It will become you so to do, you have the
Present that came last.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: Yes, and please your Honour; the Gentleman
Concerning her Brothers release, hath also
Sent in a piece of Plate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: It's very well.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: But the Man without, about a bargain of the Kings
Land, is come empty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Bid him be gone, I'll not speak with him;
He does not understand himself.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: I shall intimate so much to him.

div.stage: As Obadiah goes out, C. Careless meets him and tumbles him back.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Why how now? what rude Companion's this?
What wou'd you have (what's your business? what's the
Matter? who sent you? who d'you belong to? who!—

sp.speaker: C Car.
sp.l: Hold, hold, if you mean to be answer'd to all
These Interrogatories, you see I resolve to be your Companion;
I am a Man, there's no great matter, no body sent me; nor I
Belong to no body: I think I have answer'd to the chief Heads.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Thou hast committed murder for ought I know?
How is't, Obadiah?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Ha, what luck have I to fall into the Territories
Of my old Kitchen acquaintance; I'll proceed upon the
Strength of Teg's Message, though I had no answer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: How is't, Man?

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: Truly he came forceably upon me, and I fear
Has bruised some intellectuals within my Stomach.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Go in and take some Irish Slat by way of
Prevention, and keep your self warm. Now, Sir, have you
Any business, you that came in so rudely as if you did not
Know who you came to. How came you in, Sir Royster?
Was not the Porter at the Gate?
