sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: No truly, the Gate kept it self, and stood gaping
As if it had a mind to speak, and say, I pray come in.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Did it so, Sir? and what have you to say?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: I, there's the point; either she does not, or will
Not know me: What shou'd I say? how dull am I? Pox on't,
This wit is like a common Friend, when one has need on him,
He won't come near one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Sir, are you studying for an invention? for ought
I know you have done some mischief,
And 'twere sit to secure you?

sp.speaker: C. Care.
sp.l: So that's well, 'twas pretty to fall into the head
Quarter of the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis e'n so, I'll fetch
Those that shall examine you.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Stay, thou mighty States-woman, I did but
Give you time to see if your memory would but be so
Honest, as to tell you who I am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: What d'you mean, Sauce-box?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: There's a word yet of thy former imployments,
That Sauce: you and I have been acquainted.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: I do not use to have acquaintance with Cavaliers.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Nor I with Committee-mens Utensils; but in
Diebus illis, you were not Honourable, nor I a Malignant.
Lord, Lord, you are horrible forgetful, Pride comes with
Godliness, and good Cloaths; what, you think I shou'd
Not know you, because you are disguised with curl'd Hair,
And white Gloves. Alas, I know you as well as if you were
In your Sabbath-days Cinamon Waistcoat, with a silver
Edging round the Skirt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: How, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: And with your fair hands bath'd in Lather, or
With your fragrant Breath, driving the fleeting
Ambergreece off from the waving Kitchenstuff.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: O, you are an impudent Cavalier! I remember
You now indeed; but I'll—

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Nay, but hark you the now Honourable,
Non obstante past conditions; did not I send my Fool Man,
An Irish-man, with a civil Message to you;
Why all this strangeness then.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: How, how, how's this; was't you that sent
That Rascal to abuse me, was't so.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: How now! what, matters grow worse and worse?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: I'll teach you to abuse those that are in
Authority: Within there, who's within?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: 'Slife, I'll stop your mouth, if you raise an Alarm.

div.stage: Cryes out, and he stops her mouth▪

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Stop my mouth, Sirrah, whoo, whoo, ho.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Yes, stop your mouth, what are you good at a
Who, bub, ha.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: What's the matter, Forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: The matter? why heres a rude Cavalier has
Broke into my House; 'twas he too that sent the Irish Rascal
To abuse me too within my own Walls: Call your Father, that
He may grant his Order to secure him. 'Tis a dangerous Fellow.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Nay, good pretty Gentlewoman, spare your motion,
What must become of me? Teg has made some strange mistake.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: 'Tis he, what shall I do, (now invention be equal to
My Love) why, your Ladiship will spoil all? I sent for aside.
This Gentleman, and enjoyn'd him secrecy, even to you your self,
Till I had made his way. O fie upon't, I am to blame; but in
Truth I did not think he would have come these two hours.

sp.speaker: C Car.
sp.l: I dare swear she did not; I might very probably
Not have come at all.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: How came you to come so soon, Sir; 'twas three
Hours before you appointed.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Hey day, I shall be made believe I came hither
On purpose presently.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: 'Twas upon a message of his to me, and please your
Honour to make his desires known to your Ladiship, that he
Had consider'd on't and was resolved to take the Covenant,
And give you five hundred pound to make his peace, and bring
His business about again, that he may be
Admitted in his first condition.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: What's this? d'hear, pretty Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Well, well, I know your mind, I have done your business.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Oh, his stomach's come down!

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Sweeten him again, and leave him to me;
I warrant you the five hundred pound and—

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Now I have found it: this pretty wench has
A mind to be left alone with me, at her peril.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: I understand thee; well, Sir, I can pass by rudeness
When I am informed there was no intention of it; I leave
You and my Daughter to beget a right understanding.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: We should beget Sons and Daughters sooner:
What does all this mean?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: I am sorry, Sir, that your love for me
Shou'd make you thus rash.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: That's more than you know, but you had a mind
To be lest alone with me; that's certain.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: 'Tis too plain, Sir, you'd ne'er have run your self
Into this danger else.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Nay, now you'r out; the danger run after me.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: You may dissemble.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Why, 'tis the proper business here; but we lose
Time; you and I are left to beget right understanding,
Come, which way?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: To your Chamber or Closet.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: But I am ingag'd you shall take the Covenant.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: No, I never swear when I am bid.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: But you wou'd do as bad?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: That's not against my principles.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Thank you for your fair opinion, good Signior
Principle, there lies your way, Sir, however I will own so much
Kindness for you, that I repent not the civility I have done,
To free you from the trouble you were like to fall into;
Make me a leg, if you please, and cry, Thank you: and so the
Gentlewoman that desired to be left alone with you, desires
To be left alone with her self, she being taught a right
Understanding of you.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: No, I am revited; nor shall you march off thus
With flying colours: my pretty Commander in chief, let us
Parley a little farther, and but lay down ingenuously the true
State of our Treaty. The business in short is this, We differ
Seemingly upon two evils, and mine the least; and therefore
To be chosen, you had better take me, than I take the Covenant.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: We'll excuse one another.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: You wou'd not have me take the Covenant then.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: No, I did but try you, I forgive your idle looseness;
For that firm vertue be constant to your fair principles
In spite of fortune.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: What's this got into petti-coats—but d'hear,
I'le not excuse you from my proposition, notwithstanding
My release: Come we are half way to a right
Understanding—nay, I do love thee.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Love vertue, you have but here and there a patch
Of it; y'are ragged still.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Are you not the Committee Day's Daughter?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Yes, what then.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Then am I thankful, I had no defence against thee
And Matrimony, but thy own Father and Mother,
Which are a perfect Committee to my nature.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Why are you sure I wou'd have match'd with a
Malignant, not a Compounder neither.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Nay, I have made thee a Joynture against my will;
Methinks it were but as reasonable, that I shou'd do something
For my Joynture, but by the way of Matrimony honestly
To encrease your Generation; this, to tell you truth, is
Against my Conscience.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Yet you wou'd beget right understandings.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Yes, I wou'd have 'um all Bastards.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: And me a Whore.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: That's a coarse name; but 'tis not sit a Committee-
Man's Daughter should be too honest, to the reproach
Of her Father and Mother.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: When the quarrel of the Nation is reconcil'd, you
And I shall agree: till when, Sir—

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Are you here then? upon my shoul the good Colonel
Blunt is over-taken again now, and carried to the Devil,
That he is, I'saith now.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: How, taken and carried to the Devil!

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: He desired to go to the Devil, that he did, I wonder of
My shoul he was not afraid of that.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: I understand it now; what mischief's this?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: You seem troubled, Sir.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: I have but a life to lose, that I am weary of: come, Teg.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Hold, you shan't go before I know the business;
What d'ye talk of?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: My friend, my dearest friend is caught up by rascally
Bayliffs, and carried to the Devil-Tavern; pray let me go.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Stay but a minute, if you have any kindness for me.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Yes, I do love you.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Perhaps I may serve your friend. Enter Arbella.
O Arbella, I was going to seek you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ruth
sp.l: The Colonel which thou lik'st is taken by Bayliffs;
There's his Friend too almost distracted: You know
The mercy of these times

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What do'st thou tell me, I am ready to sink down!

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Compose your self, and help him nobly; you have no
Way but to smile upon Abel, and get him to bail him.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Look where he and Obadiah comes; shou'd either
By providence—O Mr. Abel, where have you been this long
Time? can you find of your heart to keep thus out of my sight▪

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: Assuredly, some important affairs constrain'd my
Absence, as Obadiah can testifie, Bona fide.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: I can do so verily, my self being a material party.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Pox on 'em, how slow they speak.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Well, well, you shall go no more out of my sight; I'll
Not be satisfied with your Bona fides: I have some occasions
That call me to go a little way; you shall e'en go with me,
And good Obadiah too: you shall not deny me any thing.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: Is it not meet I shou'd, I am exceedingly exalted;
Obadiah thou shalt have the best bargain of all my Tenants.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: I am thankful.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: What may this mean?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Ruth, how shall we do to keep thy swift Mother
From pursuing us?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Let me alone, as I go by the Parlor where she sits,
Big with expectation; I'le give her a whisper that we
Are going to fetch the very five hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: No question now. Will you march, Sir?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Lord, how dull these men in Love are! why to your
Friend. No more words.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: I will stare upon thee though.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Colonel Blunt brought in by Bayliffs.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.p: I, I, we thought how well you'd get Bail.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Why, you unconscionable Rascal, are you
Angry that I am unlucky, or do you want some Fees?
I'll perish in a dungeon before I'll consume with throwing
Sops to such Curs.

sp.speaker: 1 Ba.
sp.p: Chuse, chuse, come along with him.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: I'll not go your pace neither, Rascals; I'll go softly,
If it be but to hinder you from taking up some other
Honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: Very well, surly Sir, we will carry you where you
Shall not be troubled what pace to walk; you'l find a
Large Bell, blood is dear; not yours is it? a farthing a pint
Were very dear for the best urine you have.

div.stage: Enter Arbella, Ruth, Abel, C. Careless, and Obadiah.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.p: How now, are these any of your Friends?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Never if you see Women, that's a Rule.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Nay, you need have no scruple, 'tis a near Kinsman
Of mine, you do not think I hope that I wou'd let you suffer—
You—that must be nearer than a Kinsman to me.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: But my Mother doth not know it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: If that be all, leave it to me and Ruth, we'll save
You harmless: besides I cannot marry, if my Kinsman be in
Prison; he must convey my Estate as you appoint; for 'tis
All in him, we must please him.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: The consideration of that doth convince me.
Obadiah, 'tis necessary for us to set at liberty this Gentleman,
Being a Trustee for Mrs. Arbella's Estate; tell 'em therefore
That you and I will Bail this Gentleman—and—
D'hear, tell them who I am.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: I shall. Gentlemen, this is the honourable
Mr. Abel Day, the first-born of the Honourable Mr. Day,
Chair-man of the Committee of Sequestrations, and I
My self by name Obadiah, and Clerk to the said
Honourable Committee.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.p: Well, Sir, we know Mr. Day, and Mr. Abel.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: Yes, that's I, and I will bail this Gentleman; I believe
You dare not except against the Bail: nay, you shall have
Obadiah's too, one that the State trusts.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: With all our hearts, Sir—
But there are Charges to be paid.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Here, Obadiah, take this Purse and discharge them,
And give the Bayliffs twenty shillings to drink.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: This is miraculous.

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.p: A brave Lady: I'faith Mrs. we'll drink your health.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: She's to be my Wife, as sure as you are here;
What say you to that now?

sp.speaker: 1 B.
sp.l: That's impossible; here's something more in this:
Honourable Mr. Abel, the Sheriffs Deputy is hard by in
Another room, if you please to go thither,
And give your Bail, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Well, shew us the way, and let him know who I am.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Hark ye, pretty Mrs. Ruth, if you were not Exeunt Abel, Obadiah, and Bayliffs.
A Committee-man's Daughter, and so consequently
Against Monarchy, two Princes shou'd
Have you and that Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: No, no, you'll serve my turn; I am not ambitious.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Do but swear then that thou art not the Issue of
Mr. Day, and though I know 'tis a lye, I'll be content
To be cousen'd, and believe.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Fie, sie, you can't abide taking of Oaths; look,
Look how your Friend and mine take aim at one another:
Is he smitten?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Cupid has not such another wounded Subject,
Nay, and is vex'd he is in love too;
Troth 'tis partly my own case.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Peace, she begins as need requires.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: You are free, Sir.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Not so free as you think.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What hinders it?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Nothing, but I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Why, Sir?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: You'll laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Have you perceived me apt to commit such a rudeness,
Pray let me know it?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Upon two conditions you shall know it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Well, make your own Laws.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: First I thank you, y'have freed me nobly; pray
Believe it, you have this acknowledgment from an
Honest heart, one that would crack a string for you,
That's one thing.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Well, the other.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: The other is only, that I may stand so ready,
That I may be gone just as I have told it you; together
With your promise, not to call me back: and upon these
Terms I give you leave to laugh when I am gone. Careless,
Come stand ready, that at the sign given
We may vanish together.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: If you please, Sir, when you are ready to start,
I'll cry one, two, three, and away.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Be pleased to forbear, good smart Gentlewoman,
You have leave to jeer when I am gone, and am just going;
By your spleens leave a little patience.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Prethee, peace.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: I shall contain, Sir.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: That's much for a Woman to do.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Now, Sir, perform your promise.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Careless, have you done with your Woman?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Nay, I have thank'd her already; prethee no more
Of that dull way of gratitude; stand ready, Man, yet nearer
The Door: so now my misfortune that I promised to
Discover, is, that I love you above my sense or reason:
So farewel, and laugh; Come, Careless.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Ladies, our lives are yours; be but so kind as to
Believe it, till you have something to command.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Was there ever such humour?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: As I live his confession shews nobly.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: It shews madly I am sure, an ill-bred Fellow, not
Indure a Woman to laugh at him!

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: He's honest, I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: That's more than I dare swear for my Colonel.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Out upon him.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis but for want of a good Example;
I'll make him so.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: But d'hear, Ruth, we were horribly to blame, that we
Did not enquire where they lodg'd, under pretence of sending
To them about their own business.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Why, thy whimsical Colonel discharg'd himself off
Like a Gun: there was no time between the flashing in
The pan, and the going off, to ask a question: but hark ye,
I have an invention upon the old account of the
Five hundred pound, which shall make Abel send
His Pursuivant, Obadiah, to look 'em.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Excellent! the Trout Abel will bite immediately at
That bait: the Message shall be as from his Master Day, Senior,
To come and speak with him; they'll think
Presently 'tis about their Composition, and come certainly.
In the mean time we'll prepare them with Counter-expectations

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: You have it, peace, see where Abel and the gentle
Squire of low degree, Obadiah, approaches, having newly
Entred themselves into Bonds.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Which I'll be sure to tell his Mother, if he be
Evermore troublesome.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: And that he's turn'd an arrant Cavalier,
By bailing one of the Brood.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: I have according to your desires given freedom to
Your Kinsman and Trustee; I suppose he doth perceive
That you may have power in right of me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Good Mr. Abel, I am sincerely beholding to you,
And your Authority.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: O sie upon't, Brother, I did forget to acquaint
You with a business before the Gentlemen went.
O me, what a Sieve-like memory have I,
'Twas an important affair too.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: If you discover it to me, I shall render you
My opinion upon the whole.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: The two Gentlemen have repented of their obstinacy,
And wou'd now present five hundred pound to your good
Honourable Mother, to stand their Friend, that they may be
Permitted to take the Covenant, and we, negligent we,
Have let them go, before we knew where to send to them.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: That was the want of being us'd to important affairs;
It is ill to neglect the accepting of their conversion,
Together with their money.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Well, there is but one way; do you send Obadiah
In your Father's Name, to desire them both to come to his House
About some business that will be for their good, but no more;
For then they'll take it ill; for they enjoin'd us secrecy;
And when they come, let us alone: Obadiah may enqui • e
Them out at some Tavern.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: The Bayliffs did say they were gone
To the Devil▪ Tavern to pay a reckoning.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: Hasten thither, good Obadiah, as if you had met
My Honourable Father, and desire them to come unto
His House, about an important affair that is for their good.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: I shall use expedition.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: And we will hasten home, lest the Gentlemen shou'd
Be before us, and not know how to address their offers;
And then we will hasten our being united in the
Bonds of Matrimony▪

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Soft and fair goes far.

div.stage: Enter the two Colonels, and Teg as at the Tavern.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Did ever Man get away so craftily from the thing
He lik't; terrible business, afraid to tell a Woman what she
Desir'd to hear; I pray heartily that the Boys do not come
To the knowledge of thy famous retreat; we shall be followed
By those small Birds, as you have seen an Owl pursued.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: I shall break some of their Wings then.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: To leave a handsome Woman, a Woman that came
To be bound Body for Body for thee; one that does that
Which no Woman will hardly do again.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Love thee, and thy Blunt Humour; a meer chance,
Man, a thing besides all the venerate Stars.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: You practice your Wit to no purpose; I am not
To be perswaded to lie still, like a Jack-a-lent to be cast at;
I had rather be a Wisp hung up for a Woman to scold at,
Than a fix'd Lover for 'em to point at:
Your Squib began to hiss.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Peace, Man, here's Jupiter's Mercury, is his
Message to us, trow?

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: Gentlemen, you are opportunely over-taken
And found out.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: I come unto you in the name of the Honourable
Mr. Day, who desires to speak with you both about some
Important affair, which is conducing for your good.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: What train is this?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Peace, let us not be rash, Teg.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Well then.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Were it not possible that you cou'd entertain this
Fellow in the next room till he were pretty drunk?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: I warrant you that now, I will make him and my self
Too drunk for thy sweet sake.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Be sure, Teg—some business, Sir, that will take us
Up a very little time to finish, make us desire your patience
Till we dispatch it: In the mean time, Sir, do us the
Favour as to call for a glass of Sack: in the next room
Teg shall wait upon you, and drink your Master's health.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: It needeth not, nor do I use to drink healths.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: None but your Masters, Sir, and that by
Way of remembrance.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: We that have the affairs of State under our
Tuition cannot long delay; my presence may be required
For the carrying on the work.

sp.speaker: C Car.
sp.l: Nay, Sir, it shall not exceed above a quarter
Of an hour; perhaps we'll wait upon you to Mr. Day presently▪
Pray, Sir, drink but one glass or two; we wou'd wait upon you
Our selves, but that wou'd hinder us from going with you.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: Upon that consideration I shall attend a little.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Go wait upon him, now Teg or never.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I will make him so drunk as can be upon my Soul.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: What a Devil shou'd this Message mean?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: 'Tis too plain; this cream of Committee Rascals! who has
Better Intelligence than a State-Secretary, has heard
Of his Son Abel's being hamper'd, in the cause of the
Wicked, and in revenge wou'd intice us to Perdition.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: If Teg cou'd be so fortunate as to make him drunk,
We might know all.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: If the close-hearted Rogue will not be open mouth'd,
We'll leave him pawn'd for all our scores, and stuff his Pockets
With blank Commissions.

sp.speaker: C Bl.
sp.p: Only fill up one with his Master's name.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: And another with his Wife's name for Adjutant General,
Together with a Bill of Ammunition hid under Day's House,
And make it be digg'd down, with scandal of Delinquency.
A Rascal to think to invite us into Newgate!

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Well, we must resolve what to do.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: I have a fancy come into my head that may produce
An admirable Scene.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Come, let's hear.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: 'Tis upon supposition, that Teg makes him drunk,
And by the way 'tis a good Omen that we have no sober
Apparition in that wavering posture of frailty; we'll send him
Home in a Sedan, and cause him to be deliver'd in that
Good natur'd condition, to the ill natur'd Rascal
His Master.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: It will be Excellent: how I pray for Teg
To be Victorious!

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Gentlemen, will you have any Musick?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Prethee no, we are out of tune.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Pish, we never will be out of humour. Do'st hear,
Canst sing us a Malignant Sonnet?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I can sing many Songs. You seem honest Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Cavaliers thou mean'st.
Sing without any apprehension.

lg.l: NOW the Vail is pull'd off, and this pitiful Nation
Too late see the gull of a Kirk-Reformation,
How all things that shou'd be
Are turn'd topsie turvy;
The Freedom we have,
Our Prince made a Slave,
And the Masters must now turn the Waiters.
The great ones obey,
While the Rascals do sway,
And the Loyal to Rebels are Traytors.
The Pulpits are crowded with tongues of their own,
And the Preachers spiritual Committee-men grown,
To denounce Sequestration
On Souls of old Fashion,
They Rail and they Pray,
Till they quite preach away
The Wealth that was once the wise Cities.
The Courts in the Hall
Where the Lawyers did bawl,
Are turn'd into pious Committees.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: This Song has rais'd my Spirits: Here, sing always
For the King; I wou'd have every Man in his way do something
For him; I wou'd have Fidlers sing for him, Parsons pray
For him, Men fight for him, Women scold for him, and
Children cry for him, and according to this rule,
Teg is drinking for him: but see, Enter Teg and Obadiah drunk.
See and rejoice where Teg with Laurel comes.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: And the vanquish'd Obadiah with nothing fix'd
About him but his Eyes.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Stay, sing another Song in the behalf of
Compounders if thou canst, that the vapours of the Wine
May have full power to ascend up to the firmament of
His truly reformed Coxcomb.

lg.l: COme, Drawer, some Wine,
Let it sparkle and shine,
And make its own drops fall abounding;
Like the Hearts it makes light,
Let it flow pure and right,
And a Plague take all kind of Compounding.
We'll not be too wise,
Nor try to advise,
How to suffer and gravely despair:
For Wisdom and Parts
Sit brooding on hearts,
And there they catch nothing but care.
Not a thought shall come in
But what brings our King,
Let Committees be damn'd with their gain;
We'll send by this stealth
To our Hearts our Kings Health,
And there in despite he shall Reign.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: This is sport beyond modest hopes. How I will
Adore Sack that can force this Fellow to Religion. The Rogue
Is full of Worship.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well now, upon my Soul, Mr. Obed.
Commit sings as well as the Man now:
Come then will you sing an Irish Song after me?

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: I will sing Irish for the King now.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I will sing for the King as well as you. Hark you now.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: That is too hard stuff; I cannot do these and these
Material matters.

div.stage: He sings an Irish Song, and Obadiah tries.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Here now, we will take some snuff for the King—so
There lay it upon your hand; put one of your Noses to it now,
So snuff now. Upon my Soul, Mr. Obed Commit will make
A brave Irish-man.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: I will snuff for the King no more. Good Mr. Teg,
Give me some more Sack, and sing English for my money.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: I will tell you that Irish is as good and better too.
Come now we will dance: Can you play an Irish Tune?
Can you play this now.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: No, Sir, but I can play you an excellent Irish Jig.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: This is beyond thought: So this motion
Like a tumbled Barrel has set the Liquor a working again.
Now for a Chair.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Drawer, who waits there?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: What d'you want Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Call a Chair presently, and bring their Chair into
This room; here's a friend of ours overtaken.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: I go, Sir.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Teg, thou hast done miracles, thou art a good Omen,
And hast vanquish'd the cause in this overthrow of this
Counterfeit Rascal its true Epitome: And now, Teg,
According to the words of Condemnation, we'l send him
To the place from whence he came.

sp.speaker: Teg
sp.l: Upon my shoul he's dead now, shall I howl as we do
In Ireland.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: How's that, Teg.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Yo, yo.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: No more, good, Teg, lest you give an Alarm to the
Enemy. Welcome, honest fellow; by your looks you seem so.

sp.speaker: 1 C.
sp.p: How Colonel, have you forgot your poor Souldier Ned.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Why, this is a miraculous pursuit of good fortune,
Honest Ned; what turn'd Chair-man?
Any thing for Bread and Beer, noble Colonel, shall I
Have the Honour to carry you.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: No, Ned, is thy fellow honest?
Or I'de be hang'd before I carry a Chair an inch with him.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: 'Tis well—look you, Ned, that fellow is Mr. Day
The Committee-man's Clerk, whom with wonderful industry
We have made drunk: Just as he is, pack him up in thy Chair,
And immediately transport him to his Master Day's house;
And in the very Hall turn him out. There's half a Crown
For thy pains.
If I fail, say Ned's a Coward: Come shall we put your short
Wing'd worship into your mew. Come along.

div.stage: They put him in and Ex.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Farewel, Ned: Teg, come, you must carry some
Money to one or two confident friends of mine;
We'l pay our Reckoning at the Bar, then go home and laugh;
And if you will plot some way to see our inchanting Females
Once more; they make me so long—

div.stage: Enter Mr. Day, and Mrs. Day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day
sp.l: Dispatch quickly I say, and say I said it; many
Things fall between the lip and the cup.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Nay, duck, let thee alone for counsel. Ah,
If thou hadst been a man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Why then you wou'd have wanted a Woman,
And a helper too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: I profess so I shou'd, and a notable one too, though
I say't before thy face, and that's no ill one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Come, come, you are wandring from the matter;
Dispatch the Marriage I say, whil'st she is thus taken with
Our Abel. Women are uncertain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: How if she shou'd be coy?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: You are at your iffs again; if she be foolish,
Tell her plainly what she must trust to, no Abel, no Land;
Plain dealing's a Jewel: Have you the Writings drawn
As I advised you, which she must sign?

sp.speaker: M. Day.
sp.l: I, I warrant you, duck; Here, here they be.
Oh she has a brave Estate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: What news you have.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: Look you, Wife.

div.stage: Day pulls out Writings, and lays out his Keys.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Pish, teach your Grannam to spin; let me see.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: May it please your Honour, your good neighbour
Zechariah is departing this troublesome life: he has made
Your Honour his Executor, but cannot depart
Till he has seen your Honours.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Alas, alas, a good man will leave us, Come, good
Duck, let us hasten: Where is Obadiah to usher you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Why Obadiah, a Varlet to be out of the way at
Such a time; truly he moveth my wrath. Come, Husband, along,
I'll take Abel in his place.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: What's the meaning of this Alarm? there's some Carion
Discover'd; the Crows are all gone upon a sudden.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: The she-Day call'd most fiercely for Obadiah;
Look here, Ruth, what have they left behind?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: As I live, it is the Day's bunch of Keys, which he always
Keeps so closely:—well—if thou hast any metal,
Now's the time.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: To do what?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: To fly out of Egypt.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Peace, we are betray'd else; as sure as can be, wench,
He's come back for the Keys.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: We'll forswear 'em in confident words, and no less
Confident countenances.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: An important affair hath call'd my Honourable Father
And Mother forth, and in the absence of Obadiah I am enforced
To attend their Honours, and therefore I conceiv'd it right
And meet to acquaint you with it; lest in my absence you
Might have apprehended, that some mischance had befallen
My person: therefore I desire you to receive consolation;
And so I bid you heartily farewel.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Given from his mouth this tenth of April, he
Put me in a cruel fright.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: As I live, I am all over in such a dew as hangs about a
Still when 'tis first set a going; but this is better and better:
There was never such an opportunity to break prison.
I know the very places holes in his Closet where the
Composition of your Estate lies, and where the Deeds of my
Own Estate lie. I have cast my eye upon them often
When I have gone up to him in errands, and to call
Him to dinner. If I miss, hang me.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: But whither shall we go?

sp.speaker: Ruth
sp.l: To a friend of mine, and of my Fathers, that lives
Near the Temple, and will harbor us; fear not, and so set
Up for our selves, and get our Colonels.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Nay, the mischief that I have done, and the condition
We are in, makes me as ready as thou art: come let's about it.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Stay, do you stand Centinel here, that's the
Closet-Window; I'll call for thee, if I need thee; and
Be sure to give notice of any news of the enemy.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I warrant thee, may but this departing Brother have
So much string of life left him as nay tie this expecting Day
To his Bedside, till we have committed this honest Robbery—
Hark!—what's that—this apprehension can make a noise
When there is none.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: I have 'em, I have 'em; nay the whole covey,
And his Seal at Arms bearing a Dog's Leg.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Come make haste then.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: As I live here's a Letter counterfeited to the King,
To the Rascal his rebellious Subject Day; with a remembrance
To his discreet Wife; nay, what do'st thou think these are?
I'll but cast my Eye upon these Papers that were Schismatically,
And lay in separation: what do'st think they are?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I can't tell; nay prethee come away.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Out upon the precise Baboon:
They are Letters from two Wenches, one from an encrease of sallary
To maintain his unlawful Issue; another from a Wench
That had more Conscience than he, and refus'd
To take the Physick that he prescrib'd to take away
A natural Tympany.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Nay, prethee dispatch.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Here be abundance more; come run up, and help
Me carry 'em. We'll take the whole Index of his Rogueries?
We shall be furnish'd with such arms, offensive and defensive,
That we shall never need
Sue to him for a League. Come, make haste.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: I come.

sp.l: Come open this portable Tomb: 'Slife here's nothing in it;
Ferret him, or he'll never bolt. It looks as if we had brought
A basket Hare to be set down and hunted.
He's dead.
Dead drunk, thou mean'st; turn up the Chair, and turn
Him out as they do Badgers caught in a Sack: Shake,
Man; So, now he sallies.

div.stage: Obadiah tumbles out of the Chair, and sings as at the Tavern—of the Song, and Enter Arbella and Ruth from robbing the Closet.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What's this? we are undone.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: Mr. Teg, will you dance, Mr. Teg.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Put a good Face on't, or give me the Van. O, 'tis Obadiah fallen.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Nay, and cannot rise neither: d'hear, honest Friends,
Was this zealous Gentleman your fraight.
Yes, Mistress, two honest Gentlemen took care of him, seeing
Him thus devoutly over-taken.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: It was our Colonels that thought Day sent him to trapan
Them as sure as can be.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: No doubt on't; how unmerciful they are, Arbella,
Every minute to do something or other to encrease
Our whimsie—Are you paid?
Yes, Mistress,—'Slife we shall be paid double.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Stay, where did you leave the two
Careful-minded Gentlemen.
Why do you ask, Mistress?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: For no hurt. Can'st carry us near the place?
Yes, Mistress, sure there's no danger in Women.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What do'st mean?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: The same that thou do'st, to see 'em if I can;

Is't near Temple-Bar?
Obadiah sings.
Hard by, Minstress.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Come in, there's my Friend lives hard by; fear not,
We can never fly so conceal'd—May that Nightingale continue
His note, till the Owl Day returns to hear him: Come,
Honest Fellow, stay over against the place where you
Left the Gentlemen; we have some business with them;
We'll pay you, and they'll thank you: so good night, Mr. Day.
I warrant you, Mistress. Come along, Tom.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: Some small Beer, good Mr. Teg.

div.stage: Enter as return'd, Mr. Day, Mrs. Day, and Abel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: He made a good end, and departed as unto sleep.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: I'll assure you his Wife took on grievously;
I do not believe she'll marry this half year.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: He died full of Exhortation. Ha, Duck,
Shou'dst be sorry to lose me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Lose you; I warrant you you'll live as long as
A better thing—Ah, Lord, what's that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: How now! what's this? how!—Obadiah—
And in a drunken distemper assuredly!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: O fie upon'e, who wou'd have believ'd that he
Shou'd have liv'd to have seen Obadiah overcome with the
Creature? Where have you been, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: D—d—drinking, the Ki—Ki—Kings's Health.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: O terrible, some disgrace put upon us, and shame
Brought within our Walls; I'll go lock up my
Neighbour's Will, and come down and shew him
A Reproof.—How—how—I cannot feel my Keys—nor— He feels in his Pocket, and leaps up to.
Hear 'em gingle: Didst thou see my Keys, Duck?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Duck me no ducks; I see your Keys, see a Fools
Head of your own: Had I kept them, I warrant they had been
Forth coming: You are so slappish, you throw 'em up and
Down at your Tail: Why don't you go look if you have
Not left them in the Door?

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: I go, I go, Duck.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Here, Abel, take up this fallen Creature, who has
Left his uprightness; carry him to a Bed, and when he is
Return'd to himself, I will exhort him.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: He is exceedingly over-whelmed.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: Stand away, I say, and give me some Sack, that He goes to lift him.
I may drink a health to the King, and let Committees
Be damn'd with their gain. Obadiah sings.
Where's Mr. Teg?

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Undone, undone, rob'd, rob'd; the Door's left
Open, and all my Writings, Papers stollen, undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Why Ruth, I say, Thieves, Thieves!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: What's the matter, Forsooth? here has been no Thieves,
I have not been a minute out of the House.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Where's Ruth, and Mrs. Arbella?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I have not seen them a pretty while.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: 'Tis they have rob'd me, and taken away
The Writings of both their Estates. Undone, undone!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: This came with staying for you, Coxcomb,
We had come back sooner else: yes, slow Drone, we must
Be undone for your dullness.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: Be not in wrath.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: I'll wrath you, ye Rascal you, teaching you,
Drunken Rascal, and you sober Dullman.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: Your Feet are swift and violent; their motion
Will make them fume.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: D'lye too, ye drunken Rascal?

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Nay patience, good Duck, and let's lay out
For these Women; they are the Thieves.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: 'Twas you that left your Keys upon the Table
To tempt them: ye need cry, good Duck, be patient. Bring in
The drunken Rascal, ye Booby, when he is sober he may
Discover something. Come take him up; I'll have 'em hunted.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.l: I rejoice yet in the midst of my sufferings, that my Mistress
Saw not my rebukes. Come, Obadiah, I pray raise your self
Upon your Feet, and walk.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: Have you taken the Covenant? that's the question.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Yea.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: And will you drink a Health to the King?
That's t'other question.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Make not thy self a scorn.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: Scorn in thy Face; void, young Satan.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: I pray you walk in, I shall be assisting.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: Stand off, and you shall perceive by my stedfast going,
That I am not drunk. Look ye now—so, softly, softly; gently,
Good Obadiah, gently and steadily, for fear it should be said
That thou art in drink: so, gently and uprightly, Obadiah.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: You do not move.

div.stage: He moves his Legs, but stands still.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.p: Then do I stand still, as fast as you go.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: What, stay all day? there's for you, Sir;
You are a sweet Youth to leave in trust; along you
Drunken Rascals, I'll set you both forward.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: The Philistines are upon us, and Day is broke loose
From darkness, with keeping has made her fierce.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Out, you drunken Rascal, I'll make
You move, you Beast.

div.head: ACT V.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Bookseller and Bayliffs, having laid hold on Teg.

sp.speaker: Booksell.
sp.p: COme along, Sir, I'll teach you to take Covenants.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Will you teach me then; did I not take
It then? why will you teach me now?

sp.speaker: Booksell.
sp.l: You shall pay dearly for the blows you struck me,
My wild Irish, by St. Patrick, you shall.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: What have you now to do with St. Patrick? he will
Scorn your Covenant.

sp.speaker: Booksell.
sp.l: I'll put you, Sir, where you shall have worse liquor,
Than your Bonny-Clabber.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Bonny-Clabber! by my Goships hand now you are
A Rascal if you do not look Bonny-Clabber, and I will break
Your pate if you will not let me go to my Master.

sp.speaker: Booksell.
sp.p: O you are an impudent Rascal. Come, away with him.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: How now, hold, my Friend; whither do
You carry my Servant?

sp.speaker: Booksell.
sp.l: I have arrested him, Sir, for striking me, and taking
Away my Books.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: What has he taken away?

sp.speaker: Booksell.
sp.l: Nay, the value of the thing is not much;
'Twas the Covenant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well, I did take the Covenant, and my Mastero took it
From me, and we have taken the Covenant then, have we not?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Here, honest Fellow, here's more than thy Covenant's
Worth; here, Bayliffs, here's for you to drink.

sp.speaker: Booksell.
sp.l: Well, Sir, you seem an honest Gentleman; for
Your sake, and in hopes of your Custom, I release him.

sp.p: Thank ye, noble Sir.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Farewel, my noble Friends—so—d'hear, Teg. Ex.
Pray take no more Covenants,—Have you paid the money
I sent you with?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Yes, but I will carry no more, look you there now.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Why, Teg?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: God sa'my Soul now, I shall run away with it.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Pish, thou art too honest.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: That I am too upon my Soul now; but the Devil is
Not honest, that he is not; he would not let me alone
When I was going; but he made go to this little long place,
And t'other little long place; and upon my Soul was carrying
Me to Ireland, for he made me go by dirty place like a lough
Now; and therefore I know now it was the way to Ireland:
Then I wou'd stand still, and then he wou'd make me go on;
And then I wou'd go to one side, and he wou'd make me go
To t'other side; and then I got a little farther, and did
Run then; and upon my Soul the Devil cou'd not catch me;
And then I did pay the money: but I will carry no more
Money now that I will not.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: But thou sha't, Teg, when I have more to send;
Thou art proof now against temptations.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well then, if you send me with money again, and if I
Do not come to thee upon the time, the Devil will make me
Be gone then with the money: Here is a Paper for thee,
'Tis a quit way indeed.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: That's well said, Teg.—

div.stage: Enter Mr. Day, Obadiah, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: See, Sir, Providence hath directed us; there is one
Of them that clothed me with shame, and the most malignant
Among the wicked.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Souldiers, seize him, I charge him with Treason;
Here's a Warrant to the Keeper, as I told you.

sp.speaker: 1 S.
sp.p: Nay, no resistance now.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: What's the matter, Rascals?

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: You shall know that to your cost hereafter,
Away with him.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Teg, tell 'em I shall not come home to night, I am engag'd.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I prethee ben't engag'd.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I am guilty of nothing, that I know of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: That will appear, Sir: away with him.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: What will you do with my Master now?

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: Be quiet, Sir, or you shall go with him.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: That I will for all you now.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Teg, come hither.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Must not I go with you then?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: No, no, be sure to do as I tell you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Away with him, we will be aveng'd on the scorner,
And I'll go home and tell my Duck this part of my good fortune.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: So far we are right, now, honest Fellow, step over
And tell the two Gentlemen, that we two Women desire
To speak with them.

sp.speaker: 1 C.
sp.p: See, Mistress, here's one of them.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: That's thy Colonel, Arbella, catch him quickly,
Or he'll fly again.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What shou'd I do?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Put forth some good words, as they use to
Shake Oats when they go to catch a skittish Jade.
Advance.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Lady—'tis she.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: I wish, Sir, that my Friend and I had some conveniency
Of speaking with you: we now want the assistance of
Some noble Friend.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Then I am happy; bring me but to do something
For you; I wou'd have my actions talk, not I: my Friend
Will be here immediately; I dare speak for him too—
Pardon my last confusion; but what I told you was as true
As if I had staid.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: To make Affidavit of it.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Good over-charged-Gentlewoman,
Spare me but a little.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Prethee peace, canst thou be merry, and we in
This condition. Sir, I do believe you noble, truly worthy:
If we might withdraw any whither out of sight,
I wou'd acquaint you with the business.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: My House, Ladies, is at that Door, where both
The Colonels lodge: Pray command it, Colonel Careless
Will immediately be here.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well now, my good Master will not come;
That Commit Rogue Day has got him with Men in red Coats,
And he is gone to Prison here below this Street;
He wou'd not let me go with him i'faith,
But made me come tell thee now.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: O my heart—Tears by your leave a while— Wipes her eyes.
D' hear, Arbella, here, take all the trinkets, only the bait that
I'll use; accept of this House, here let me find thee, I'll try my
Skill; nay, talk not.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Careless in Prison! Pardon me, Madam, I must
Leave you for a little while; pray be confident,
This honest Friend of mine will use you with
All respects till I return.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What do you mean to do, Sir?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: I cannot tell, yet I must attempt something,
You shall have a sudden account of all things;
You say you dare believe,
Pray be as good as your word; and
Whatever accident befals me, know I love you dearly:
Why do you weep?

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Do not run your self into a needless danger.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: How, d'you weep for me? pray let me see, never Woman
Did so before, that I know of, I am ravish'd with it; the
Round gaping Earth ne'r suck'd showrs so greedily,
As my heart drinks these: Pray if you love me, be but
So good and kind as to confess it.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Do not ask what you may tell your self.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: I must go, Honour and Friendship call me: Here,
Dear Lieutenant, I never had a Jewel but this; use it as
Right ones shou'd be used; do not breath upon it, but
Gaze as I do,—hold—one word more; the Souldier that
You often talk'd of to me, is still honest.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Most perfectly.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: And I may trust him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: With your Life.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Enough,—pray let me leave my last looks fix'd
Upon you—So, I love you, and am honest; be careful,
Good Lieutenant, of this treasure—She weeps still—
I cannot go, I must—

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Madam, pray let my House be honoured with you;
Be consident of all respect and faith.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: What uncertainties pursue my Love and Fortune.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Come, give me the bundle, he now the habit;
'Tis well, there's for your pains, be secret, and wait
Where I appointed you.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: If I fail, may I dye in a Ditch, and there lie,
And out-stink it.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Now for my wild Colonel; first, here's a Note,
With my Lady Day's Seal to it, for his Release; if that fails
(As he that will shoot at these Rascals must have two Strings
To his Bow) Then here's my Red-Coats skin to disguise him,
And a string to draw up a Ladder of Cords, which I have
Prepared against it grows dark; one of them will hit sure,
I must have him out, and I must have him when he is out:
I have no patience to expect—within there—ho.—

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: You have not a Prisoner, Sir, in your Custody,
One Colonel Careless?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Yes, Mrs. and committed by your Father Mr. Day.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: I know it; but there was a mistake in it; here's a Warrant
For his Delivery, under his Hand and Seal.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I wou'd willingly obey it, Mrs; but there's a general
Order come from above, that all the Kings Party shou'd be kept
Close, and none releas'd but by the States Order.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: This goes ill; may I speak with him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Very freely, Mrs. there's no order to forbid any to come
To him: To say Truth, 'tis the most pleasant'st Gentleman.
—I'll call him forth.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: O'my conscience every thing must be in love with him;
Now for my last hopes; if this fail, I'll use the Ropes
My self.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Mr. Day's Daughter speak with me?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I, Sir, there 〈◊〉 is.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: O Sir, does the name of Mr. Day's Daughter
Trouble you; you love the Gentlewoman, but hate his Daughter.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Yes, • do love that Gentlewoman you speak of most
Exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: And the Gentlewoman loves you: but what luck
This is, that Day's Daughter shou'd ever be with her to spoil all!

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Not a whit one way; I have a pretty Room—
Within, dark, and convenient.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: For you and I to give Counter-security for
Our kindness to one another.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p:
But 〈…〉
Day's Daughter will be there too?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: 'Tis dark, we'll ne'er see her.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: You care not who you are Wicked with; methinks
A Prison shou'd tame you.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Why, d'you think a Prison takes away blood
And sight? As long as I am so qualified, I am Touch-wood, and
When ever you bring fire, I shall fall a burning.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: And you wou'd quench it.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: And you shall kindle it again.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: No, you will be burnt out at last, burnt to a coal,
Black as dishonest love.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Is this your business? Did you come to disturb my
Contemplations with a Sermon? Is this all?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: One thing more; I Love you, it's true; but I love you
Honestly, if you know how to love me vertuously, I'll free
You from Prison, and run all Fortunes with you.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Yes, I cou'd love thee all manner of ways;
If I cou'd not, freedom were no bait; were it from death.
I shou'd despise your offer to bargain for a lye.—but—

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Oh noble—but what?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: The Name of that Rascal that got thee: yet I lye
Too, he ne'er got a Limb of thee. Pox on't, thy Mother
Was as unlucky to bear thee: But how shall we salve that;
Take but off these incumbrances, and I'll purchase thee in
Thy Smock; but to have such a slaw in my Title.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Can I help Nature?

sp.speaker: C Car.
sp.l: Or I honour? Why, bark you now, do but swear
Me into a pretence, do but betray me with an Oath, that thou
Wert not begot on the Body of Gillian,
My Fathers Kitchen-maid.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Why, the honourable Mrs. Day that now is.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Will you believe me if I swear?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: I that I will, though I know all the while 'tis not true.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: I swear then by all that's good,
I am not their Daughter.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Poor kind Perjur'd pretty one, I am beholding
To thee; woud'st damn thy self for me?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: You are mistaken, I have try'd you fully;
You are noble, and I hope you love me; be ever fl • m to
Virtuous principles: My Name is not so godly 〈…〉 one

As Ruth, but plain Anne, and Daughter to Sir 〈…〉
Thorowgood,
One perhaps that you have heard of, since in the World he
Has still had so loud and fair a Character: 'tis too long to tell
You how this Day got me an Infant, and my ••• ate
Into his power, and made me pass for his 〈…〉 Daughter,
My Father dying when I was but two years 〈…〉 .
This I knew but lately, by an unexpected meeting of an ancient
Servant of my Fathers: but two hours since Arbella and I
Found an opportunity of stealing away all the Writings that
Belong'd to my Estate, and her Composition: 〈…〉 flight
We met your Friend, with whom I left heras soon as I had
Intelligence of your misfortune, to try to get your liberty;
Which if I can do, you have an Estate, for I have mine.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Thou more than—

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: No, no, no Raptures at this time; here'd our disguise
Purchas'd from a true hearted Red coat▪ here's a 〈…〉
Let this Line down when 'tis almost dark, and you shall draw
Up a Ladder of Ropes; if the Ladder of Ropes be done sooner,
I'le send them by a Souldier that I dare trust; and you may,
Your Window's large enough: As soon as you receive it
Come down; if not, when 'tis dusk, let down your line;
And at the bottom of the Window you shall find yours,
More than her own, not Ruth, but Anne.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: I'll leap into thy arms.—

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: So you may break your neck: If you do, I'll jump too;
But time steals on our Words; observe, all I have told you:
So farewell.—

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Nay, as the good Fellows use to say, Let us not part
With dry Lips.—One kiss.

sp.speaker: Ruth
sp.p: Not a bit of me, till I am all Yours.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Your hand then, to shew I am grown reasonable.
A poor Compounder.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Pish, there's a dirty Glove upon't.—

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Give me but any naked part, and I'll kiss it as a Snail
Creeps, and leave sign where my Lips • id along—

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Good Snail, get out 〈◊〉 your hole •• st, think of
Your business. So fare

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l:
Nay, preth • e he not▪
•• am'd that thou art loth
To leave me. 'S • id, I am a Man, but I'm as ar • ant a Rogue, as thy
Quondam Father Day, it I cou'd not cry to leave thee
A brace of Minutes.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Away, we grow foolish—farewel—yet be careful—
Nay, go in.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Do you go first.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Nay, sie, go in.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: We'll fairly then divide the Victory,
And draw off together.—So—I will have the last look.

div.stage: Exeunt severally, looking at one another.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: N 〈…〉 words; I do believe, nay, I know thou art
Honest I may 〈…〉 thank thee better.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: I scorn any encouragement to love my King, or those
That serve him. I took Pay under these People,
With a design to do him Service; the Lieutenant knows it.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: He has told me so, no more words, thou art a noble
Fellow; thou art sure his Window's large enough?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.p: Fear it not.

sp.speaker: C. Bl
sp.l: Here then, carry him this ladder of Ropes: So now give
Me the Coat; say not a word to him, but bid him dispatch
When he sees the Coast clear; he shall be waited for at
The bottom of his Window. Give him thy Sword too if
He desires it.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.p: I'll dispatch it instantly, therefore get to your place.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Have you done every thing then? By my shoul now,
Yonder is the Man with the hard name; that Man now, that I
Made drunk for thee, Mr. Tay's Rascal; he is coming along
There behind, now upon my Shoul that he is.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: The Rascal comes for some mischief. Teg, now, or
Never play the Man.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: How shou'd I be a Man then?

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Thy Master is never to be got out, if this Rogue
Gets hither; meet him therefore, Teg, in the most winning
Manner thou canst, and make him once more Drunk, and it
Shall be call'd the Second Edition of Obadiah, put forth
With Irish Notes upon him; and if he will not go drink with thee.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: I will carry him upon my back-side, if he will not go;
And if he will not be Drunk, I will cut his Throat then, that
I will, for my sweet Master now, that I will.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Dispatch good Teg, and dispatch him too if he will
Not be conformable; and if thou canst but once more
Be Victorious, bring him in Triumph to Lieutenant Story's,
There shall be the general Rendezvouz: Now or never, Teg.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: I warrant you, I will get drink into his Pate, or I will
Break it for him; that I will, I warrant you: He shall
Not come after you now.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Good luck go with thee: The Fellow's faithful and
Stout; that fear's over: Now to my station.

sp.speaker: C Car.
sp.l: The time's almost come, how slow it flutters?
My desires are better wing'd: how I long to counterfeit
A faintness when I come to the bottom, and sink into the arms
Of this dear witty fair!—Ha, who's this?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Here, Sir, here's a Ladder of Ropes, fasten it to your
Window, and descend: you shall be waited for.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: The careful her creature has sent it—but d'hear, Sir,
Cou'd you not spare that implement by your side; it might
Serve to keep off small Curs.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: You'l have no need on't, but there 'tis, make haste,
The coast is clear.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: O this pretty she Captain General over my Soul
And body; the thought of her musters every faculty I have:
She has sent the Ropes, and stays for me; no danger of the
Ropes, ever slide down with that swiftness (of desire of haste)
That I will make to thee.

div.stage: Enter Blunt in his Souldiers Coat.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: All's quiet, and the coast clear; so far it goes well;
That is the window, in this nook I'll stand, till I see him
Coming down.

div.stage: C. Careless above in his Souldiers habit, lets down the Ladder of Ropes and speaks.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: I cannot see my North Star that I must Sail by, 'tis
Clouded, only she stands close perhaps in some corner;
I'll not trifl time, all's clear; Fortune, forbear
Thy tricks, but for this small occasion.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: What's this, a Souldier in the place; Careless,
I am betray'd, but I'll end this Rascalls duty.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: How, a Souldier! betray'd! this Rascal shan't laugh at me.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Dog.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: How Blunt!

sp.speaker: C Bl.
sp.p: Careless!

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: You guess shrewdly; plague, what contrivance
Hath set you and I a Tilting at one another.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: How the Devil got you a Souldiers habit?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: The same Friend for ought I know, that furnish'd you.
This kind Gentlewoman is Ruth still. Ha, here she is;
I was just ready to be suspicious.

div.stage: Enter Ruth, with a Ladder of Ropes.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Two notable charging Red-coats.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: As I live, my heart is at my mouth.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Prethee, let it come to thy Lips, that I may kiss it;
What have you in your lap?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: The Ladder of Ropes: How a Gods name got you hither?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Why, I had the Ladder of Ropes, and came down by it.

sp.speaker: C Bl
sp.l: then the mistake is plainer; 'twas I that sent the
Souldier with the Ropes.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: What an Escape was this! come, let's lose no time;
Here's no place to explain Matters in.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: I will stay to tell thee, I shall never deserve thee.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Tell me so when you have had me a little while. Come▪
Follow me, put on your plainest Ga • b; not like a Dancing
Master, with your Toes out. Come along,
Hang down your head, Ruth pulls their Hats over their Eyes▪
As if you wanted pay. So.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Day, Mrs. Day, Abel, and Mrs. Chat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Are you sure of this, Neighbour Chat?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ch.
sp.p: I'm as sure of it, as I am that I have a Nose to my Face.

sp.speaker: Mrs Day.
sp.l: Is my—
You may give one leave methinks to ask out one question.
Is my Daughter Ruth with her?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ch.
sp.l: She was not when I saw Mrs. Arbella last; I have not
Been so often at your Honours House, but that I know
Mrs. Arbella, the rich Heir, that Mr. Abel was to have had,
Good Gentleman, if he has his due; they never suspected
Me for—to buy things of my Neighbour Story, before she
Married the Lieutenant; and stepping in to see Mrs. Story
That now is; my Neighbour Wish-well, that was; I saw, as
I told you, this very Mrs. Arbella, and I warrant Mrs. Ruth
Is not far off.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Let me advise then, Husband.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: Do, good Duck, I'll warrant 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: You'll warrant when I have done the business.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: I mean so, Duck.

sp.speaker: Mrs Day.
sp.l: Well, pray spare your meaning too; first then
We'll go our selves in person to this Story's House, and in the
Mean time send Abel for Souldiers; and when he has brought
The Souldiers, let them stay at the Door, and come up himself;
And then if fair means will not do, foul shall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Excellent well advised, sweet Duck:
Ah let thee alone. Be gone, Abel, and observe thy Mother's
Directions. Remember the place. We'll be reveng'd for
Robbing us, and for all their tricks.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: I shall perform it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Come along, Neighbour, and shew us the best way,
And by and by we shall have news from Obadiah, who is gone
To give the t'other Colonels Gaoler a double charge to keep
The wild Youth close. Come, Husband, let's hasten. Mrs. Chat,
The State shall know what good service you have done.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Chat.
sp.p: I thank your Honour.

sp.speaker: Lieu
sp.l: Pray, Madam, weep no more; spare your tears till
You know they have miscarried.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: 'Tis a Woman, Sir, that weeps; we want Mens reasons
And their courage to practise with.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: Look up, Madam, and meet your unexpected joys.

div.stage: Enter Ruth, C. Careless, C. Blunt.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: Oh my dear Friend, my dear, dear Ruth.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Pray none of these phlegmatick hugs; there, take
Your Colonel, my Captain and I can hug afresh every minute.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: When did we hug last, good Souldier?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: I have done nothing but hug'd thy infancy, ever since
You Ruth turn'd Annice.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: You are welcome, Sir, I cannot deny
I shar'd in all your danger.

sp.speaker: Lieu
sp.p: If she had deny'd it, Colonel, I would have betray'd her.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: I know not what to say, nor how to tell, how dearly,
How well—I love you.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Now can't I say I love him, yet I have
A mind to tell him too.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Keep't in and choak your self, or get the rising of the lights.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: What shall I say?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Say something, or he'll vanish.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: D'ye not believe I love you, or can't you love me?
Not a word? cou'd you—but—

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: No more, I'll save you the labour of Courtship, which
Shou'd be too tedious to all plain and honest natures:
It is enough, I know you love me.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: Or may I perish whilst I am swearing it.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.p: How now, Jack!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: O Master, undone! here's Mr. Day the Committee-man,
And his fierce Wife, come into the Shop: Mrs Chat
Brought them in, and they say they will come up, they know
That Mrs. Arbella, and their Daughter Ruth, is here:
Deny 'em if you dare, they say.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Go down, Boy, and tell 'em I'm coming to 'em; this pure
Jade, my Neighbour Chat, has betray'd us; what shall I do?
I warrant the Rascal has Souldiers at his heels: I think I
Cou'd help the Colonels out at a back Door.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: I'd dye rather by my Arbella; Now
You shall see I love you.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Nor will I Charles forsake you Annice.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Come, be chearful, I'll defend you all against
The assaults of Captain Day, and Major General Day, his
New drawn up Wife; give me my Ammunition, the Papers,
Woman. So, if I do not rout 'em, fall on; let's all dye together,
And make no more Graves but one.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.p: 'Slife, I love her now for all she has jeer'd me so.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Go fetch 'em in, Lieutenant, stand you all drawn up
As my reserve—so—I for the Forlorn Hope.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: That we had, Teg, here to quarrel with the Female
Triumphing Day, whilst I threw the Ma • e Day out of the Window.
Hark, I hear the Troop marching; I know the she Day stamp
Among the tramples of a Regiment.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: They come, Wench, charge 'em bravely,
I'll second thee with a Volley.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: They'll not stand the first charge, fear not;
Now the Day breaks.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Wou'd 'twere his Neck were broke.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Day, and Mrs. Day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Ah ha, my fine run-aways, have I found you?
What, you think my Husbands honour lives without intelligence.
Marry come up.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: My Duck tells you how 'tis—we—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Why then let your Duck tell 'em how 'tis;
Yet as I was saying, you shall perceive we abound in intelligence;
Else 'twere not for us to go about to keep the Nation
Quiet; but if you, Mrs. Arbella, will deliver up what you have
Stollen, and submit, and return with us, and this ungracious Ruth.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Anne, if you please.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Who gave you that Name pray?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: My God-Fathers and God-Mothers in Baptism; on, for
Sir, I can answer a Leaf farther.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Duck, good Duck, a word; I do not like this
Name Annice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: You are ever in a fright, with a shrivell'd heart
Of your own. Well, Gentlewomen, you are merry.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: As newly come out of our Wardships, I hope Mr. Abell is well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Yes, he is well, you shall see him presently;
Yes, you shall see him.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: That is with Mirmidans, come, good Anne, no more
Delay, fall on.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Then before the furious Abel approaches with his
Red-Coats, who perhaps are now marching under the Conduct
Of that expert Captain in weighty matters; know the Articles
Of our Treaty are only these: This Arbella will keep her
Estate, and not marry Abel, but this Gentleman; and I
Anne, Daughter to Sir Basil Thorowgood, and not Ruth,
As has been thought, have taken my own Estate,
Together with this Gentleman, for better for worse: we were
Modest, though Thieves, only plundred our own.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Yes, Gentlewoman, you took something else,
And that my Husband can prove; it may cost you your Necks
If you do not submit.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Truth on't is, we did take something else.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Oh, did you so?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Pray give me leave to speak one word in private
With my Father Day?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Do so, do so; are you going to compound?
Oh, 'tis Father Day now.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: D'hear, Sir, how long is't since you have practis'd Physick?

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: Physick, what d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: I mean Physick; look ye here's a small prescription
Of yours: d'ye know this hand-writing?

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Here's another upon the same subject; this young one I
Believe came into this wicked World for want of your preventing
Dose; it will not be taken now neither; it seems your Wenches
Are willful: nay, I do not wonder to see 'em have more
Conscience than you have.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: Peace, good Mrs. Anne, I am undone if you betray me.

div.stage: Enter Abel, goes to his Father.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: The Souldiers are come.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Go and send 'em away, Abel; here's no need,
No need now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: Are the Souldiers come, Abel?

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Yes, but my Father biddeth me send 'em away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: No, not without your opinion, Duck; but since
They have but their own, I think, Duck, if we were all Friends.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: O, are you at your ifs again; d'you think they
Shall make a Fool of me, though they make an Ass of you:
Call 'em up, Abel, if they will not submit;
Call up the Souldiers, Abel.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Why your fierce Honour shall know the business
That makes the wise Mr. Day inclinable to Friendship.

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.p: Nay, good sweet heart, come, I pray let us be Friends.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: How's this! what am not I • it to be trusted now?
Have you built your credit and reputation upon my council
And labours, and am not I • it now to be trusted?

sp.speaker: Mr. Day.
sp.l: Nay, good sweet Duck, I confess I owe
All to thy wisdom. Good Gentlemen, perswade my Duck
That we may be all Friends.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Hark you, good Gillian Day, be not so fierce upon
The Husband of thy Bosom; 'twas but a small start of frailty;
Say it were a Wench, or so?

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: As I live he has hit upon't by chance: now we
Shall have sport.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: How, a Wench, a Wench! out upon the Hypocrite.
A Wench! was not I sufficient? a Wench! I'll be reveng'd,
Let him be ashamed if he will: call the Souldiers, Abel.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Haste, good Abel, march not off so hastily.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.l: Soft, gentle Abel, or I'll discover, you are in Bonds;
You shall never be released if you move a step.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: D'hear, Mrs. Day, be not so furious, hold your peace;
You may divulge your Husbands shame if you are so simple,
And cast him out of Authority, nay and have him trv'd for
His Life: read this, remember too I know of your Bribery
And Cheating, and something else▪ you guess, be Friends,
And forgive one another; here's a Letter counterfeited
From the King, to bestow preferment upon Mr. Day, if
He would turn honest; by which means I suppose you
Cousened your Brother Cheats, in which he was to remember
His service to you; I believe 'twas your indicting: you are the
Committee-man, 'tis your best way: nay, never demur;
So, kiss and be Friends. Now if you can contrive handsomly
To cozen those that cozen all the World, and get these
Gentlemen to come by their Estates easily, and without
Taking the Covenant, the old Sum of five hundred pound
That I used to talk of, shall be yours yet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.p: We will endeavour.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.p: Come, Mrs. Arbella, pray let's all be Friends.

sp.speaker: Arb.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ruth.
sp.l: Brethren, Abel, the Bird is flown, but you shall be
Released from your Bonds.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: I bear my afflictions as I may.

div.stage: Enter Teg leading Obadiah in a Halter, and Musician.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: What is this now? who are you? well, are not you
Mrs. Tay? well, I will tell her what I should say now?
Shall I then? I will try if I cannot laugh too, as I did, that I will.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: No, good Teg, there's no need of thy Message now;
But why do'st thou lead Obadiah thus?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well, I will hang him presently, that I will; look you
Here Mrs Tay, here's your Man Obadiah, do you see that now?
He wou'd not let me make him drunk; no more that
He wou'd not; so, I did take him in this string, and I did tell
Him if he did make noises, I wou'd put the Knife into
Him, that I wou'd upon my Soul.

sp.speaker: C Bl.
sp.l: Honest Teg, thy Master is beholding to thee in some
Measure for his liberty.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.p: Teg, I shall require thy honesty.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well, shall I hang him then? It is a Rogue now; who
Wou'd not be drunk, that he wou'd not.

sp.speaker: Obad.
sp.l: I do beseech you, Gentlemen, let me not
Be brought unto death?

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: No, poor Teg, 'tis enough we are all Friends;
Come, let him go.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: Well, he shall go then; but you shall love the King,
Or I will hang you another time, that I will by my Soul. Well,
Look you here now, here is the Man that sung you the Song,
That he is; I met him as I came, and I bid him come hither
And sing for the King, that I did.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: D'hear, my Friends, is any of your
Companions with you?

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: As I live we'll all dance; it shall be the celebration
Of our Weddings: nay, Mr. Day, as we hope to continue
Friends, you and your Duck shall trip it too.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.l: I by my Soul will we; Obadiah shall be my Woman too;
And you shall dance for the King, that you shall.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: Go, and strike up then, no chiding now, Mrs. Day;
Come, you must not be refractory for once.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Day.
sp.l: Well, Husband, since these Gentlemen will have
It so, and that they may perceive we are Friends,
Dance.

sp.speaker: C. Bl.
sp.l: Now, Mr. Day, to your business, get it done as soon as
You will, the five hundred pound shall be ready.

sp.speaker: C. Car.
sp.l: So, Friends, thank honest Teg, thou shalt flourish
In a new Livery for this: Now, Mrs. Annice, I hope you and
I may agree about kissing, and compound every way.
Now, Mr. Day, if you will have good luck in every thing,
Turn Cavalier, and cry, God bless the King.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: BUT now the greatest thing is left to do,
More just Committee, to Compound with you;
For, till your equal Censures shall be known,
The Poet's under Sequestration:
He has no Title to his small Estate
Of Wit, unless you please to set the Rate.
Accept this half years purchace of his Wit,
For in the compass of that time 'twas Writ:
Not that this is enough, he'll pay you more,
If you your selves believe him not too poor:
For 'tis your judgments give him wealth, in this,
He's just as rich as you believe he is.
Wou'd all Committees cou'd have done like you,
Made Men more rich, and by their payments too.

div.p: THE Indian Queen, A TRAGEDY. Written by the Honourable Sir ROBERT HOWARD.
LONDON, Printed for Henry Herringman, and are to be Sold by R. Bentley, J. Tonson, F. Saunders, and T. Bennet. MDCXCII.

list.item: Garrucca, a faithful Subject to Amexia.
Ismeron, one of their Prophets, a Conjurer.
Amexia, the lawful Queen of Mexico.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.stage: As the Musick plays a soft Air, the Curtain rises softly, and discovers an Indian Boy and Girl sleeping under two Plantain-Trees; and when the Curtain is almost up, the Musick turns into a Tune expressing an Alarm, at which the Boy wakes and speaks.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: WAke, wake, Que • ira; our soft rest must cease,
And fly together with our Country's Peace;
No more must we sleep under Plantain shade,
Where bounteous Nature never feels decay,
And op'ning Buds drive falling Fruits away.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Why should men quarrel here, where all possess
As much as they can hope for by success?
None can have most, where Nature is so kind
As to exceed Man's Use, though not his Mind.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: By ancient Prophecies we have been told
Our World shall be subdu'd by one more old;
And see that World already's hither come.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: If these be they, we welcome then our Doom.
Their Looks are such, that Mercy flows from thence,
More gentle than our Native Innocence.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why should we then fear these are Enemies,
That rather seem to us like Deities?

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: By their protection let us beg to live;
They came not here to Conquer, but Forgive.
If so, your Goodness may your Pow'r express;
And we shall judge both best by our success.

div.head: ACT I.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Ynca, Orazia, Montezuma, Acasis, Prisoners, with Peruvians.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: THrice have the Mexicans before us fled,
Their Armies broke, their Prince in Triumph led;
Both to thy Valour, brave young Man, we owe;
Ask thy Reward, but such as it may show
It is a King thou hast oblig'd, whose Mind
Is large, and like his Fortune unconfin'd.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Young and a Stranger to your Court I came,
There by your Favour rais'd to what I am:
I Conquer, but in right of your great Fate,
And so your Arms, not mine, are Fortunate.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: I am impatient, till this Debt be paid,
Which still encreases on me while delay'd;
A Bounteous Monarch to himself is kind;
Ask such a Gift as may for ever bind
Thy service to my Empire, and to me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: What can this Gift he bids me ask him be!
Perhaps he has perceiv'd our mutual Fires,
And now with ours, wou'd crown his own Desires;
'Tis so, he sees my Service is above
All other payments but his Daughters Love.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: So quick to merit, and to take so slow?
I first prevent small wishes, and bestow
