This Prince, his Sword and Fortunes to thy hand;
He's thine unask'd; Now make thy free demand.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Here, Prince, receive this Sword, as only due Gives Acacis his Sword.
To that excess of Courage shown in you.
When you without demand, a Prince bestow,
Less than a Prince to ask of you, were low.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.p: Then ask a Kingdom; say where thou wilt Reign.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I beg not Empires, those my Sword can gain;
But for my past and future Service too,
What I have done, and what I mean to do;
For this of Mexico which I have won,
And Kingdoms I will Conquer yet unknown;
I only ask from fair Orazia's Eyes
To reap the Fruits of all my Victories.

sp.speaker: 1. Peru
sp.p: Our Ynca's Colour mounts into his Face.

sp.speaker: 2. Peru.
sp.p: His Looks speak Death.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Young Man of unknown Race,
Ask once again, so well thy Merits plead;
Thou shal't not Die for that which thou hast said:
The price of what thou ask'st, thou dost not know;
That Gift's too high.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: And all besides too low.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.p: Once more I bid thee ask.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Once more I make
The same demand.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: The Ynca bids thee take
Thy choice, what Towns, what Kingdoms thou wouldst have.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Thou giv'st me only what before I gave.
Give me thy Daughter.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Thou deserv'st to dye.
O thou great Author of our Progeny,
Thou glorious Sun, dost thou not blush to shine,
While such base Blood attempts to mix with thine!

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That Sun thou speakst of did not hide his face,
When he beheld me Conquering for his Race.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: My Fortunes gave thee thy success in Fight;
Convey thy boasted Valour from my sight;
I can o'recome without thy feeble aid.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: And is it thus, my Services are paid?
Not all his Guards—

div.stage: Offers to go, Acaces holds him.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: Hold, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Unhand me.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: No, I must your Rage prevent,
From doing what your Reason wou'd repent;
Like the vast Seas, your Mind no limits knows,
Like them lies open to each Wind that blows.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Can a Revenge that is so just be ill?

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: It is Orazia's Father you wou'd kill.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Orazia, how that name has charm'd my Sword?

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Compose these wild Distempers in your Breast;
Anger, like Madness, is appeas'd by Rest.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Bid Children sleep, my spirits boil too high;
But since Orazia's Father must not Dye,
A nobler Vengeance shall my Actions guide,
I'll bear the Conquest, to the conquered side,
Until this Ynca for my Friendship sues,
And proffers what his Pride does now refuse.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: Your Honour is oblig'd to keep your trust.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: He broke • hat Bond in ceasing to be just.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: Subjects to Kings shou'd more Obedience pay.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Subjects are bound, not Strangers, to obey.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Can you so little your Orazia prize,
To give the Conquest to her Enemies?
Can you so easily forego her sight?
I that hold Liberty more dear than Light:
Yet to my freedom, shou'd my chains prefer,
And think it were well lost to stay with her.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How unsuccessfully I still o'recome,
I brought a Rival, not a Captive home;
Yet I may be deceiv'd; but 'tis too late
To clear those doubts, my stay brings certain fate. Aside.
Come, Prince, you shall to Mexico return,
Where your sad Armies do your absence mourn;
And in one Battle I will gain you more
Than I have made you lose in three before.

sp.speaker: Aca
sp.l: No, Montezuma, though you change your side,
I as a Prisoner am by Honour ty'd.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You are my Prisoner, and I set you free.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: 'Twere baseness • o accept such Liberty.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: From him that Conquer'd you, it shou'd be fought.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: No, but from him, for whom my Conqueror fought.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Still you are mine, his Gift has made you so.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: He gave me to his General, not his Foe.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How poorly have you pleaded Honours Laws?
Yet shun the greatest in your Country's Cause.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: What succour can the Captive give the Free?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: A needless Captive is an Enemy,
In painted Honour you wou'd seem to shine;
But 'twou'd be clouded, were your wrongs like mine.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: When Choler such unbridled power can have,
Thy Vertue seems but thy revenge's Slave:
If such injustice shou'd my Honour stain,
My Aid wou'd prove my Nations loss, not gain.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Be cousend by thy guilty honesty,
To make thy self thy Countrey's Enemy.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: I do not mean in the next Fight to stain
My Sword in Blood of any Mexican,
But will be present in the fatal strife
To guard Orazia's, and the Ynca's Life.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Orazia's Life, fond Man: First guard thy own,
Her Safety she must owe to me alone.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Your Sword that does such Wonders, cannot be,
In an ill Cause, secure of Victory.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Hark, hark.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: What noise is this invades my ears?
Fly, Montezuma, fly; the Guards are near
To favour your Retreat: I'le freely pay
That Life, which you so frankly gave this day.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I must retire, but those that follow me,
Pursue their Deaths, and not their Victory.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Our Quarrels kinder, than our Friendships prove:
You for my Country Fight, I for your Love.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: I was to blame, to leave this mad Man free,
Perhaps he may revolt to th' Enemy,
Or stay, and raise some fatal Mutiny.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: Stop your Pursuits, for they must pass through me.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.p: Where is the slave?

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: Gon.—

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: O're the Plain.—
Where he may soon the Camp, or City gain.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Curse on my dull neglect—
And yet I do less cause of wonder find,
That he is gone, than that thou stayest behind.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: My treatment since you took me was so free,
It wanted but the name of liberty.
I with less shame can still your Captive live,
Than take that freedom which you did not give.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Thou brave young Man, that hast thy years out-done,
And losing Liberty hast Honour won:
I must my self thy Honour's Rival make,
And give that freedom which thou wou'dst not take.
Go and be safe.—

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: But that you may be so—
Your dangers must be past before I go.
Fierce Montezuma will for sight prepare,
And bend on you the fury of the War,
Which by my presence I will turn away,
If Fortune gives my Mexicans the Day.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Come then, we are alike to honour just,
Thou to be trusted thus, and I to trust.—

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: O my Acacis!
Does not my grief, Traxalla, seem too rude,
Thus to press out before my Gratitude
Has paid my debts to you?—yet it does move
My Rage and Grief, to see those Powers above
Punish such Men, as if they be Divine,
They know will most Adore, and least Repine.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Those that can only mourn when they are crost,
May lose themselves with grieving for the lost.
Rather to your retreated Troops appear,
And let them see a Woman void of fear:
The shame of that may call their Spirits home.
Were the Prince safe, we were not overcome,
Though we retir'd: O his too youthful heat,
That thrust him where the dangers were so great!
Heaven wanted power his Person to protect,
From that which he had Courage to neglect:
But since he's lost, let us draw forth, and pay
His Fun'ral Rites in Blood; that we are they
May in our Fates perform his Obsequies,
And make Death Triumph when Acacis dies.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: That Courage thou hast shown in Fight seems less
Than this, amidst Despair to have Excess:
Let thy great deeds force Fate to change her mind,
He that courts Fortune boldly makes her kind.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: If e'r Traxalla so successful proves,
May be then say he hopes as well as Loves;
And that aspiring Passion boldly own,
Which gave my Prince his Fate, and you his Throne?
I did not feel Remorse to see his Blood
• ow from the spring of life into a flood;
Nor did it look like Treason, since to me
You were a Sovereign much more great than he.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: He was my Brother, yet I scorn'd to pay
Nature's mean debts, but threw those Bonds away;
When his own Issue did my hopes remove,
Not only from his Empire, but his Love.
You that in all my wrongs then bore a part,
Now need not doubt a place within my heart:
I cou'd not offer you my Crown and Bed,
Till Fame and Envy with long time were dead;
But Fortune now does happily present
Occasions fit to second my intent.
Your Valour may regain the Publick Love,
And make the Peoples Choice their Queens approve. Shout.
Hark, hark, what noise is this that strikes my Ear!

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: 'Tis not a sound that should beget a fear;
Such Shouts as these have I heard often fly
From Conquering Armies crown'd with Victory.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Great God of Vengeance, here I firmly vow,
Make but my Mexicans successful now,
And with a thousand Feasts thy flames I'll feed;
All that I take shall on thy Altars bleed;
Princes themselves shall fall, and make thy Shrine,
Dy'd with their blood, in glorious blushes shine.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: How now!—
What News is this that makes thy haste a flight?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Such as brings Victory without a Fight;
The Prince Acaces lives.—

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: Oh, I am blest.—

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Reserve some joy till I have told the rest.
He's safe, and only wants his liberty;
But that great Man that carries Victory
Where e'er he goes; that mighty Man by whom
In three set Battels we were overcome;
Ill us'd (it seems) by his ungrateful King,
Does to our Camp his Fate and Valour bring.
The Troops gaze on him, as if some bright Star
Shot to their Aids, call him the God of War:
Whilst he, as if all Conquest did of right
Belong to him, bids them prepare to fight;
Which if they shou'd delay one hour, he swears
He'll leave them to their Dangers or their Fears,
And Shame (which is th' ignoble Cowards choice.)
At this the Army seem'd to have one Voice,
United in a shout, and call'd upon
The God-like Stranger, Lead us, lead us on.
Make haste, Great Sir, lest you should come too late,
To share with them in Victory or Fate.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: My Gen'ral go; the Gods be on our side;
Let Valour act, but let Discretion guide. Exit Traxalla.
Great God of Vengeance—
I see thou dost begin to hear me now;
Make me thy Off'ring if I break my Vow.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Ynca, Orazia, as pursued in a Battle.

sp.speaker: Orazia.
sp.l: O Fly, Sir, fly, like torrents your swift Foes
Come rowling on.—

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: The Gods can but destroy.
The noblest way to fly, is that death shows;
I'll court her now, since Victory's grown • oy.

sp.speaker: Oraz.
sp.l: Death's wing'd to your pursuit, and yet you wait
To meet her—

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Poor Orazia, time and fate
Must once o'ertake me▪ though I now shou'd fly.

sp.speaker: Oraz.
sp.p: Do not meet death; but when it comes then dye.

sp.speaker: 3. Sould.
sp.p: Stand, Sir, and yield your self, and that fair prey.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.p: You speak to one unpractis'd to obey.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Hold, Villains, hold, or your rude lives shall be
Lost in the midst of your own Victory:
These I have hunted for; nay do not stare,
Be gone, and in the common plunder share. Ex. Sould.
How different is my Fate, from theirs, whose Fame
From Conquest grows! from Conquest grows my shame.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Why do'st thou pause? thou canst not give me back
With fruitless grief, what I enjoyed before,
No more than Seas repenting of a Wrack,
Can with a calm our buried wealth restore.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: 'Twere vain to own repentance, since I know
Thy scorn, which did my passions once despise,
Once more would make my swelling anger flow;
Which now ebbs lower than your miseries:
The Gods that in my fortunes were unkind,
Gave me not Scepters, nor such gilded things;
But whilst I wanted Crowns; inlarg'd my mind
To despise Scepters, and dispose of Kings.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Thou art but grown a Rebel by success,
And I that scorn'd Orazia shou'd be ty'd
To thee my slave, must now esteem thee less:
Rebellion is a greater guilt than Pride.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Princes see others faults but not their own;
'Twas you that broke that Bond, and set me free:
Yet I attempted no • to climb your Throne,
And raise my self; but level you to me.

sp.speaker: Oraz.
sp.l: O Montezuma, cou'd thy love engage
Thy Soul so little, or make Banks so low
About thy heart, that thy revenge and rage,
Like suddain Floods, so soon shou'd over-flow!
Ye Gods, how much was I mistaken here!
But you as humoursome as Winds appear,
And subject to more Passions than your Love.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How have I been betray'd by guilty rage,
Which like a flame rose to so vast a height
That nothing cou'd resist, nor yet asswage,
Till it wrapt all things in one cruel fate,
But I'll redeem my self, and act such things,
That you shall blush Orazia was deny'd;
And yet make Conquest, though with wearied Wings,
Take a new flight to your now fainting side.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Vain Man, what foolish thoughts fill thy swell'd mind?
It is too late our ruine to recal;
Those that have once great Buildings undermin'd
Will prove too weak to prop them in their fall.

div.stage: Enter Traxalla with the former Souldiers.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.l: See, mighty Sir, where the bold stranger stands,
Who snatch'd these glorious Prisoners from our hands.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: 'Tis the great Ynca, seize him as my prey,
To crown the triumphs of this glorious day.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Stay your bold hands from reaching at what's mine,
If any title springs from Victory;
You safer may attempt to rob a shrine,
And hope forgiveness from the Deity.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: O my dear Prince, my Joys to see you live
Are more than all that Victory can give.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: How are my best endeavours crost by fate!
Else you had ne'er been lost, or found so late.
Hurried by the wild fury of the fight,
Far from your presence, and Orazia's sight,
I could not all that care and duty show,
Which as your Captive (mighty Prince) I owe.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: You often have preserv'd our lives this day,
And one small debt with many bounties pay.
But humane actions hang on springs that be
Too small, or too remote for us to see.
My glories freely I to yours resign,
And am your Prisoner now, that once were mine.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: These Prisoners, Sir, are mine by right of War;
And I'll maintain that right, if any dare.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Yes, I wou'd snatch them from thy weak defence;
But that due reverence which I owe my Prince,
Permits me not to quarrel in his sight,
To him I shall refer his General's right.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I knew too well what Iustice I shou'd find
From an arm'd Plaintiff, and a judge so kind.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Unkindly urg'd, that I shou'd use thee so;
Thy Vertue is my Rival, not my Foe;
The Prisoners Fortune gave thee shall be thine.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.p: Would you so great a prize to him resign?

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Shou'd he who boldly for his Prey design'd
To dive the deepest under swelling tides,
Have the less title if he chance to find▪
The richest • ewel that the Ocean hides?
They are his due—
But in his Vertue I re pose that trust,
That he will be as kind as I am just:
Dispute not my Commands, but go with haste,
Rally our Men, they may pursue too fast,
And the disorders of the inviting Prey
May turn again the fortune of the day.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How gentle all this Prince's actions be!
Vertue is calm in him, but rough in me.

sp.speaker: Aca
sp.p: Can Montezuma place me in his Breast?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: My heart's not large enough for such a Guest.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: See, Montezuma, see, Orazia weeps.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Acacis, is he deaf, or waking, sleeps?
He does not hear me, sees me not, nor moves;
How firm his Eyes are on Orazia fixt!
Gods that take care of Men, let not our loves
Become divided by their being mixt.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Weep not, fair Princess, nor believe you are
A Prisoner subject to the chance of War;
Why shou'd you waste the stock of those fair Eyes
That from Mankind can take their liberties?
And you, great Sir, think not a generous mind
To vertuous Princes, dares appear unkind,
Because those Princes are unfortunate,
Since over all Men hangs a doubtful fate:
One gains by what another is bereft;
The frugal Deities have only left
A common bank of happiness below,
Maintain'd like nature, by an ebb and flow.

div.stage: Zempoalla appears seated upon a Throne, frowning upon her Attendants▪ then comes down and speaks.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: No more, you that above your Princes dare proclaim
With your rebellious breath a stranger's name.

sp.speaker: 1. Peru.
sp.p: Dread Empress—

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Slaves, perhaps you grieve to see
Your young Prince glorious, 'cause he sprang from me;
Had he been one of base Amexia's brood,
Your Tongues, though silent now, had then been loud.

sp.speaker: Traxalla,
sp.l: welcome, welcomer to me,
Than what thou bring'st, a Crown and Victory.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: All I have done is nothing, fluttering Fame
Now tells no News, but of the Stranger's Name,
And his great Deeds; 'tis he they cry by whom
Not Men, but War it self is overcome;
Who bold with his success, dares think to have
A Prince to wear his Chains, and be his Slave.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: What Prince—

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: The great Peruvian Ynca, that of late
In three set Battles was so Fortunate,
Till this strange Man had power to turn the tide,
And carry Conquest unto any side.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Wou'd you permit a private Man to have
The great Peruvian Ynca for his Slave!
Shame to all Princes! was it not just now
I made a sacred, and a solemn Vow
To offer up (if blest with Victory)
The Prisoners that were took, and they shall dye.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: I soon had snatched from this proud stranger's hand
That too great object for his bold demand;
Had not the Prince your Son, to whom I owe
A kind obedience, judg'd it shou'd be so.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: I'll hear no more; go quickly take my Guards,
And from that Man force those usurpt rewards;
That Prince upon whose Ru •• es I must rise,
Shall be the Gods, but more my Sacrifice:
They with my Slaves in Triumph shall be tyed,
While my Devotion justifies my Pride.
Those Deities in whom I place my Trust,
Shall see when they are kind, that I am Just.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: How gladly I obey—
There's something shoots through my enliven'd Frame,
Like a new Soul, but yet without a Name:
Nor can I tell what the bold guest will prove,
It must be Envy, or it must be Love;
Let it be either, 'tis the greatest bliss
For Man to grant himself, all he dares wish;
For he that to himself, himself denies,
Proves meanly wretched, to be counted wise.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: You wrong me, my best friend, not to believe
Your kindness gives me joy, and when I grieve,
Unwillingly my Sorrows I obey,
Showres sometimes fall upon a shining day.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Let me then share your Griefs, that in your fate
Wou'd have took part—

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Why shou'd you ask me that?
Those must be mine, though I have such excess;
Divided Griefs increase, and not grow less.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: It does not lessen Fate, nor satisfie
The Grave, 'tis true, when Friends together dye;
〈…〉 et they are unwilling to divide.
To such a Friend nothing can be deny'd
You, when you hear my story will forgive
My grief, and rather wonder that I live.
Unhappy in my Title to a Throne,
Since Blood made way for my Succession:
Blood of an Uncle too, a Prince so free
From being Cruel, it taught Cruelty.
His Queen Amexia then was big with Child;
Nor was he •• ntler, than his Queen was mild:
Th' impatient people long'd for what shou'd come
From such a Father, bred in such a Womb—
When false Traxalla, weary to obey,
Took with his Life their joyes and hopes away.
Amexia by the assistance of the Night,
When this dark Deed was acted, took her flight;
Only with true Garrucca for her aid;
Since when, for all the searches that were made,
The Queen was never heard of more: yet still
This Traytor lives, and prospers by the ill:
Nor does my Mother seem • o reign alone,
But with this Monster shares the guilt and Throne:
Horror choaks up my words; now you'l beheve
'Tis just I shou'd do nothing else but grieve.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Excellent Prince.—
How great a proof of vertue have you shown,
To be concern'd for griefs, though not your own!

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: Pray say no more.—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: How now, whither so fast?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: O Sir, I come too slow with all my haste!
The fair Orazia—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Ha, what do'st thou say?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Orazia with the Ynca's forc'd away
Out of your Tent; Traxalla in the head
Of the rude Souldiers, forc'd the Door, and led
Those glorious Captives, who on Thrones once shin'd,
To grace the Triumph that is now design'd.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Orazia forc'd away! what tempests roul
About my thoughts, and toss my troubled Soul?
C • n there be Gods to see, and suffer this?
Or does Mankind make his own fate or bliss;
While every good and bad happens by chance,
Not from their orders, but their ignorance—
But I will pull a ruine on them all,
And turn their Triumph to a Funeral.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: Be temperate, Friend.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: You may as well advise
That I shou'd have less love, as grow more wise.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Yet stay—I did not think to have revealed
A secret which my heart has still concealed;
But in this cause since I must share with you,
'Tis sit you know—I love Orazia too:
Delay not then, nor wast the time in words,
Orazia's cause calls only for our Swords.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That tyes my hand, and turns from thee that rage
Another way; thy blood shou'd else asswage:
The •• orm on our proud Foes shall higher rise,
And changing, gather blackness as it flies:
So when Winds turn, the wandering Waves obey,
And all the Tempest rouls another way.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Draw then a Rivals Sword, as I draw mine,
And like Friends suddenly to part, let's join
In this one act, to seek one destiny;
Rivals with honour may together die.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Zempoalla appears seated upon her Slaves in Triumph, and the Indians as to celebrate the Victory, advance in a Warlike Dance; in the midst of which Triumph, Acacis and Montezuma fall in upon them.
Zempoalla descends from her Triumphant Throne, and Acacis and Montezuma are brought in before her.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: SHame of my blood, and Traytor to thy own,
Born to dishonour, not command a Throne;
Hast thou with envious Eyes my Triumph seen?
Or cou'dst not see thy Mother in the Queen?
Cou'dst thou a stranger above me prefer?

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: It was my Honour made my Duty err;
I cou'd not see his Prisoners forc'd away,
To whom I ow'd my Life, and you the day.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: Is that young Man the Warrior so renown'd?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Yes, he that made thy Men thrice quit their ground.
Do, smile at Montezuma's Chains; but know,
His Valour gave thee power to use him so.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Grant that it did, what can his merits be,
That sought his Vengeance, not our Victory?
What has thy bruitish fury gain'd us more,
Than only heal'd the wounds it gave before?
Dye then, for whilst thou liv'st, Wars cannot cease;
Thou may'st bring Victory, but never Peace.
Like a black storm thou roul'st about us all,
E'en to thy self unquiet till thy fall.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: Unthankful Villain, hold.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: You must not give
Him succour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Why then I must not live.
Posterity shall ne'er report they had
Such thankless Fathers, or a Prince so bad.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: You'r both too bold to will or to deny,
On me alone depends his destiny.
Tell me, audacious Stranger, whence cou'd rise
The confidence of this rash enterprize?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: First tell me how you dar'd to force from me
The fairest spoils of my own Victory?

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Kill him—hold, must he dye?—why let him dye;
Whence shou'd proceed this strange diversity
In my resolves?—
Does he command in Chains? what wou'd he do
Proud Slave, if he were free, and I were so?
But is he bound, ye Gods, or am I free?
'Tis love, 'tis love, that thus disorders me:
How Pride and Love tear my divided Soul!
For each too narrow, yet both claim it whole:
Love as the younger must be forc'd away;
Hence with the Captives (General) and convey
To several Prisons that—young Man, and this—
—Peruvian Woman—

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: How concern'd she is!
I must know more.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Fair Princess, why shou'd I
Involve that sweetness in my destiny?
I cou'd out-brave my death, were I alone
To suffer, but my fate must pull yours on.
My breast is armed against all sence of fear,
But where your Image lies, 'tis tender there.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Forbear thy saucy love, she cannot be
So low, but still she is too high for thee.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: Be gone, and do as I command, away.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I ne'er was truly wretched 'till this day▪

sp.speaker: Orazia.
sp.l: Think half your sorrows on Orazia fall,
And be not so unkind to suffer all:
Patience in Cowards is tame hopeless fear,
But in brave minds a scorn of what they bear.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: What grief is this which in your face appears?

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: The badge of sorrow, which my Soul still wears.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Though thy late actions did my • nger move,
It cannot rob thee of a Mother's love▪
Why shou'dst thou grieve?
Grief seldom join'd with blooming youth is seen,
Can sorrow be where knowledge so •• ce has been,
Fortune does well for heedless youth provide,
But Wisdom does unlucky age misguide▪
Cares are the train of present power and sta • e,

But hope lives best that on himself do • s wa ••
▪
O happiest Fortune if well •• derstood,
The certain prospect of a future good▪

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: What joy can Empire bring me when I know▪
That all my greatness to your crimes • owe?

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: Yours be the joy, be mine the punishment.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: In vain alas that wish to Heaven is sent
For me, if fair Orazia must not live.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Why shou'd you ask me what I cannot give?
She must be sacrific'd: Can I bestow
What to the Gods by 〈…〉 ?

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: O plead not Vows; I wish you had not shown
You slighted all things 〈◊〉 for a Th • o • e.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: I love thee so, that though fear follow still,
And horrour urges, all that have been 〈◊〉
I cou'd for thee—
Act o'r my crimes •• en, and not • ep • nt,
Even when I bore the shame and punishment▪

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Cou'd you so many ill acts undertake,

And not perform one good 〈◊〉
• or my sake?

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Prudence permits not pity 〈◊〉 be shown▪
To those that rais'd the War to shake my •• rone▪

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: As you are wise, permit 〈…〉 just▪
We owe our Conquest to 〈…〉 ,
'Tis just his Prisoners be to hi • restor'd▪
I love Orazia, but a nobler way—
Than for my Love my Honour to betray.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Honour is but an itch in youthful Blood,
Of doing Acts extravagantly good;
We call that Vertue, which is only Heat
That reigns in Youth, till Age finds out the cheat.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Great Actions first did her Affections move,
And I by greater, wou'd regain her love.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Urge not a Suit which I must still deny;
Orazia and her Father, both shall dye:
Be gone, I'll hear no more—

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: You stop your Ears—
But though a Mother will not, Heaven will hear;
Like you I vow, when to the Pow'rs Divine
You pay her guiltless Blood, I'll offer mine.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: She dies, this happy Rival that enjoys
The Stranger's love, and all my hopes destroys;
Had She triumph'd, what cou'd She more have done,
Than robb'd the Mother, and enslav'd the Son?
Nor will I at the name of Cruel stay,
Let dull successive Monarchs mildly sway:
Their Conquering Fathers did the Laws forsake,
And broke the Old, e're they the New cou'd make.
I must pursue my Love—yet Love enjoy'd,
Will with esteem that caus'd it first grow less;
But Thirst and Hunger fear not to be cloy'd,
And when they be, are cur'd by their Excess.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Now I shall see, what thoughts her Heart conceals;
For that which Wisdom covers, Love reveals.
Madam, the Prisoners are dispos'd.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: They are—
And how fares our Young blustering Man of War?
Does he support his Chains with patience yet?

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.p: He, and the Princess, Madam.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: Are they met?—

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.p: No, but from whence is all this Passion grown?

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: 'Twas a mistake.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: I find this rash Unknown
Is dangerous; and if not timely Slain,
May plunge your Empire in new Wars again.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: Thank ye, I shall consider.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Is that all?—
The Army doat on him, already call
You cruel; and for ought I know, they may
By force Unchain, and Crown him in a day.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: You say, I have already had their curse
For his bad usage; shou'd I use him worse?

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Yet once you fear'd his Reputation might
Obscure the Prince's in the People's sight.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Time will inform us best, what course to steer,
But let us not our Sacred Vows defer:
The Ynca, and his Daughter both shall Dye.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: He Suffers justly for the War; but why
Shou'd she share his sad fate? a poor pretence,
That birth shou'd make a crime of innocence.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Yet we destroy the poisonous Vipers young,
Not for themselves, but those from whom they sprung.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: O no, they die not for their Parents sake,
But for the poisonous seed which they partake;
Once more behold her, and then let her dye,
If in that face or person you can see
But any place to fix a Cruelty:
The Heavens have Clouds, and spots are in the Moon;
But faultless Beauty shines in her alone.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: Beauty has wrought compassion in your mind.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: And you to Valour are become as kind.
To former services there's something due.
Yet be advised—

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: Yes by my self, not you—

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.p: Princes are sacred.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: True, whilst they are free;
But power once lost, farewell their sanctity:
'Tis power to which the Gods their worship owe,
Which, uncontroul'd, makes all things just below:
Thou do'st the Plea of saucy Rebels use,
They will be judge of what their Prince must chuse:
Hard fate of Monarchs, not allow'd to know
When safe, but as their Subjects tell them so.
Then Princes but like publick Pageants move,
And seem to sway because they sit above.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: She loves him; in one moment this new Guest
Has drove me out from this false Womans Breast;
They that wou'd fetter Love with Constancy,
Make Bonds to Chain themselves, but leave him free.
With what impatience I her fallhood bear!
Yet do my self that which I blame in her;
But Interest in my own Cause makes me see
That Act unjust in her, but just in me.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Ho, Ismeron, Ismeron.
He stirs not; ha, in such a dismal Cell
Can gentle Sleep with his soft blessings dwell?
Must I feel tortures in a humane Breast,
While Beasts and Monsters can enjoy their Rest?
What quiet they possess in sleeps calm bliss!
The Lions cease to roar, the Snakes to hiss,
While I am kept awake—
Only to entertain my Miseries.
Or if a slumber steal upon my Eyes,
Some horrid Dream my lab'ring Soul benums,
And brings Fate to me sooner than it comes.
Fears most oppress when sleep has seiz'd upon
The outward parts, and left the Soul alone.
What envy'd blessing's these curs'd things enjoy!
Next to possess, 'tis pleasure to destroy.
Ismeron; ho Ismeron, Ismeron.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Who's that with so loud and fierce a call
Disturbs my rest?

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: She that has none at all,
Nor ever must, unless thy powerful Art
Can charm the Passions of a troubled heart.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: How can you have a discontented mind,
To whom the Gods have lately been so kind?

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Their envious kindness how can I enjoy,
When they give Blessings, and the use destroy?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Dread Empress, tell the cause of all your grief▪
If Art can help, be sure of quick Relief.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: I dream'd before the Altar that I led
A mighty Lion in a twisted thread;
I shook to hold him in so slight a tie,
Yet had not power to seek a remedy:
When in the midst of all my fears a Dove,
With hovering Wings, descended from above,
Flew to the Lion, and Embraces spread,
With Wings, like clasping Arms, about his head,
Making that murm'ring noise that cooing Doves
Use in the soft expression of their Loves.
While I, fix'd by my wonder, gaz'd to see
So mild a Creature with so fierce agree,
At last the gentle Dove turn'd from his head,
And pecking try'd to break the slender thread,
Which instantly she sever'd, and releas'd
From that small bond the fierce and mighty Beast,
Who presently turn'd all his rage on me,
And with his Freedom brought my Destiny.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Dread Empress, this strange Vision you relate
Is big with wonder, and too full of fate
Without the Gods assistance to expound.
In those low Regions where sad Night hangs round
The drowsie Vaults, and where moist Vapors steep
The God's dull brows that sways the Realm of Sleep;
There all th' informing Elements repair,
Swift Messengers of Water, Fire, and Air,
To give account of Actions whence they came,
And how they govern every mortal frame;
How from their various mixture, or their strife,
Are known the Calms and Tempests of our Life:
Thence Souls, when Sleep their Bodies overcome,
Have some imperfect knowledge of their doom.
From those dark Caves those Powers shall strait appear;
Be not afraid whatever shapes they wear.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: There's nothing thou canst raise can make me start;
A living form can only shake my heart.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: You twice Ten Hundred Dei • ies,
To whom we daily sacrifice;
You Powers that dwell with Fate below,
And see what men are doom'd to do;
Where Elements in discord dwell;
Thou God of Sleep, arise and tell
Great Zempoalla what strange Fate
Must on her dismal Vision wait.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: How slow these Spirits are! Call, make them rise,
Or they shall fast from Flame and Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Great Empress—
Let not your rage offend what we adore,
And vainly threaten, when we must implore.
Sit and silently attend,—
While my powerful Charms I end.
By the creaking of the Toad,
In their Caves that make aboad,
Earthy Dun that pants for breath,
With her swell'd sides full of death;
By the Crested Adders Pride
That along the Clifts do glide▪
By thy visage fierce and black;
By the Deaths-head on thy back;
By the twisted Serpents plac'd
For a Girdle round thy Waste.
By the Hearts of Gold that d • ck
Thy Brest, thy Shoulders, and thy Neck:
From thy sleepy Mansion rise,
And open thy unwilling Eyes,
While bubling Springs their Musick keep,
That use to lull thee in thy sleep.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Seek not to know what must not be reveal'd;
Joys only flow where Fate is most conceal'd:
Too busie Man wou'd find his Sorrows more,
If future Fortunes he shou'd know before▪
For by that knowledge of his Destiny
He wou'd not live at all, but always die.
Enquire not then who shall from Bonds be freed,
Who 'tis shall wear a Crown, and who shall bleed:
All must submit to their appointed doom;
Fate and Misfortune will too quickly come:
Let me no more with powerful Charms be prest,
I am forbid by Fate to tell the rest.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Stay Couz'ner, thou that hat'st clear truth like light,
And usest words dark as thy own dull night.
You Tyrants Gods do you refuse to free
The Soul you gave from its perplexity?
Why shou'd we in your mercies still believe,
When you can never pity though we grieve?
For you have bound your selves by harsh decrees;
And those, not you, are now the Deities.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: She droops under the weight of Rage and Care:
You Spirits that inhabit in the Air,
With all your powerful Charms of Musick try
To bring her Soul back to its Harmony.

lg.head: SONG is suppos'd sung by Aerial Spirits.
lg.l: POor Mortals that are clog'd with Earth below
Sink under Love and Care,
While we that dwell in Air
Such heavy Passions never know.
Why then should Mortals be
Unwilling to be free
From Blood, that sullen Cloud,
Which shining Souls does shroud?
Then they'l shew bright,
And like us light,
When leaving Bodies with their Care,
They slide to us and Air.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Death on these Trifles: Cannot your Art find
Some means to ease the Passions of the Mind?
Or if you cannot give a Lover rest,
Can you force Love into a Scornful Breast?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: 'Tis Reason only can make Passions less;
Art gives not new, but may the old encrease;
Nor can it alter Love in any Breast
That is with other flames before possess'd.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: If this be all your slighted Art can do,
I'll be a Fate both to your Gods and you;
I'll kindle other Flames, since I must burn,
And all their Temples into ashes turn.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Great Queen.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: If you wou'd have this Sentence staid,
Summon their Godheads quickly to your aid,
And presently compose a Charm that may
Loves flames into the Strangers Breast convey,
The Captive Stranger, he whose Sword and Eyes
Where e'er they strike meet ready Victories:
Make him but burn for me in flames like mine,
Victims shall bleed, and feasted Altars shine:
If not—
Down go your Temples, and your Gods shall see
They have small use of their Divinity.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I.
div.stage: The Scene opens and discovers Montezuma sleeping in Prison.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: NOW take your choice, and bid him live or die;
To both shew Pity, or shew Cruelty:
'Tis you that must condemn, I'll only act;
Your Sentence is more cruel than my Fact.

sp.speaker: Oraz.
sp.l: You are most cruel to disturb a mind
Which to approaching Fate was so resign'd.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Reward my Passions, and you'll quickly prove
There's none dare sacrifice what I dare love
Next to thee, Stranger, wake, and now resign
The bold pretences of thy Love to mine,
Or in this fatal minute thou shalt find—

sp.speaker: Mont▪
sp.l: Death, Fool; in that thou maist be just and kind:
'Twas I that lov'd Orazia, yet did raise
The storm in which she sinks: why dost thou gaze,
Or stay thy hand from giving that just stroke,
Which rather than prevent, I wou'd provoke?
When I am dead, Orazia may forgive;
She never must, if I dare wish to live.

sp.speaker: Oraz.
sp.l: Hold, hold—O Montezuma, can you be
So careless of your self, but more of me?
Though you have brought me to this misery,
I blush to say I cannot see you die.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Can my approaching Fate such pity move?
The Gods and you at once forgive and love.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Fond Fool, thus to mispend that little breath
I lent thee to prevent, not hasten Death:
Let her thank you she was unfortunate,
And you thank her for pulling on your fate;
Prove to each other your own Destinies.

div.stage: Enter Zempoalla hastily, and sets a Dagger to Orazia's Breast.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Hold, hold, Traxalla, or Orazia dies.
O, is't Orazia's Name that makes you stay?
'Tis her great Power, not mine, that you obey.
Inhumane Wretch, dar'st thou the Murtherer be
Of him that is not yet Condemn'd by me?

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: The Wretch that gave you all the pow'r you have,
May venture sure to execute a Slave;
And quench a flame your fondness would have burn,
Which may this City into ashes turn.
The Nation in your guilty Passion lost,
To me ungrateful, to your Country most:
But this shall be their Offering, I their Priest.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: The wounds thou giv'st I'll copy on her Breast.
Strike, and I'll open here a spring of blood,
Shall add new Rivers to the crimson flood.
How his pale looks are fix'd on her!—'tis so.
Oh, does amazement on your spirit grow?
What, is your publick Love Orazia's grown?
Cou'dst thou see mine, and yet not hide thy own?
Suppose I shou'd strike first, wou'd it not breed
Grief in your publick heart to see her bleed?

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: She mocks my passions, in her sparkling eyes
Death and a close dissembled fury lies:
I dare not trust her thus.—If she must die,
The way to her lov'd Life through mine shall lie.

div.stage: He puts her by and steps before Orazia, and she runs before Montezuma.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: And he that does this Stranger's fate design,
Must to his heart a passage force through mine.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Can fair Orazia yet no pity have?
'Tis just she shou'd her own Preserver save.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Can Montezuma so ungrateful prove
To her that gave him Life, and offers Love?

sp.speaker: Oraz.
sp.l: Can Montezuma live, and live to be
Just to another, and unjust to me?
You need not be ungrateful; can she give
A Life to you, if you refuse to live?
Forgive me Passion, I had rather see
You dead, than kind to any thing but me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: O my Orazia!
To what new joys and knowledge am I brought!
Are deaths hard lessons by a Woman taught?
How to despise my Fate I always knew;
But ne'er d • rst think at once of death and you:
Yet since you teach this generous jealousie,
I dare not wish your Life, if I must die.
How much your Love my Courage does exceed!
Courage alone would shrink to see you bleed.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Ungrateful Stranger, thou shalt please thy Eyes,
And gaze upon Orazia while she dies.
I'll keep my Vow:—It is some joy to see
That my Revenge will prove my Piety.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Then both shall die; we have too long withstood,
By private Passions urg'd, the publick good.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Sure he dissembles, and perhaps may prove
My ruine with his new ambitious Love:
Were but this Stranger kind, I'd cross his Art,
And give my Empire where I gave my heart. Aside.
Yet thou ungrateful Man,
Let thy approaching ruine make thee wise.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Thee and thy Love and Mischief I despise.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: What shall I do?—some way must yet be try'd.
What Reasons can she use whom Passions guide?

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Some black designs are hatching now; false Eyes
Are quick to see anothers Treacheries.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: Rash Stranger, thus to pull down thy own fate.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You, and that Life you offer me, I hate.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Here Jaylor,—take—what title must he have?
Slave—Slave—Am I then Captive to a Slave!
Why art thou thus unwilling to be free?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Death will release me from these Chains and thee.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Here, Jaylor, take this Monster from my sight,
And keep him where it may be always night;
Let none come near him; if thou dost, expect
To pay thy Life the price of the Neglect.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I scorn thy Pity and thy Cruelty,
And shou'd despise a Blessing sent from thee.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Oh horror to my Soul! take him away;
My Rage like dam'd up Streams swell'd by some stay
Shall from this opposition get new force,
And leave the bound of its old easie course.
Come, my Traxalla, let us both forgive,
And in these Wretches Fates begin to live.
The Altars shall be crown'd with Fun'ral Boughs,
Peace-offrings pay'd, but with unquiet Vows.

sp.speaker: Oraz.
sp.l: How are things ordered, that the wicked shou'd
Appear more kind and gentle than the good!
Her Passion seems to make her kinder prove,
And I seem cruel through excess of Love:
She loves, and wou'd prevent his Death; but I
That love him better, fear he shou'd not die.
My Jealousie, immortal as my Love,
Wou'd rob my Grave below, and me above,
Of Rest.—Ye Gods, if I repine, forgive;
You neither let me die in Peace, nor live.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: They are just gone, Sir.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: 'Tis well: be faithful to my just design,
And all thy Prince's Fortune shall be thine.

sp.speaker: Indian.
sp.p: This shall to the Empress.

sp.speaker: Oraz.
sp.l: What can this mean!—
'Twas Prince Acacis, if I durst believe
My sight; but Sorrow may like Joy deceive:
Each object different from it self appears,
That comes not to the Eyes but through their Tears.

div.p: Ha!—

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Here, Sir, wear this again;
Now follow me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So, very good;—
I dare not think, for I may guess amiss;
None can deceive me while I trust to this.

div.stage: Enter Orazia, conducted by two Indians with their Swords drawn: Montezuma, Acacis, whispering another Indian.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: Think what a weight upon thy Faith I lay.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.p: I ne'er did more unwillingly obey.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: First, Montezuma, take thy liberty;
Thou gav'st me freedom, here I set thee free;
We're equal now. Madam, the danger's great
Of close pursuit; to favour your Retreat
Permit we two a little while remain
Behind, while you go softly o'er the Plain.

sp.speaker: Oraz.
sp.l: Why shou'd I go before? what's your intent?
Where is my Father? whither am I sent?

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Your doubts shall soon be clear'd. Conduct heron. Exit Orazia▪
So, Montezuma, we are now alone:
That which my Honour ow'd thee I have paid;
As Honour was, so Love must be obey'd.
I set Orazia as thy Captive free,
But as my Mistress ask her back from thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Thou hast perform'd what Honour bid thee do;
But Friendship bars what Honour prompts me to.
Friends shou'd not fight.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: If Friendship we profess,
Let us secure each others happiness;
One needs must die, and he shall happy prove
In her Remembrance, t'other in her Love.
My Guards wait near, and if I fail they must
Give up Orazia, or betray their trust.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Suppose thou conquer'st, wou'dst thou wander o'er
The South-Sea Sands, or the rough Northern Shore,
That parts thy spacious Kingdom from Peru;
And leaving Empire, hopeless Love pursue?

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: By which of all my actions cou'd you guess,
Though more your Merit, that my Love was less?
What prize can Empire with Orazia bear?
Or where Love fills the Breast, what room for fear?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Let fair Orazia then the Sentence give,
Else he may die whom she desires to live.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Your greater merits bribe her to your side;
My weaker Title must by Arms be try'd.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Oh Tyrant Love, how cruel are thy Laws!
I forfeit Friendship, or betray thy Cause.
That Person whom I wou'd defend from all
The World, that Person by my hand must fall.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Our Lives we to each others Friendships owe;
But Love calls back what Friendship did bestow:
Love has its Cruelties, but Friendship none;
And we now sight in Quarrels not our own.

sp.speaker: Oraz.
sp.l: What noise is this?—
Hold, hold; what cause cou'd be so great to move
This furious hatred?—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: 'Twas our surious Love.—

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Love which I hid till I had set you free,
And bought your pardon with my liberty:
That done, I thought I less unjustly might
With Montezuma for Orazia fight;
He has prevail'd, and I must now confess
His Fortune greater, not my Passion less;
Yet cannot yield ye till his Sword remove,
A dying Rival that holds fast his Love.

sp.speaker: Orazia.
sp.l: Who ever falls, 'tis my Protector still,
And then the crime's as great to dye as kill.
Acacis, do not hopeless love pursue,
But live, and this soft malady subdue.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: You bid me live, and yet command me dye,
I am not worth your care, fly, Madam, fly,
While I fall here unpittied, o'er this Plain,
Free from pursuit, the faithless Mountains gain;
And these I charge as they wou'd have me think their Friendship true.
Leave me alone to serve and follow you:
Make haste, fair Princess, to avoid that fate,
Which does for your unhappy Father wait.

sp.speaker: Orazia.
sp.l: Is he then left to dye, and shall he see
Himself forsaken, e'er his death, by me?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: What wou'd you do.—

sp.speaker: Orazia.
sp.l: To Prison I'll return,
And there in Fetters with my Father mourn.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: That saves no • his, but throws your Life away.

sp.speaker: Orazia.
sp.p: Duty shall give what nature once must pay.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Life is the gift, which Heaven and Parents give,
And duty best preserves it, if you live.

sp.speaker: Orazia.
sp.l: I shou'd but further from my Fountain fly,
And like an unfed stream run on and dye:
Urge me no more, and do not grieve to see
Your Honour rival'd by my Piety.

div.stage: Exit. She goes softly off, and often looks back.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: If Honour wou'd not, shame wou'd lead the way.
I'll back with her.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Stay, Montezuma, stay—
Thy Rival cannot let thee go alone,
My love will bear me, though my blood is gone.

div.stage: Enter Zempoalla, Traxalla, the Indian that went to tell her, and the rest, and seizes them.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: Seize them—

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: Oh, Montezuma, thou art lost.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: No more, proud heart, thy useless Courage boast.
Courage thou curse of the unfortunate,
That canst encounter, not resist ill fate.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Acacis bleeds.—
What barbarous hand has wounded thus my Son?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: 'Twas I, by my unhappy Sword 'twas done.
Thou bleed'st, poor Prince, and I am left to grieve
My Rival's fall.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.p: He bleeds, but yet may live.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Friendship and love my failing strength renew,
I dare not dye when I shou'd live for you;
My death were now my crime, as it wou'd be
My guilt to live when I have set you free:
Thus I must still remain unfortunate,
Your Life and Death are equally my fate.

sp.speaker: Orazia.
sp.l: A noise again, alas what do I see!
Love thou didst once give place to Piety:
Now Piety, let Love triumph awhile;
Here bind my hands: come, Montezuma, smile
At Fortune, since thou sufferest for my sake,
Orazia will her Captive's Chains partake.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Now, Fate, thy worst.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Lead to the Temple straight,
A Priest, and Altar for these Lovers wait:
They shall be join'd, they shall.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: And I will prove—
Those joys in Vengeance which I want in Love.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: I'll quench your thirst with Blood, and will destroy
My self, and with my self, your cruel joy.
Now, Montezuma, since Orazia dyes,
I'll fall before thee, the first Sacrifice;
My title in her death shall exceed thine,
As much as in her life, thy hopes did mine:
And when with our mixt blood the Altar's dy'd,
Then our new Title let the Gods decide.

div.head: ACT V.
SCENE I.
div.stage: The Scene opens, and discovers the Temple of the Sun all of Gold, and four Priests in habits of white and red Feathers, attending by a bloody Altar, as ready for Sacrifice.
Then Enter the Guards, and Zempoalla, and Traxalla; Ynca, Orazia, and Montezuma bound; as soon as they are plac'd, the Priest sings.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: YOU to whom Victory we owe,
Whose glories rise
By Sacrifice,
And from our fates below;
Never did yet your Altars shine
Feasted with Blood so near divine;
Princes to whom we bow,
As they to you,
Thus you can ravish from a Throne,
And by their loss of power declare your own.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: NOW to inflict those punishments that are
Due to the Authors of invasive War;
Who to deceive the oppressed World, like you,
Invent false quarrels to conceal the true.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: My quarrel was the same that all the Gods
Must have to thee, if there be any odds
Betwixt those Titles that are bad or good,
To Crowns descended, or usurpt by Blood:
Swell not with this success, 'twas not to thee,
But to this Man the Gods gave Victory.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Since I must perish by my own success,
Think my misfortunes more, my Crimes the less;
And so forgiving make me pleas'd to dye,
Thus punish'd for this guilty Victory.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Death can make Vertue easie; I forgive:
That word wou'd prove too hard were I to live;
The Honour of a Prince wou'd then deny,
But in the Grave all our distinctions dye.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Forgive me one thing yet; to say I love,
Let it no more your scorn or anger move,
Since dying in one flame, my ashes must
Embrace and mingle with Orazia's dust.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Name thy bold love no more, lest that last breath
Which shou'd forgive, I stisle with my death.

sp.speaker: Orazia.
sp.l: Oh my dear Father! Oh, why may not I,
Since you gave Life to me, for you now dye?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: 'Tis I that wrought this mischief ought to fall;
A just and willing sacrifice for all.
Now, Zempoalla, be both just and kind,
And in my fate let me thy mercy find:
Be grateful then, and grant me that esteem,
That as I live, so dead I may redeem.

sp.speaker: Oraz.
sp.l: O do not for her cruel mercy move;
None shou'd ask pity but from those they love.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Fond Girl, to let thy disobedient Eyes
Show a concern for him whom I despise.

sp.speaker: Orazia.
sp.l: How love and nature may divide a Breast,
At once by both their Pow'rs severely prest!
Yet, Sir, since love seems less, you may forgive,
I wou'd not have you dye, nor have him live;
Yet if he dies, alas what shall I do?
I cannot dye with him, and live with you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How vainly we pursue this generous strife,
Parting in death more cruel than in life!
Weep not, we both shall have one destiny,
As in one flame we liv'd, in one we'll dye.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Why do we waste in vain these precious hours?
Each minute of his Life may hazard ours:
The Nation does not live whilst he enjoys
His life, it is his safety that destroys.
He shall fall first, and teach the rest to dye.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Hold—
Who is it that commands—ha, you or I?
Your Zeal grows saucy; sure you may allow
Your Empress freedom first to pay her Vow.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: She may allow—a justice to be done
By him that rais'd his Empress to her Throne.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: You are too bold—

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.p: And you too passionate.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Take heed with his, you urge not your own fate.
For all this pity is now due to me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I hate thy offer'd mercy more than thee.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Why will not then the fair Orazia give
Life to her self, and let Traxalla live?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Orazia will not live, and let me dye;
She taught me first this cruel jealousie.

sp.speaker: Orazia.
sp.l: I joy that you have learn'd it—
That flame not like immortal love appears
Where death can cool its warmth, or kill its fears.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: What shall I do? am I so quite forlorn,
No help from my own pride, nor from his scorn!
My Rival's death may more effectual prove,
He that is robb'd of hope, may cease to love:
Here, lead these Offerings to their deaths.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Let none—
Obey, but he that will pull on his own.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: Tempt me not thus, false and ingrateful too.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.p: Just as ungrateful, and as false as you.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: 'Tis thy false love that fears her destiny.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.p: And your false love that fears to have him dye.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.p: Seize the bold Traytor.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: What a slighted frown▪
Troubles your brow? feared nor obeyed by none;
Come prepare for Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Hold, hold, such Sacrifices cannot be▪
Devotion's but a solemn Cruelty:
How can the Gods delight in humane Blood?
Think 'em not cruel; if you think 'em good.
In vain we ask that mercy, which they want,
And hope that pity, which they hate to grant.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Retire, Acacis—
Preserve thy self, for 'tis in vain to waste
Thy breath for them: The fatal Vow is past.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: To break that Vow is juster than commit
A greater Crime, by your preserving it.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: The Gods themselves their own will best express
To like the Vow, by giving the Success.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: If all things by Success, are understood,
Men that make War, grow wicked to be good:
But did you Vow, those that were overcome,
And he that Conquer'd both, shou'd share one Doom?
There's no excuse; for one of these must be
Not your Devotion, but your Cruelty.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: To that rash Stranger, Sir, we nothing owe,
What he had rais'd, he strove to overthrow:
That duty lost, which shou'd our Actions guide,
Courage proves Guilt, when Merits swell to Pride.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: Dar'st thou, who didst thy Prince's Life betray,
Once name that Duty, thou hast thrown away:
Like thy Injustice to this Stranger shown,
To tax him with a Guilt, that is thy own?—
Can you, brave Soldiers, suffer him to Dye,
That gave you Life, in giving Victory?
Look but upon this Stranger, see those Hands,
That brought you Freedom, fetter'd up in Bands.
Not one looks up—
Lest suddain pitty shou'd their Hearts surprize,
And steal into their Bosoms, through their Eyes.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Why thus in vain, are thy weak Spirits prest?
Restore thy self, to thy more needful Rest.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: And leave Orazia—

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Go, you must resign—
For, She must be the Gods; not Yours, nor Mine.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: You are my Mother, and my Tongue is ty'd
So much by Duty, that I dare not chide.
Divine Orazia—
Can you have so much Mercy to forgive?
I do not ask it, with design to Live,
But in my Death, to have my Torments cease:
Death is not Death, when it can bring no Peace▪

sp.speaker: Orazia.
sp.p: I both Forgive, and Pity—

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: O say no more, lest Words less kind destroy,
What these have rais'd in me of Peace and Joy;
You said, you did both Pity, and Forgive;
You wou'd do neither, shou'd Acacis live.
By Death alone, the certain way appears,
Thus to hope Mercy, and deserve your Tears.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: O my Acacis!—
What cruel Cause cou'd urge this fatal Deed Weeps▪
He Faints, help, help, some help, or he will Bleed,
His Life and mine away:
Some Water there—Not one stirs from his Place;
I'll use my Tears, to sprinkle on his Face.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.p: Crazia.—

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Fond Child, why do'st thou call upon her name?
I am thy Mother.

sp.speaker: Aca.
sp.l: No, you are my shame,
That blood is shed that you had title in,
And with your title may it end your sin:
Unhappy Prince, you may forgive me now,
Thus bleeding for my Mothers cruel vow.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: Be not concern'd for me—
Death's easier than the changes I have seen,
I wou'd not live to trust the World again.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Into my Eyes sorrow begins to creep,
When hands are ty'd it is no shame to weep.

sp.speaker: Aca▪
sp.l: Dear Montezuma.
I may be still your Friend, though I must dye
Your Rival in her love; Eternity
Has room enough for both, there's no desire,
Where to enjoy is only to admire:
There we'll meet Friends, when this short storm is past.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why must I tamely wait to perish last?

sp.speaker: Aca▪
sp.l: Crazia weeps, and my parch'd Soul appears
Refresh'd by that kind shower of pitying tears;
Forgive those faults my passion did commit,
'Tis punish'd with the life that nourish'd it:
I had no power in this extremity
To save your life, and less to see you dye.
My Eyes wou'd ever on this object stay,
But sinking Nature takes the props away.
—Kind Death— 〈…〉
To end with pleasures all my miseries
Shuts up your Image in my closing Eyes.

sp.speaker: 1 Mess.
sp.p: To Armes, to Armes.

sp.speaker: Trax▪
sp.p: From whence this sudden fear?

sp.speaker: 1 Mess.
sp.l: Stand to your Guard, my Lord, the danger's near:
From every quarter Crowds of People meet,
And leaving Houses empty, fill the street.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Fond Queen, thy fruitless tears a while defer.
Rise, we must join again—Not speak nor stir!
I hear the Peoples Voice like Winds that roar,
When they pursue the flying Waves to shore.

sp.speaker: 2 Mess.
sp.l: Prepare to fight▪ my Lord; the Banisht Queen,
With old Garrucca, in the streets are seen.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: We must go meet them e▪er it be too late;
Yet, Madam, rise, have you no sence of fate.

sp.speaker: 3 Mess.
sp.l: King Montezuma their Lord shouts Proclaim,
The City rings with their new Sovereign's Name;
The banish'd Queen declares he is her Son,
And to his succour all the people run.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Can this be true? O Love! O Fate! have I
Thus doated on my mortal Enemy.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: To my new Prince I thus my homage pay;
Your Reign is short, young King.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Traxalla, stay—
'Tis to my hand that he must owe his fate,
I will revenge at once my love and hate.

div.stage: She sets a Dagger to Montezuma's Breast.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.l: Strike, strike, the conquering Enemy is near,
My Guards are press'd while you detain me here.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Dye then, ungrateful, dye; Amexia's Son
Shall never triumph on Acacis Throne:
Thy death must my unhappy flames remove;
Now where is thy defence—against my love?

div.stage: She cuts the Cords, and gives him the Dagger.

sp.speaker: Trax.
sp.p: Am I betrayed?

div.stage: He draws and thrusts at Montezuma, he puts it by and kills him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So may all Rebels dye:
This end has Treason join'd with Cruelty.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: Live thou whom I must love, and yet must hate;
She gave thee Life, who knows it brings her fate.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Life is a trifle which I wou'd not take,
But for Orazia's and her Father's sake:
Now, Ynca, hate me, if thou canst; for he
Whom thou hast scorn'd will dye or rescue thee.

div.stage: As he goes to attacque the Guards with Traxalla's Sword, Enter Amexia, Garrucca, Indians, driving some of the other Party before them.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: He lives, ye Gods, he lives, great Queen, see here
Your coming joys, and your departing fear.

sp.speaker: Amex.
sp.l: Wonder and joy so fast together flow,
Their haste to pass has made their passage slow;
Like strugling Waters in a Vessel pent,
Whose crowding drops choak up the narrow Vent.
My Son.—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I am amaz'd, it cannot be
That fate has such a joy in store for me.

sp.speaker: Amex.
sp.p: Can I not gain belief, that this is true?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: It is my fortune I suspect, not you.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: First ask him if he old Garrucca know.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: My honoured Father, let me fall thus low.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Forbear, great Prince, 'tis I must pay to you
That adoration, as my Sovereign's due:
For from my humble Race you did not spring,
You are the Issue of our Murthered King,
Sent by that Traytor to his blest abode,
Whom to be made a King, he made a God:
The story is too full of fate to tell,
Or what strange fortune our lost Queen befel.

sp.speaker: Amex.
sp.l: That sad relation longer time will crave;
I liv'd obscure, he bred you in a Cave,
But kept the mighty secret from your Ear,
Lest heat of blood to some strange course shou'd steer
Your youth—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I owe him all that now I am,
He taught me first the noble thirst of fame,
Shew'd me the baseness of unmanly fear,
Till th' unlick'd Whelp I pluck'd from the rough Bear,
And made the Ounce and Tyger give me way,
While from their hungry Jaws I snatch'd the Prey:
'Twas he that charg'd my young arms first with toils,
And drest me glorious in my Salvage spoils.—

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: You spent in shady Forest all the day,
And joy'd returning to shew me the Prey.
To tell the story, to describe the place,
With all the pleasures of the boasted chase;
Till sit for arms, I reav'd you from your sport,
To train your Youth in the Peruvian Court:
I left you there, and ever since have been,
The sad attendant of my exil'd Queen.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: My fatal Dream comes to my memory;
That Lion whom I held in bonds was he,
Amexia was the Dove that broke his Chains;
What now but Zempoalla's death remains?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Pardon, fair Princess, if I must delay
My love a while, my gratitude to pay.
Live, Zempoalla—free from dangers live,
For present merits I past crimes forgive:
Oh might she hope Orazia's Pardon too.—

sp.speaker: Orazia.
sp.l: I wou'd have none condemn'd for loving you;
In me her merit much her fault o'er powers,
She sought my Life, but she preserv'd me yours.

sp.speaker: Amex.
sp.l: Taught by my own I pity her estate,
And wish her penitence, but not her fate.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.l: I wou'd not be the last to bid her live;
Kings best revenge their wrongs when they forgive.

sp.speaker: Zemp.
sp.l: I cannot yet forget what I have been,
Wou'd you give life to her that was a Queen:
Must you then give, and must I take; there's yet
One way, that's by refusing to be great:
You bid me live—bid me be wretched too,
Think, think, what Pride unthron'd must undergo:
Look on this youth, Amexia, look, and then
Suppose him yours, and bid me live again;
A greater sweetness on these Lips there grows,
Than breath shut out from a new folded Rose:
What lovely charms on these cold Cheeks appear,
Cou'd any one hate death and see it here?
But thou art gone—

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: O that you wou'd believe,
Acacis lives in me, and cease to grieve.

sp.speaker: Zemp
sp.l: Yes, I will cease to grieve, and cease to be,
His Soul stays watching in his wound for me;
All that cou'd render Life desir'd is gone,
Orazia has my Love, and you my Throne:
And Death Acacis—yet I need not dye,
You leave me Mistriss of my destiny;
In spight of Dreams how am I pleas'd to see,
Heavens truth or falshood shou'd depend on me;
But I will help the Gods;
The greatest proof of Courage we can give,
Is then to dye when we have to power live.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How fatally that instrument of death
Was hid—

sp.speaker: Amex.
sp.p: She has expir'd her latest breath.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: But there lies one to whom all grief is due.

sp.speaker: Orazia
sp.p: None e'er was so unhappy and so true.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Your Pardon, Royal Sir.

sp.speaker: Ynca.
sp.p: You have my Love.

sp.speaker: Amex.
sp.p: The Gods, my Son, your happy choice approve.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Come, my Orazia, then, and pay with me, Leads her to Acacis.
Some tears to poor Acacis memory;
So strange a fate for Men the Gods ordain
Our clearest Sun shine shou'd be mixt with rain;
How equally our joys and sorrows move!
Death's fatal triumphs join'd with those of Love.
Love Crowns the dead, and death Crowns him that lives,
Each gains the Conquest which the other gives.

div.head: EPILOGUE to the INDIAN QUEEN,
div.l: YOU see what Shifts we are inforc'd to try
To help out Wit with some Variety;
Shows may be found that never yet were seen,
'Tis hard to find such Wit as ne'er has been:
You have seen all that this old World cou'd do,
We therefore try the fortune of the new,
And hope it is below your aim to hit
At untaught Nature with your practis'd Wit:
Our naked Indians then, when Wits appear,
Wou'd as soon chuse to have the Spaniards here:
'Tis true, y'have marks enough, the Plot, the Show,
The Poet's Scenes, nay, more, the Painter's too;
If all this fail, considering the cost,
'Tis a true Voyage to the Indies lost:
But if you smile on all, then these designs,
Like the imperfect Treasure of our Minds,
'Twill pass for currant wheresoe'er they go,
When to your bounteous hands their stamps they owe

div.p: THE VESTAL VIRGIN, OR, THE Roman Ladies. A TRAGEDY. Written by the Honourable Sir ROBERT HOWARD.
LONDON, Printed for Henry Herringman, and are to be Sold by R. Bentley, J. Tonson, F. Saunders, and T. Bennet. M DC XCII.

list.head: Dramatis Personae.
list.item: Emilius, A Roman Senator of great Quality.
Sertorius, One that had been a General; a brave Man, of a high Spirit.
Sulpitius, His Brother, of a treacherous Nature.
Mutius, One that had been a Lieutenant of a Province, a Lover of War.
Artabaces, Prince of Armenia, driven from his Country by the Romans.
Tiridates, His younger Brother, Pris'ner at large in Rome, and kept as Hostage till his Brother came in.
Corbulo, and four or five more Veterans.

div.p: SCENE ROME.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: PRologues, like Forlorn-hopes, first face the Stage,
Before the main Battalions do engage:
Just so our Poet, doubtful of the day,
Ventures his Prologue first, and next his Play.
But stay, I fancy that I hear one call;
I'll step but to the door, and tell you all.
'Troth 'tis the Poet's Voice, now danger's near;
He sends me back as his Commissioner,
To treat that he might fairly march away,
If you wou'd be content to have no Play.
He offers fair: Shou'd it prove very bad,
As like enough it will, you'd wish you had:
He has been wounded, proofs there need no more
Than what you know, that he has writ before;
For sure none ever scap'd that ever writ;
There's no being shot-free in the Wars of Wit:
Poets by dangers like old Souldiers taught,
Grow wise, and shun the fame which once they sought.
But if he must proceed—
Wou'd you wou'd tell him which of all the ways
You like in Prologues, us'd to help out Plays.
Some tell you stories of the former Age,
And swear that Faction now undoes the Stage;
Sure such believe you'll do as you are bid,
And that you paid your money to be chid.
Some craftier Poets at each other hit,
Knowing grave Rudeness has been took for Wit;
This does a wretched dearth of Wit betray,
When things of Kind on one another prey.
Some Prologues are more modestly address'd,
Just like Petitions, those he thinks are best;
For such a one he means that this shall be,
And therefore humbly shews as you shall see.

div.head: THE VESTAL VIRGIN, OR, THE Roman Ladies.
ACT I.
SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: NOT speak to her, nor see her!

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: But for a few days.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: A minute is too much.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: Be but patient.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: And tamely wait upon my Rival's triumph.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: You do mistake.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: So do you, to think a Roman Soul can be
So mean to stoop to his own Victory;
Submitting to a Prince's empty Name,
And tamely yield unto a vanquish'd Fame.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Your Passion tells you wrong; 'tis not that Prince,
But 'tis Hersilia sends you these Commands.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: I care not whence they came, I like 'em not.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: You throw away your fury now as wildly,
As Tempests waste their giddy violence.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: No matter, raging Storms grow loud and high
When they are most oppos'd, and so will I.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: Am not I your Brother!

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Is not Prince Tiridates, as you call him,
Your bosom Friend?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: You are not jealous, are you, that his Friendship
Makes me betray the trust you plac'd in me?

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: You shou'd have scrupled then to bring a Brother
Such an unwelcome Message.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: Consult a little with your prudence.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Wisdom's too froward to let any find
Trust in himself, or pleasure in his mind;
She takes by what she gives, her help destroys;
She shakes our Courage, and disturbs our joys▪
Rashness allows unto the sudden sense
All its own joys, and adds her Confidence.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: You have not patience but to hear the Circumstance.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: Well, well, what is't? quickly then.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: 'Tis more than you deserve.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: Then keep it for your self.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: They properly belong to you,
Since they were her Commands; when she sent them
She mingled trouble with her seeming Cruelty▪
—The • sigh'd, and pa •• 'd—then bid me tell you,
Her Father was so kind to Tiridates,
She cou'd no other way deny his Visits,
But by forbidding yours for some few days,
To give her self time to attempt some Friends,
To try their interest to perswade her Father
That she with freedom▪ may be left to chuse
Where inclination guides her.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: Um'h.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: Now, Sir, is the Circumstance so trivial?

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: But was this all she said?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: Was not this enough?

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: As it may prove—
You are sure Tiridates will be forbid too,—
—Are you not?—

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: As I suppose.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: I will be sure of that,—or else—

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: What need you question it? in a few hours
You will discover that you are abus'd,
If there be foul play meant on any side.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: That's true,—but—

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Come trouble your self no more, but strictly
Observe what she Commands.
These starts are the Convulsions of weak Reason,
When sits of Passion grow too strong upon you.
We have all our haggard Passions, but none so wild
Or so unman'd as yours;—
They may be tam'd and brought from their excess,
And watch'd by Reason into gentleness.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Without your Simile I will endeavour to endure it,
—But—

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: I find a mutiny in all my Faculties,
That will not yield to this Cessation;
My Tongue seems to consent without Commission▪
But I'll go wrangle with my self,
And will obey her—if I can—

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Where must my wild beginnings find an end?
Nature and Friendship; Brother too, and Friend!
Titles that grow in soils so rich and good,
Whose Roots are spread in Honour and in Blood:
Yet all those ties keep not their hold so fast,
As to oppose unshaken but▪ one blast
Of Love's unruly storm; great Trees fall so,
Pulling up all about 'em where they grow.

div.stage: Enter Tiridates, runs to Sulpitius, and embraces him.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: O my Sulpitius, thou that canst prove
Friend to the Rival of thy Brother's Love;
Have you yet spoke of me, and wou'd she hear?
'Tis not thy Friendship, but her Love I fear.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: I did not name you.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: —Perhaps you did not dare.
Methinks concern'd Physicians, in despair,
Gaze on their Patients as you stare on me,
And from their Skill sink to their Piety.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: I wish Hersilia had not nam'd you.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.p: You are my Friend.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: And therefore cou'd not like th' unwelcom Office
That she has put upon me.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.p: Cou'd you dislike what she commands!

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Yes, I do, or else I must repent
My Love to you, and grow indifferent.
Know, 'tis the cruel fair Hersilia's pleasure
You shou'd forbear to visit her, or if you meet her,
To speak to her for some few days.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Why shou'd Hersilia cruelly contrive
Death for that Passion which she keeps alive?
But 'tis a guilt to question or repine;
She acts like what she seems, something divine:
For when Mankind their frailer passions show,
Those Pow'rs above condemn that made them so.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I fear'd 'twou'd trouble you, for I can find
A measure of your Sorrows by my Mind.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.p: Did she not tell you why?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: —That she refus'd,
Though I still prest it to find out her end,
More than became one that was less your Friend:
At last continuing still importunate,
She told me with a Smile, 'twas not her hate,
Nor love unto another was the cause,
She seem'd to be so cruel in these Laws.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: When I lost my Brother—
Brave Artabaces, whom I cou'd not call
More Brother than a Friend: for he was all▪
I did not think a Friendship cou'd express
It self so great, to make his loss the less:
But thine, my dear Sulpitius, is above
The Rules and Measures of the strictest Love.
You might have hop'd to see your Brother's joy,
Sprung from those harsh commands which mine destroy.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: My love unto Sertorius is not less,
I wish his Gratitude, his Happiness,
To pay great Marcellina all Love's scores,
Whom every Roman but himself adores:
Why do you droop? fie, fie, do not give way
To your encroaching Griefs; hope and obey:
In the mean time during your Banishment,
In my best Love and Care rest confident▪
I'll weary her with Pray'rs, till I obtain
Leave from her Lips to call you back again.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: My hopes are only rais'd by thy kind Charms,
O let me always hold thee in my Arms.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I must go back and tell him 'tis impossible.
—Ha—twisted.—

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: How, my Brother!—
I must say something quickly; but—what,
—Brother—perhaps you wonder—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I mean, to see my kindness at this time
So great to Tiridates: but as a Friend,
I cou'd not be exempt from pity.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: What pity does he need?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: It seems much more than you,
In the severe Commands of fair Hersilia:
He is for over banished; no time nor hopes
Allow'd to him: you are too generous
To swell upon his sinking.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: That I despise.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Pray give me leave at least to shew
That pity which a Friend ought to bestow:
Perhaps the Reasons of a Friend may prove
A Balm to cure the Wounds of hopeless Love. Goes to Tiridates.
—I cou'd not stay a minute, Sir,—
From telling you the happy News
Which you may find writ in my Brother's looks.
The fair and just Hersilia has pronounc'd
His Banishment for ever.— Enter Hersilia and Marcellina.
Ha, Hersilia! what new Confusions croud upon me?
How near my Plots are to discovery!
I must out-face Fortune and Honesty, He steps to Sertorius hastily.
Brother, give not Tiridates the advantage
To seem more pleas'd than you in his Obedience.
I'll instantly attempt to serve you. Goes to Hersilia.
—Madam, this unexpected Happiness
Adds to the greatness of it.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: The coolness of the Evening, and these Walks,
Invited out me and my Cousin,
Not thinking to have met so much good Company
As you, Prince Tiridates, and Sertorius. She curtsies to them, and they bow and stand still.
—Ha—Marcellina, a word. Speaks aside with Marcellina.
D'ye not observe what an unusual distance
Prince Tiridates, and Sertorius keep?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: I both observe and wonder.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Peace, let's be gone—
We have almost tir'd our selves, Sir,
And were just now returning home▪

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Permit me, Madam, to receive the Honour
Of waiting on you; I have something to acquaint you with.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Madam,
Your Sister the fair Verginia is just now
Brought from the Vestals, and begs to see you.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: I long as much to look on her:
They say she is much alter'd.—
—This is strange, Marcellina.—Looks at Tiridates and Sertorius.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I will return presently; till then be silent: To Sertorius.
I wait upon you, Madam.

div.stage: Manent Tiridates and Sertorius; they stare at one another; at last Sertorius speaks.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: I hope you do not think that I forbore
