To speak my love and thoughts unto Hersilia,
Because a Rival did look on.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.p: Nor did that hinder me to own my Love.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: Your hopes upon her Father's friendship move.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.p: The greatness of my love is its own aid.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Some use of empty Titles might be made:
There is a noise with Names of Princes brought;
Yet though her Father is with nothing caught,
Those that have conquer'd Princes need not show
Respect to Titles which they can bestow.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Cou'd any Roman Sword find Victory,
As soon as you can with your Vanity;
A Prince indeed might tremble then to hear,
But now he smiles at what you'd have him fear.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: O you shall see that I can keep my word,
And shew no Roman e'er out-talk'd his Sword; They draw and fight.
To this a greater Quarrel yet I joyn,
Hersilia's Cause, they equally are mine.

div.stage: Enter Sulpitius, runs in and parts them.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Hold, hold, hear me but speak:
From what hid Cause does all this Fury break?

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Love is our Cause which we resolve to trust
To our own Swords, we're sure that they are just.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: 'Tis mean to wait for one to be deny'd,
And to refer that which we may decide:
Death is the certain Umpire that makes friends;
With him that dies Hersilia's trouble ends.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Stand by, and since you wear the double tyes
Of Friend and Brother, look with equal Eyes.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Must Hersilia thus
Be sav'd from trouble by the loss of Fame?
Your Swords will wound her yet unspotted Name;
No drop of blood vou shed but will remain
Upon her injur'd Innocence, a stain;
She will be equally oblig'd to hate
The Victor's life; the vanquish'd in his Fate.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: She's cruel now; if she her hate shou'd show
When I am dead, 'tis more than I shall know.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Suppose she never wou'd your loves requite,
For what is' • then you wou'd pretend to fight?
'Tis vain to strive for Empire, that wou'd be
Not gain'd, but rather lost by Victory.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Yet without Conquest she is gain'd by none,
And only can be overcome by one;
Both in Hersilia cannot happy prove,
The Government is Monarchy in love.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Sulpitius now your troubles shall have end,
Left free to serve a Brother or a Friend:
He that first falls, (for one of us must dye)
Leaves you to t'other as his Legacy.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: All the disputes of love are judg'd by fate,
And death makes room when life is grown too strait.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: Hold, hear me a word!

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: Pish.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Of you I ask it, Tiridates, stay,
And let your reason this rash action weigh.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Love never waits on Reason but on chance;
But why shou'd you advise this temperance?
Bid me be cold, and bring the Fever too;
Hersilia sent the banishment by you.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Ha,—
Did my careful Brother bring you such news?

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.p: Yes, and from Hersilia's cruel Lips.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: I received just such another Message.
Can you tell Brother which was the Copy and Original?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: Whence came they then?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: From me.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: And your invention.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Right.
D'you think Hersilia's lov'd by you alone?
Had I perceiv'd it easie to be done,
I wou'd have fool'd you both: Why d'you stare?
D'you wonder that I love, or that I dare
A vow a Passion which both you proclaim?
I'll be as loud as you in Love or Fame.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: O Monster.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: See I am chang'd, of your opinion grown, Draws.
Think Life and Love is useful but for one:
We shall but hinder one another still; agree
Which is my Man, so Fate and Love for me.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Brave Tiridates,
This Villain's baseness the first cause removes,
And makes the quarrel Nature's, which was Love's:
To me 'tis just the title to resign,
To let out his soul blood that will stain mine:
Nor will I on the score of Rivals fight.
And while I take my own injure your right:
But as his Executioner I'll prove,
The Minister of Justice, not of Love.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Fight you by your own Rules, I'll make the Laws
For my own Sword, and Love shall be my Cause.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Hold, hold, Sertorius,
No seeming cause can check or cousen Fame,
Every thing will at last bear its own name;
You may stand by with justice and look on,
Nature is your excuse, but I have none.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Nature did never yet send an excuse
In her own whispers, for her own abuse.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Come, come, we trisle; let some lots decide
Which of your Fates with mine shall first be try'd.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Fortune has ever been too curst to me,
To trust her with my hopes of Victory:
But, Tiridates, now methinks we shew
In our own Cause too quick, in Loves too slow:
He that survives of us by love will be
Entitled to revenge thy Treachery.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.p: Thus I embrace the offer.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Not so fast,
I will fight too, and will not fight the last:
That mighty rate which nicely you assign
Your love and honour, I have sixt on mine.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: My flesh trembles like shaking Earth, when prest
By tempests that want room within her Breast:
Through all my Veins there runs a boiling stood,
And makes a thousand pulses in my blood.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Stay, Sertorius, stay; methinks we grow
Too bold; Hersilia's Sentence shou'd bestow
Life, or give Death: we but like Rebels are,
While with our Swords Hersilia's Pow'r we share.
Come let us go like Friends in misery,
And from our Judges Lips learn which shall dye.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: He does dissemble sure—'tis noble— Aside.
Brave Prince, with your fair temper I am brought
To reason, by a Rival's Friendship taught:
Had you or I sunk under t'others hate,
The living wou'd have pittied his hard fate.
Though love condemns, our grief may be the same;
For death's all one brought by a Sword or Flame:
'Twere mean, if love had not the pow'r to shew
That gen'rous grief which honour can bestow. They put up.
Why shou'd the steps rais'd by our honour prove
Too hard to be ascended by our love.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Good, very good; d'ye think to couzen me?
You practise to dissemble scurvily.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.p: All treachery dwells only in thy Breast.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Pish, none are truly by themselves exprest;
He that seems Vertuous does but act a part,
And shews not his own Nature, but his Art.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: I can be tame no longer.

div.stage: Draws and offers to run at him.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: —Sertorius, stay
Our Friendship must not yet oblige this way.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: O does the mask fall off!

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: Let us together then dispatch the Traytor.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: You dare not—
—Your honours as my guard will stand;
You both scorn odds, and I a single hand.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: Tortures seize thee.—Tiridates.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: I'll follow too: O you need say no more.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: How meanly we must part! never before
Honour and Love shew'd such strange properties,
To keep all safe by being Enemies;
With their own niceness they themselves betray,
And while they both Command they both obey.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Emilius, Hersilia, Marcellina, and Verginia vail'd.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: WElcome my sweet, my dear Verginia;
Off with this Cloud, in thy own brightness shine,
And let my longing Eyes twist rayes with thine;
All my decaying joys grow warm, and bring
A heat which thaws me into youth again.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Are you my Father, Sir?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I am, sweet Innocence; and richer in that title
By Nature's gift, than he that by his fame
Of his own Country gains a Father's name.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Your Pardon, Sir, that I seem amaz'd,
I never saw a Man before.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, give us leave
To have a little share in her enjoyment;
Dearest Sister, you look amaz'd or troubled.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pardon me, dear Sister, if you find
Some small disturbance hang about my mind;
To be thus soon from a devotion brought,
Not more by precept than by custom taught.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Dear Cousin, so much kindness yet express
As to take pleasure in our happiness.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: 'Twere want of true Religion not to know
Some joy in so much goodness which you shew.

sp.speaker: Emil
sp.l: My dear Verginia,
I have found out a Man to make thee happy,
Whose Vertues, and whose Fortunes shall contend
Which are the greatest, both without an end.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: What does my Father mean?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Come, Verginia, Company troubles thee I see,
Be not amaz'd; I must be fond of thee,
To wean thee from thy self, till thou sha't find
No room but for content within thy mind.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How fair she is, how full of Innocence!
All true content dwells with unpractis'd sense.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: O Marcellina!
Though Knowledge does beget both Joy and Love,
Yet Vice and Sorrow too her issue prove;
Prest with the last the greatest numbers shew;
And the Worlds seeming mischief is to know.
—Did you not wonder, Marcellina,
At the strange distance that was kept so strictly
By Tiridates and Sertorius?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I did, and was as much amaz'd as you;
I wish no mischief happen, for their looks
Strove with a strange constraint.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Prince Tiridates too exprest the same
—Whose gentle temper I have always seen,
Like standing Water wearing still one face,
That had no tides to move it from its place.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Can you guess the cause?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Not in the least.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I need not ask, it is enough that they are Rivals,
And both love you.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Such quarrels still my injury must prove;
Both may deserve, but cannot have my love;
Love cannot like the wind its help convey
To fill two sails, though both are spread one way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: D' you love one of them?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Yes, but not Sertorius:
Though freely I confess my love to thee;
Yet I forgive thy short return to me,
Which seems to violate our Friendship's Laws;
But his ingratitude pleads in thy cause;
Since the acknowledgment wou'd lay a blame
On thy great Soul, or on thy cheeks a shame.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Be not deceiv'd, Hersilia,
I wou'd not make my self so guilty prove,
And like a hidden sin disown my love.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Thus his ingratitude the more is shown.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By his ingratitude confess your own:
Where does the difference appear to be?
You cannot sigh for him, nor he for me.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: But you deserve much more than he can do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He merits more than me, he merits you:
Love pleads no cause for the unfortunate,
Choice rules above our pow'r as much as fate:
Love unrewarded may to Vertue grow,
But love for love like a design may shew.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Sertorius my revenge not love invites,
And that strict Friendship which our Souls unites:
Must now our Soul's affections separate,
And what you love 'tis just that I shou'd hate.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What friendship wou'd return my love denies,
I dare not say I hate whom you despise.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Peace; Sulpitius;
Let him not see disorder in our looks,
I suspect him.—How amaz'd he seems!

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Help, Fortune, now, thou that hast always sent
Thy willing aid to the most confident.
—Madam—

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Perhaps your own amazement might be less,
Cou'd I forbear my wonder to express.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: What wonder, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Some wonder must attend a sudden change,
To see Prince Tiridates and Sertorius strange.
So unlike Lovers now they did appear,
That they both seem'd as if they never were.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I wish 'twere so, my troubles then might end,
One is my Brother, t'other is my Friend:
Yet to those titles there is nothing due,
Since they so soon forget themselves and you.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: You only fancy sure this strange neglect,
They paid to me as much as I expect.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: I'm sorry that my Passion renders me
The severe judge of their inconstancy.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Your Passion, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Yes mine, so mingled with Eternity,
It understood not what they seem'd to be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You speak too like a Rival now to prove
An uncorrupted Judge in Pleas of love.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: If I confess the bonds in which I'm ti'd,
Fair Marcellina shou'd not seem to chide;
Since if the just Hersilia pitties me,
I leave Sertorius to her love more free.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In such mean paths as cous'ning States-men move,
To walk to greatness, others tread to love:
Both creep upon the strength of fawning lyes,
And on Mens blasted fames attempt to rise.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: This to me, Madam, that have always shewn
A sorrow for your wrong!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I know of none,
But those which I receive from your design;
The injury of Vertue must be mine.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: Vertue by truth receives no injury.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Truth is ill carried by an Enemy;
I'll do my self and them at least this right,
To forbid you to come into my sight.
O Marcellina, As going out.
How hard it is my trouble to disguise,
Though I believe not him, I must my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: What can this mean, perhaps they both agree!
To hide their trouble, and to cousen me;
'Twas dull and foolish to betray my flame,
Designs that hit shou'd be as swift as aim.
They shou'd go quicker off; Powder not dry
Does seldom hit, but makes the Fowl more shie. Enter Servant.
O, Claudius, welcome.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Have you sped, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Indifferently; but still thy merits
Deserve more than I promis'd: Here, take this,
And still continue constant to my wishes;
I shall need thy further help.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: You shall not fail to have it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Meet me an hour hence
Hard by the Flavian Bridge: fail not.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: You need not, Sir, repeat commands to me.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Thy rewards shall fall like show'rs upon thee. Ex. Serv.
My plots fall short, like Darts which rash hands throw
With an ill aim, and have too far to go;
Nor can I long discoveries prevent,
I deal too much among the Innocent I
Their tracks are not so soon discern'd that go
Thorough soul paths, as theirs that tread in snow.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: When will Tiridates meet?

sp.speaker: Cask.
sp.l: Presently, Sir; he promis'd to be there as soon as you.
A little farther brings you to the place.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: He's noble.
Why shou'd it easier prove
To agree more in Virtue than in Love!
Those that are Rivals in their Piety
Are kind, yet all bow to one Deity:
We both have but one Altar and one Flame,
Our Honour, Love and Wishes are the same;
From those fair Springs true Friendship us'd to flow;
But from those Fountains now our Quarrels grow.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Noble Sertorius.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: You mean Sulpitius.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: I shou'd be glad to see him.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: Prethee look him.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: What's this! I have been better entertain'd:
My Sword has help'd this Man to Victory;
But now it seems there is no use of me:
There may come yet a time— Enter five or six Veterans.
Brave Mutius.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Mighty Plebeians, yours.
A hard time, Mutius.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Easie enough for you, brave Veterans;
I take it you are not cloy'd with business.
Troth we have scarce business for our teeth.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Draw 'em then;
Hunger is the worst kind of Tooth-ach.
We have been courted, Mutius,
Speeches made to us, and call'd the Bulwarks of the Country▪
Now we are slighted.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Did you intend that for a Jest?
I hate a Souldier that is poor and witty;
Wit is the peace of every Man; hang it,
A Souldier should be blunt and mutinous.
We shou'd be hang'd then.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Not if you'd hang together, Puppies.
O the brave days of Julius, when he flew
The Roman Eagles at the stooping World,
And dar'd it like a Lark!
I, I, those were days.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Peace is the rust of Minds; brave Souls refine
By great Examples, and with use they shine.
I remember Pharsalia's dreadful Field,
When the first Ranks came to so near a view,
The Roman Souldiers all each other knew;
In vain the Generals gave their fierce Commands,
The Eyes of both the Armies held their hands;
While Brothers gaze, and Fathers Sons behold,
Nature in whispers her fond stories told;
Friends gaz'd on Friends, forgot they were to fight,
And made a halt as shameful as a flight;
When Crastinus advanc'd before the rest,
And struck his Pyle into a Roman Breast:
As from one Cloud vast Tempests fill the Skies,
So showres of Piles from his began to rise:
Had not his great Example set us free,
We had been robb'd of that day's Victory.
I Captain, our Emperour has shut up Janus's Gates,
The World's at peace now.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Let him lull in't,
Till he forget the way how to Command;
'Tis a dark Lanthorn in a Prince's hand;
'Tis Peace that shines, while he in darkness lives,
Hid by the light which he to others gives.
The Gown-men now by cherish'd Vices thrive;
Virtue is starv'd, or hardly kept alive;
Mischief is fed, while out of Policy
They keep some to betray, and some to lie.
No employment now for Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: You are dull Blockheads when y'are out of pay;
The Souldiers Vices lie another way.
D'ye think that Statesmens kindnesses proceed
From any principles but their own need?
When they'r afraid, they'r wondrous good and free;
But when they'r safe they have no memory.
The Great Men swallow all.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Mankind upon each others ruines rise,
Cowards maintain the brave, and Fools the wise:
Honour and all Religion bears a price,
But as the rates are set by Death and Vice.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: Brave Mutius, never more happily met.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: That's well; did you not meet Sertorius?

sp.speaker: Sulp
sp.p: No, why d'ye ask?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Nay nothing;
I thought he had been going to keep an Oracle,
He practis'd to stare and swell strangely.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Let him swell and burst, it matters not.
—Who are these, Mutius?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Quiet Rogues; they were brave Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: Have they lost their Spirits?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: I know not; they are out of practice;
They have been bob'd;
They might be train'd again perhaps, and enter'd.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: This way a little, Mutius; you are my Friend.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: I wou'd cut any Man's throat
That said the contrary.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: I must use your Sword, Mutius.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Here it hangs ready, 'tis almost rusty.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Be not startled when I tell you
'Tis against my Brother.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Let it be against your Father,
'Tis all one to me.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: The quarrel is Hersilia.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: A Woman is the worst that cou'd be.
Are you to fight who shall have her?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: That she must only judge.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: So then, shall we fight to make her sport?
A parcel of such Lovers
Wou'd make excellent pastime in the Amphitheatre:
I had an easier way with my Damsels;
Kind or cruel, they never scap'd me.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: Not if you cou'd come at 'em, Mutius.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: If they were hid in Houses
I made 'em bolt with Fire,
And pitch'd my toils on all sides ready for 'em.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Ha—
Noble Mutius, farewel; we'll wait on you
Another time.

sp.speaker: Sulp
sp.p: Pray let your Friends stay a little.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Stay, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: Fire a House, Mutius!

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: There's no such way; the coyest then
Will leap into the next Man's Arms:
I have been thank'd for saving them
Out of the very Fire that I kindled.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: I hey may live to love Hersilia.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: If we kill 'em, 'tis two to one however
That you'll ne'er have her.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: Dare these Men stick by us?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Pay 'em well, and let the business
Be wicked enough; Then never fear 'em.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: They shall eat Gold.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: 'Troth I believe they can digest it too.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Thou hast put wild thoughts into my head:
If I shou'd fail, she crowns their Victory;
Or if Prince Tiridates falls by me,
I must live hated by her. You Pow'rs above,
Let either Death or Life reward my Love.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: You are troubled, Sir: I did not talk
To save the • ighting part: I wou'd serve you in your love
Through greater dangers.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: O Mutius, advise me something;
My blood and thoughts stand still within my Breast;
Reason's asleep, and torments seem a • rest.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Why I have told you my best stratagem;
If you get her Father's House but fir'd,
Let us alone, we'll help to quench it;
And in the hurry we may get your Mistress;
There's no suspicion waits on such disorders.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Dear Mutuis, thou reviv'st my drooping Soul;
There is no other way left probable. Enter Claudius a Servant.
See, Mutius, Fortune seconds thy advice,
Here's one may prove the Instrument—walk off.
Claudius, welcome; here I have been short in my Rewards.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: You have been, Sir, too bountiful
To my small services.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I have a business, if thou dar'st attempt it,
Shall treble thy Rewards, and yet leave me thy debtor.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Name it, Sir, and think it done.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Thou know'st
How unsuccessful I am like to prove;
One Act of thine may help me to Hersilia,
Then think what thy reward shall be.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Speak but the thing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Presently then in some convenient place
Set fire on thy Master's House; do not wonder,
I'll have those ready that shall quench it quickly;
And in the hurry, under pretence of help,
Bring Hersilia forth at the East-gate,
That looks towards the Tiber;
There I'll wait for her; and by my happiness
Measure thy own Rewards.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Whither shall we fly, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Trouble not thy self, leave that to me:
Dar'st thou do it?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: When wou'd you have it done, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sulp
sp.p: Presently, before suspicion can have time to grow.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I'll do it, Sir; be sure that you wait ready.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Be gone about it, let me see it flame
Before an hour's expir'd: trust to me,
And have no fears.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I know an unfrequented room
Fit for my purpose; I'll do it instantly:
Expect me at the East-gate.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: I will not fail.
'Tis done, Mutius, 'tis a fire already;
That Fellow is a Servant to Emilius,
He's gone about it: Are your Friends prepar'd?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Beyond sick Men, ready to dye for you.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: 'Tis well,
I'll place you in your several stations
That she may scape no way:
Then if we can but carry off our plunder.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Pish, the fire will have all the Enemies,
We shall have none.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: Where shall our Rendezvouz be?

sp.speaker: Mut
sp.l: At my House of pleasure
That stands upon the Tiber;
That will be least suspected, because I live
Most in the City: besides, we have the River
To help us to escape if need require.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: No better place.—Gentlemen,
Pray observe such orders as my Friend Mutius gives you.
He shall have money to reward you
Equal to all your services, and beyond modest wishes.
Doubt us not, Sir, we will be punctual.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Come, Mutius▪ as we go
We will agree on the particulars:
Justice has took away all my compassion;
And when their flames in cruel brightness shine,
I'll smile, since there was none that pittied mine.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: Have you plac'd the Horses where I appointed?

sp.speaker: Cask.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I have but one thing more then to enjoyn thee;
If I shou'd fall by Tiridates Sword,
Carry the News thy self unto Hersilia,
And watch her as thou woud'st an Arrow shot,
To see whether it hit or no.

sp.speaker: Cask.
sp.p: To what purpose, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: If she had any pity for me living,
Her sorrow for me dead, will shew it.

sp.speaker: Caska.
sp.p: But how, Sir, shou'd I send you word?

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: 'Tis true, abundance travel through the Grave;
But there's not one of all the multitude
Will carry more than his own News about him:
Why shou'd things so remote beget such strife
Beyond our knowledge, and beyond our life?
Succession thus some to fond Joys betray,
For whose vain hopes their ruine must make way.

sp.speaker: Cask.
sp.p: Prince Tiridates, Sir,

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: O 'tis well; leave us now, Caska,
And watch where I appointed:
If Tiridates comes without me,
Let him receive those helps that I shou'd have.

sp.speaker: Cask.
sp.p: This is a cruel Service, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: Dispute it not

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Your pardon, Sertorius, that I seem'd thus slow.
I was enforced to make some little stay
To 'scape Sulpitius▪ he and Mutius
Were earnest in Discourse.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: May be they are looking us; Mutius is bold,
Nor is that base Sulpitius less than he;
And thus much, Tiridates, I'll acknowledge,
Had they now met us with their Swords about 'em▪
I shou'd with much more pleasure as your Friend
Have took my share against 'em.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Assisted by Sertorius, I shou'd have been.
As sure of Conquest, as he is now of Victory. Draws.
I have one motion only left to make,
He that survives • e • him go tell Hersilia
That though his Rival in the fatal Strife
Was lost in Death, yet Love out-liv'd his Life.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: I will be just to you; but if I fall,
Carry no news of Love▪ nor me at all;
For▪ I have thought upon't, and find it vain,
To me no Message can come back again.

—So to our For ••••
▪

sp.speaker: Cask.
sp.p: Hold, hold, as you have Honour, hold.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: Ha, Caska What tempts thee to this Folly?

sp.speaker: Cask.
sp.l: The saddest Spectacle that ever was:
Emilius's House seems almost wrapt in Flame;
The noise of people, and the Fire encrease.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: Take heed you do not play the Fool.

sp.speaker: Cask.
sp.l: Go but to the place where you appointed me to wait,
And if it be not true, cut me to pieces:
While you doubt,
You but delay to help Hersilia.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.p: Can this be true!

sp.speaker: Cask.
sp.p: Or I am more a Villain than I was us'd to be.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: We may believe him. Come, Tiridates,
Hersilia's Danger now our Quarrel ends,
And when she is unsafe, we must be Friends:
Our Actions some fantastick Planet guides,
Ill Fortune can unite whom Good divides.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Artab.
sp.l: WHat Noise is this!—How!— Noise.
A House in Flames! where e'er I go, I see
Ruines of several Natures wait on me.
—Hark, they cry for help— Noise of help.
'Twere pity to devote my self to Flames,
To save I know not who; what need I care?
He that is wretched has a Life to spare;
Fate shall not need look after me, I'll try
Which is most careless grown, Fortune, or I.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: No stirring yet?

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.l: Not as we can see.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: They are not sindg'd yet:
Nor do I gaze with such a Gust of Joy,
As Pyrrhus had to look on burning Troy:
That this might grow to be Rome's funeral Flame,
And in its Ashes bury its own Name.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.l: Shall we go to th'other side?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: We'll keep our motions in this compass.

sp.speaker: 1 S.
sp.l: How shou'd we know the right Lady, Mutius?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Troth 'twas high time to ask;
Yet to say truth, I scarcely know my self;
But that we may be sure not to mistake,
Catch up every thing that looks but like a Woman.
Come softly this way.

div.stage: Enter Artabaces with Verginia, vail'd, and in a swoon.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Here's something yet, she was well findg'd,
And had been over-roasted presently. Sets her down.
—Now let me see my purchace.—
—Ha,—my Eyes dazle as if they star'd on Sun-shine.
—I'll wipe 'em, and then look again;
Her Eyes are clos'd; and though with her 'tis Night,
Her Beauty shines without the help of Light:
A darker Form has hid a Deity,
But Death's too near for Immortality.
I'll bow her gently;
Nature begins to triumph in the Strife,
And through her Lips soft Whispers steal of Life.
How fresh they shew, the Roses almost gone
For want of air, by Breath seem newly blown.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: —Ha,—where am I?
Hersilia, Sister, Hersilia,—
Ha,—who are you? Are you not my Father?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: No, by no means, fair Creature.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Are you not a Man?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That's an odd question—yes.—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: You shou'd be then my Father.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That's right, a man indeed shou'd be her Father.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Or is there any other man besides my Father?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: She's mad, over-heated with the Fire.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pray pardon my want of knowledge,
I never saw a man besides my Father,
Till I saw you, if you be one.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: This is the likeliest thing to be a Virgin
That e'er I met with. Aside
—Where have you liv'd, to be so ignorant?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Among the Vestal Virgins from an Infant,
And help'd to keep the Sacred Fire alive.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: O that my Flame, as pure as those, might be
Fed by your pity, though not piety!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Help me but back again, and I'll attend
With true Devotion those pure Flames you send.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: From Ignorance alas her pity grows,
Her Innocence above a Vertue shews.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I had forgot, my Father and my Sister
May want the help that you ill plac'd in me.
O pity, there's rather my misery;
Their Merits and Rewards far exceed mine.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Rewards cou'd never yet my Soul incline.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I can invite you then no other way.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Command me to my Death, and I obey.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Sure all Mankind are not thus vertuous too.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: All Womankind do less resemble you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Hark, a Noise again; O my Father! Noise.
Gentle Sir, that gen'rous pity shew,
Which those above gave you but to bestow.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Dry up your Tears, fair Innocence;
I only beg, if I return,
That I may find you in this place again.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Here you shall find me sending up my Pray'rs
For your Success and Happiness.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I had forgot to ask your Name.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Verginia, Sir, my Father's Name's Emilius,
You never ask'd me that.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Nor never shou'd;
I have your word to stay just in this place.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: You need not doubt; I know not where to go.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: 'Tis all I ask for my Reward;
Think, bright Verginia, all your Cares are mine.
Fortune has play'd her Tricks, now Love play thine.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Does Heaven on all Mankind such good bestow?
My Fortune's excellent, or they are so:
I grow strangely concern'd, some unknown Cause
A secret warmth into my Bosom draws;
I blush, I know not why; my confus'd Sense
Whispers, that Shame can live with Innocence;
Mind's like smooth Paper never writ upon,
When folded up, by some Impression,
Marks will remain it never had before,
And ne'er return to former smoothness more.

div.stage: Enter Mutius, and three or four.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: No news yet of Sulpitius!
—The Women are all burnt, I hope.
—Ha, here's one yet left, a very fair one too.
—Come, Lady, you must along with me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Why, men.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: You wou'd not be thus rude then.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Who the Devil shou'd be rude, if men shou'd not?
Away with her, and stay for me
Under the Grove I told you of.
• Come along.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Whither? why d'ye pull me?
Alas, you'll frighten me.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: She's wond'rous fair.—Away with her.
I hope this is not Hersilia.— Aside.
Then 'tis fair play: Equal Danger, equal Plunder.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pray do not pull me, I promis'd to stay here
Till a Friend come; I must not break my word.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Indeed you must.—Away with her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What d'ye mean. O my heart fails me.
—Oh.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Up with her, she'll wake with jogging:
Stay where I told you; I'll see a little farther,
And then come to you.

div.stage: Enter Sulpitius and Hersilia, with Claudius and others.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Follow still behind, and give me notice
If any overtakes us: Is Cinna gone to Mutius?
Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Whither d'you carry me?
I do command you let me go.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: When we are a little farther,
Free from the Danger that concerns your Honour,
I will obey you; till then, believe it was your Service,
That made me throw my self into this Danger.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: This is strange, I mistrust something.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: You might if you knew all I know;
Pray ask no Questions in this place.
All is unsafe about us.

div.stage: Enter Sertorius, bringing out Marcellina out of the fire.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Set down your wretched load, for I am grown
Your burthen, that only wou'd have been my own;
Had you preserv'd Hersilia, you had prov'd
Happy to save the person we both lov'd;
But now you are as much unfortunate
To save a wretched thing whom we both hate.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Forgive the mixture which in me appears;
Wrong not my joys, nor yet condemn my fears.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why do you stay, look on those shining Walls,
And think that from those flames Hersilia calls.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: O what a wonder does your Friendship prove!
Forgives ingratitude, and urges love.
—I know not what to do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: —Go, go,
And pay what you to Love and Honour owe.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Then I must stay; for there is nothing due
From Love or Honour justly but to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: All debts to me, to her I thus resign;
Be gone, and think Hersilia's danger's mine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: And leave you thus!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: —If you stay here,
Your formal gratitude will look like fear.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: It is my shame to stay, my shame to go;
Yet not my Virtue, but yours makes it so:
If in these flames I meet my death, they'll prove
As gentle, but more just than those of love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: —What shall I do, my thoughts are tir'd, I find,
With tedious Journeys up and down my mind;
Sometimes they lose their way, sometimes as slow,
Like Beasts o'er-loaded, heavily they move,
Prest by the weight of sorrow and of love.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: So much for this; I'll have no more of these siery trials,
My hair stinks like new burn'd Tinder:
See, she has kept her word.
—Best Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: 'Slife, 'tis not she.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You seem concern'd at some mistake.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: A little, Madam; it was my good fortune
To save a Lady from these flames,
That I expected here: 'twas her Commands
That sent me back, to see what help
Her Father and her Sister might have need of.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: She was not tall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: No, Madam, her beauty and her stature
Shew'd her very young.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are happy, Sir, to be the fortunate preserver
Of so much Innocence and Beauty.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: D' you know her, Madam? or to whom
This wretched House did once belong?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: She was my Cousin, Sir, and that was once
Her Father's Palace: you seem a stranger by these questions.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: I am, Madam, and but arriv'd this minute:
The first thing I almost saw, at least took notice of,
Was this sad Spectacle.

sp.speaker: Mar▪
sp.p: Is all consum'd?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Every one now is 'scapt or perisht,
And need no help, or else are past it:
The last I met with was a noble Gentleman,
Concern'd it seems above the thought of danger;
For he appear'd careless of cracking beams,
And uncheck'd flames: A sudden noise
Without the House call'd him away.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Sertorius! which way, Sir, was the noise?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: 'T was on the other side.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That way Sertorius went, and I must follow.
—Pardon my disturbance, Sir—yet—
—Reason and Honour check my haste—
But our unsteady actions cannot be
Manag'd by rules of strict Philosophy;
There is but part belongs unto our care;
Fortune has right, and title to a share.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Shou'd Fortune count with me unto this day,
She'd find there was a mighty debt to pay;
The Roman Conquest o'er my Country spread,
My Brother lost, or worse, in Triumph led;
Sure such full Empires have no aim or guide,
And those that reach 'em do not move but slide.
Man is too weak to manage with frail sense,
Such a resemblance of Omnipotence.
A Storm at Sea threw me on Italy,
And here I thought to find my death or thee:
Poor Tiridates,—how cou'd fortune prove,
So curst among my woes to mingle love!
Which way to go I know not, nor need care;
I have been us'd to wander in despair.
All by uncertain ways pursue their ends,
And unto every object Reason bends.

div.stage: Enter Emilius, and Tiridates, and followers.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: You have sav'd my Life, brave Tiridates;
Wou'd I cou'd pay you with Hersilia,
That wou'd appear more than a common gratitude.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Hersilia is a happiness beyond
My hopes and merits.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: This fire was kindled by some treachery;
I fear Hersilia is the purchace
Of their designs and mischiefs.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Let us not now waste time with vain conjectures;
Hersilia and Verginia may want help,
While we are talking how they come to need it.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: 'Tis true, let us take several ways,
And meet down by the Tiber, hard by Numa's Grove.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: If I have life I'll bring it thither. Ex. Emil. and followers.
—What did I say! how cou'd I talk
Of carrying any longer life about me!
—But humane things have such variety,
Neither the wise nor brave know when to die;
For neither justly can their deaths intend,
Till they are sure all hopes have first their end.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: —Ha—Tiridates!
He's it seems no happier yet than I.
Stay,—Sir,—what news?

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: None that either of us wish;
Hersilia is for certain forc'd away
By unknown Persons.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: So I have heard.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Emilius has took the great Flaminian way;
Let us divide our selves,—and when—

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Stay, Tiridates; Fortune seems wise in bringing us together,
She knows not what to do with both of us;
In the pursuit of Honour she can be
Liberal to many in one Victory:
When Fame's the Mistress, more than one may prove
Happy at once; but 'tis not so in Love.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: He that blind Fortune will have happy made,
Let her guide him unto Hersilia's aid.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: She shall guide me no farther; you and I
Will not ask her Opinion which shall die;
Our Swords will tell us all that she can know;
Her means are quick, though she her self be slow.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: I draw for my defence, not my design; Draws.
You urge a wrong both to your Love and mine;
While your Revenge above your own does prove,
And force my Honour to exceed my Love.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: 'Tis only Love that does this quarrel breed,
And so my Love my Honour does exceed.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Wou'd Love attempt to ruine its own aid?
We fight for them by whom she is betray'd:
Whoe'er o'ercomes, his guilty Conquest shews,
Hersilia nothing to his Valour owes.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: 'Tis true,—
'Tis against her that I my Sword employ,
And she may want that help which I destroy.
—Forgive me, Sir:—Yet all things that can move,
As well as I, have felt Revenge and Love;
Unruly heats are with our Essence spread,
And by craz'd Passion Nature's cemented.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: While she has Enemies let us be Friends,
And now by several ways pursue our ends.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Stay, I am yet confus'd; 'tis a hard fate
To • elp to make my self unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: We waste that time which takes too fast a slight,
And 'tis more guilt to talk than 'twere to fight.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: How weak these wild distractions make me prove!
I am taught when to fight, and how to love;
Yet one thing more, if in your Breast you have
No mix'd designs but what are clear and brave;
Let us engage, whoe'er is happy made,
To find Hersilia first, and bring her aid,
That he shall make no use of his success,
Nor the least story of his Love express,
Till first by our own Swords our cause is try'd;
It is too great for Fortune to decide.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: To keep this sacred here I freely vow;
You learn'd at first, but teach me Honour now.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Till then let us embrace; whoe'er Love guides
Unto his bliss, for t'other Fate provides.
Now to our Fortunes; I'll pursue the way
Which leads through Numa's Grove.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: —But stay,
Where shall we meet?

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Under those stately ranks
Of Cypress Trees that shade the Tiber's Banks,
Near Mutius's House; for still I apprehend
That Man; he's Mischief's and my Brother's Friend.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.p: Agreed;—in equal hopes now both are tied.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: But when we meet our wishes must divide.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: How ignorant of every thing I move!
I know not where I go, nor what I love:
Yet though she's gone, her Image still I find,
And I pursue what she has left behind.
Ah, my dear Brother,—poor Tiridates!—
Cast on these Shores I came to look out thee,
And by my Bonds or Death to set thee free;
But into other Fetters I am thrown,
Not by my honour but my Love put on.
Quite tir'd I seem, like a hard-hunted Beast,
That does not seem to go, but sinks to rest.
Spent Nature's weight hangs heavy on my Eyes;
Sleep can cure Fevers, why not Miseries?
A Soul's disease can few Physicians find;
For Emp'ricks only practise on the mind:
Yet sleep her Image might convey to me,
And shew in Dreams what I must never see. Enter two of Mutius men with Verginia still in a swoon.
On, on, to the Tiber with her,
And Sacrifice her to Neptune.
The Devil we will;—what,
Go twice as far as we need,
To try to be apprehended for Murderers!
The next Ditch will serve.—Ha,—what's here!
A dead man! 'slife, a most excellent Companion for her;
If he be asleep let him wake and answer for't;
Gently, gently; so, lay her behind him. They lay her behind Artabaces.
So, now to Mutius, and swear she was dead.
I, and cold too.

div.stage: Artabaces after a little time wakes.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Sure 'twas that Beauty which appear'd so bright;
My Eyes by waking rob me of my sight;
When they were shut her Image did appear;
I star'd too boldly sure, and made her fear. Turns and sees her
Ha!—look where she is; alas, I do mistake;
For I dream still, and think I am awake:
Some pitying Pow'r this Vision does bestow,
And helps me to deceive my Sorrow so. She groans.
What's that! my Senses sure are not my own!
Can empty Dreams and airy Visions groan?
Her Eyes begin to move and shine with life,
Now sink again in Death's ungentle strife:
In doubtful Weather, so the Sun resigns
Sometimes his Light to Clouds, and sometimes shines.
She lives again; O cease your Cruelty,
And she'll by that Example pity me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Oh me!
Have I not slept too long, and am to blame,
Neglecting to attend the Sacred Flame?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Here is that Flame to which your Eyes did give
Life first, and promis'd it should always live.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Where are the Vestals then, or where am I?
Some confus'd Thoughts now shake my Memory;
I do remember I was seiz'd upon
By some rude men; I thought there had been none.
Pray, who are you?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: —Alas, I have no Name,
But that which is my Trouble, or my Shame.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sure both my Eyes and Ears deceive me now,
Once I saw something look'd, and spoke like you:
But by my fond Desires he was betray'd;
I ow'd him Life, which with his Death I pay'd.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Those Flames you sent me to, have let me live,
Perhaps reserv'd to dye by those you give.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pray do not wrong me, are you he indeed?
I feel some unknown Joys that do exceed
The usual Measures of my Happiness;
I fear there may be guilt in the excess.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: O do not fear that Pity e'er can prove
A guilt in any, shou'd it grow to Love.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Pity is Love, and then it need not grow.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: In the World's common Charity 'tis so;
Such Love is only in Obedience shown
To those above, the other is our own.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: We shou'd deny our own Affections still.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: These Passions are all Strangers to the Will.
When I first saw your Eyes, my Heart was free.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: O that I cou'd restore your Liberty.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: That way there is no pity to be shown,
Restore not mine, but try to lose your own.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Will that strange way a Remedy procure?
Can a Disease in one, another cure?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: In Love's Disease neither their Cures obtain,
But both grow well by one anothers pain.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I know not what you mean, but I incline
To think that your Misfortunes wou'd be mine.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: May I not dare to wish a little more?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: —Take heed,
Our Wishes may be Faults when they exceed.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Do covetous men, or the ambitious find
Their vast Desires by any bounds confin'd?
If pow'rful Nature lets no Passion move
Within known limits, why alas shou'd Love? Enter the two men of Mutius.
On, on; we are dead men;
Look where she is alive too: O happy Chance.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Help, help, these are the Villains.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Your business, Rascals. He steps before her.
That Woman is our business.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: You shall have her thus, Dogs.

div.stage: Fight, kills one, the other runs, and as he pursues,
Enter Mutius, and others behind him, and seize him.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Unhand me, Slaves.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: O help.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: You call for that you need not.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Slaves, Dogs.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Ha, what's this? Tigellinus dead!
Thy Life for his is justly forfeited

div.stage: Offers to run at Artabaces, she steps between.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O hold, I was the cause that stain'd his Innocence
With that man's blood, for 'twas in my Defence;
Besides, I'm tir'd with Life, and fit to dye.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: There's none so weary of a Life as I;
Yet if you Romans wou'd be thought such men,
Give me a Sword, and try to take it then.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: 'Tis for her sake I do not punish thee.
This Fellow is not to be trusted free; Aside.
Bring him along.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: —Slaves, I will not go.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Drag him along.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: —O, do not use him so.
Alas, what d'you mean?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Why do I stay
Thus trifling? Madam, come, here lies our way.
Bring him alive or dead.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: —Pray hold your hands.
Good Sir, obey their Pow'r, or my Commands.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Come, lead me where you please; how much above
My Reason and my Courage is my Love!

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: STill weeping, Madam? these are unkind Tears,
Love is ill paid with Sorrow, or with Fears.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If Love's ill paid with Grief, it needs must be
As ill exprest by signs of Cruelty.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: It is a Cruelty to my Soul exprest,
Because I keep it Pris'ner in my Breast?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not while 'tis willing, but it wou'd be so
Had it as much desire as I to go.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Since Life and you in me bear equal sway,
Be not less willing than my Life to stay.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If Bondage only does express you kind,
Why does the Stranger such harsh usage find?
Can you pretend that the same act should be
Cruel to him, and yet so kind to me?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: O my vex'd Soul! how true my Fears do prove!
Love betrays me, and she betrays her Love. Aside.
I'll try her yet.—Shou'd I not seem to be
In all things kind, to set this Stranger free?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Alas, what shall I say!—I think you were,
He offers all I wish, and all I fear.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: How brightly her betraying Blushes move,
And seem a glorious Traytor to her Love!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sure when he has his Freedom he'll be gone. Aside.
Shou'd I beg his that am deny'd my own?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: You need not now your Pow'r or Tears employ,
The Stranger does his Liberty enjoy.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: But is he gone already? Can it be?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: What, are you troubled at his Liberty?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Did he not ask to see me ere he went?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: He said not much: I know not what he meant.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Perhaps you did refuse that small Request?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: I cou'd not grant that which he ne'er exprest.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Why, did I owe my Safety to his aid?
O Kindness ill bestow'd, but worse repay'd?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Thou hast betray'd thy self, the Lover's part
I'll act henceforward with a Souldier's Heart.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Alas, what do you mean? What Tempests rise?
The gathering Storms lye rowling in your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: I blush that I have been so calm and tame;
Conquests in Love and War are but the same;
Both reach'd by boldest hands, and Fools alone
Thank Fate or you, for that which is their own.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Alas, what have I done?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: —How cou'd you be
So foolish to think I had set him free?
I quickly found he was too fortunate:
You may cheat those you love, not those you hate.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: O be more gentle.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: —Yes, when you are kind.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Storms hardly will teach Calmness to a Mind.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: You rais'd the Storm which shall his ruin prove,
And he shall owe his Fate unto your Love.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Alas, 'tis your suspicion does engage
Your Fury thus; this Object of your Rage
I never saw, till from the Flames just now
He brought me forth, and gave me Life to owe.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: What Flames were those?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: —Those wretched Flames which burn'd
My Father's House, and all to Ashes turn'd.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: O happy, Hersilia's Sister!
How the kind Fates still nearer Bonds provide,
For me, and for Sulpitius to be ty'd.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Are you not yet appeased? Or can it be,
That Gratitude shou'd cause such Jealousie? Walks musing, she after him.
In gentle Minds, Love takes the most delight;
Rough Natures urge not Passion, but affright.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Come, dry those gentle Show'rs, for there will be
No need of Tears, unless to pity me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Will you no more appear in such a Rage?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: You need not fear the Storms you can asswage:
Teach me by your Example, I shall prove
The aptest Scholar, when I'm taught by Love:
—But I forget Sulpitius:—Who's there?
—Here— Enter 1.
Receive this Virgin with Respect and Care,
Safely till I return, and let her be
Obey'd by you that is ador'd by me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I find his Jealousie has told him true,
And found my Love sooner than I cou'd do;
What shall I say? which will the hardest prove,
To hide my Hate, or to conceal my Love?
How can I practise what I never knew?
And appear false, that so I might be true?
And yet if they shou'd take his Life away—
Will none of these as well as I betray? Looks on the men.
—Is your Captain gone, my Friend?
A little way.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: When will he return?
That's uncertain.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: He was very kind to me;
You know it best, with whom he left
Commands that were so civil.
Yes, I think he did.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I do believe there was no need;
Your Natures wou'd have urg'd you to as much
As I shall beg
What does she mean?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I have a small Request.
Well, what is't?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Nay, do not ask me harshly;
A Kindness may be lessened by the manner.
What the Devil does she mean?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: How ruggedly they look?— Aside.
Yet I shou'd take it well, nay, very kindly.
'Slife, how she tempts!— Aside.
—Well, name it.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: 'Tis only—If they shou'd deny me, Aside.
I know you'll think it but a small Request.
Well, let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I wou'd see the Stranger that was taken with me,
I have a little business with him.
We dare not do it.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Your Captain said you shou'd obey me;
But I wou'd owe it to your Natures,
Rather than his Commands.
'Tis impossible to deny her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yet I wou'd be grateful too; not to bribe,
But to reward your gentle natures.
If we do not take the better care,
She'll make us think w'are honest too.
We can easily convince her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Why d'you delay? pray make more haste to goodness;
Here, divide this between you. o •• exs money.
Do'st think we shall be able to deny her?
'Tis impossible to deny her, and her money too;
Our Captain has a brave prize.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Alas, I fear they will deny me:
Are you not yet resolv'd?—here, pray accept it.
Well, for once we'll strain a point;
Come follow us, we'll bring ye to him:
But 'tis two to one whether he'll speak to you or no;
He's as sullen as a new taken Eagle.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I'll venture that.
My Companion will guide you to the place;
Follow me slowly, for I must step before
And prepare those that guard him.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I thank you, may you find full rewards
In the success of all your just desires: Exit.
When shall the fears of minds concern'd grow less,
I tremble now at my own wisht success:
Courage in great distress can only • id,
But fear of what shou'd help will be afraid.
The Gods from passions might have made us free,
Or gave us only those which best agree;
For such as mine a wretched mingle prove,
The want of Courage, and excess of Love:
They were not jealous sure that we might be
By Vertue rais'd too near Divinity;
For since within their pow'r dwells all our breath,
The distance is preserv'd enough by death.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: That I cou'd fly from every thought I have,
And lie as senseless in my Life as Grave:
I that had pow'r of thousand lives am thrown
In bonds out of the Title to my own. Lies down.
Why did the gods—
Make us so fit for Vice and Misery?
In goodness their immortal Chequers lye;
They might have given our Souls better Estates,
And set our Blessings at far cheaper rates. Enter one of those that went from Verginia, with another Comrade that had the keeping of Artabaces.
Come, come, here's that will conquer
Both thy Fears and Honesty.
If Mutius shou'd return.
Pish, he's engag'd to look Sulpitius;
Besides, he bid us to obey what she desir'd.
Well, let's go to him; to toll thee true,
I pity him; 'tis a brave Fellow.
I cou'd pity too; but we are p •• d too well
To be good-natur'd;—prethee tell him
That one desires to speak with him.
He's horrible surly.—Sir,—
D'hear, Sir? there's one without desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: 'Tis a question whether I'll speak with him or no.
You must needs.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: I am busie, Rascals.
'Tis but a word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: I will not waste half a one, Slaves, for you.
Fetch her in Man; he'll ne'er be perswaded.

sp.speaker: Art
sp.l: What d'you stay for, gentle Sir?
D'you suppose your Company is pleasant?
You'll be made tamer.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Yes, thus Rascals. Starts up.
'Twere a just act to take away your Life,
It troubles you.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l:
Prethee do me but that curtesie, 〈◊〉
• ot,
Lend me the Sword, and see how kind 〈◊〉
He does amaze me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Hold, hold; what's this? why a Sword drawn?
This Madman wou'd provoke his death.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pray hold, you do mistake:— 〈◊〉 he not; Sir?
How he stares on her!
And how his fury slides away—Sir—
—The Lady—Sir—

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Peace, Slaves.—I was co 〈…〉 . Stamps.
What, Sir?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That, Rascal.

div.stage: 〈◊〉 him; the Fellow offers to draw.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pray hold; here, take more; pray hold:
For my sake, Sir, be gentle.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I have done.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pray be gone; you do disturb him. Exeunt.
Why are your furious Eyes so fix'd on 〈◊〉 ?
I do confess I caus'd your misery.
Propose your own revenge, and my just nearst
Against the Life it feeds, will take your part.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Alas, if your just heart so kind 〈◊〉 pro •••
To share in Griefs, teach it to share in Love.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: 'Tis aptest to learn any thing from you.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l:
'Tis strange you shou'd not know the thing y ••
〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sure I shou'd understand w •• t you 〈◊〉 ;

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Fortune, alas, has 〈◊〉 all 〈◊〉 ;
Love seldom is the gift of Misery.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: You said Pity was Love.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Pity is Love when grown into excess.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If that be all, Love is not taught I see;
For before you cou'd speak 'twas learn'd by me.
Sure Nature's Laws are above Heaven's got;
Love need not, though Religion must be taught.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: O speak again; the breath that tells your Love
Approaches like the gentle Winds that move
Over the tops of fragrant Flow'rs, and brings
To the blest Sense their Souls upon their Wings.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Alas, I have said something which I fear
Had such a sound a Virgin shou'd not hear;

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: O do not teach your Love a common way;
Love's power is small, unless it can betray.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: You'll then confess y'ave pow'r enough in me,
If for your sake I'm pleas'd with Treachery.
But tales of Love make us forget our woes;
A sudden fear upon my spirit grows,
Like People that tell tales of Ghosts at night,
So long till they are talk'd into a fright.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Such phancies, from no real cause, will prove
But Dreams, that hinder the repose of Love.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: You call my phancies dreams; but if they are,
All those must wake that do their dreams declare.
Think I am sleeping when you see me sad,
And when I wake I'll tell what dreams I had.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: I cannot find Sulpitius; all's in an uproar.
—Ha!—
What sight is this, at which my stiffened hair
Starts from their shaken roots! I shou'd not stare
So frightened, had I met every Ghost
Started from Hell which Roman Conquests boast.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ah me! what storm is falling on us now?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: No Thunder dwells upon a humane brow.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Yes, you shall feel the Thunder that you slight:
It shews more pow'r to ruine than to fright.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Vain slighted Villain.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: —Pray let me speak;
Perhaps he'll least resist what is most weak:
Pray be not angry; did you not engage
That I shou'd never see you in a rage?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: You Pow'rs, what an ungrateful confidence
This Woman hides with painted Innocence!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Wou'dst thou have thanks for want of liberty?
Which way is gratitude grown due to thee?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: While thou dost speak 'tis with ingrateful breath,
Which I cou'd stisle if I wou'd in death.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Prethee then do.—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: —Cannot my tears incline?
Will you provoke your ruine, perhaps mine?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: I've done; and though death's business I despise,
Yet when you talk that it may close your Eyes,
This too fond heart of mine, that did not fail
At death in gross, shrinks now at the retail.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Come, have ye done? I long till I remove
With him thy hopes, if not destroy thy love.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Hold, hold, your passion guides you to mistake;
Alas, 'tis the wrong life that you wou'd take.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: My just revenge is this way best express'd,
To take that Life away which you love best.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yet hear me speak; Had I no life to pay
To Nature, wou'd you then take his away? Mut. studies.
How plain it is, if Death to him you give,
The reason only is because I live?

sp.speaker: Art
sp.l: Do not on my loath'd Life set such a rate;
It is unkind to plead for what I hate.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: One thing may save all yet;
If you will swear by all that you adore
From hence, never to see each other more.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What shall I do? I fear that this may be
An easie Oath for him, though not for me.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: —Then hear me swear.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Alas, I thought 'twou'd prove
My fears wou'd be far truer than his love.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: By all that's good, thus, in this blest amaze,
I wou'd for ever on this object gaze.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: They trifle with my rage. Without there, ho. Enter one or two.
Here, Take 'em away.
—Hold—be gone with her, but let him stay.
—Now, Sir,
Once more I ask you, will you swear?
You'd best consult with wisdom, and with fear.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Let fear upon the prosp'rous hearts take hold,
Cowards themselves in miseries grow bold.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Fortune, by me, now offers to be kind.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: And raise me on the ruines of my mind;
Though I am sunk, my honour keeps above.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: 'Tis not thy Honour urges, but thy Love.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Those are the same. Poor frighted men at Sea,
To save their lives cast all their goods away.
In storms of Fortune, where there is a strife
Which shall be sav'd Man's Honour, or his Life,
Who wou'd preserve this tottered Bark from fate,
But sink the Vessel to preserve the freight?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: I'll shake thy stubborn Spirit, while I feed
Thy Life with tortures, Death shall death exceed.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Life may be less than Life, as it does waste;
But Death cannot be more than death at last.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Who's there? Enter one or two.
—Here—
Take him away, and shut him up from light,
Let him see nothing but Death's Image, Night.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Thou canst not reach the light that I shall find;
A generous Soul is Sun-shine to the mind.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Be gone,
In the least title he that disobeys,

His own neglect his wretched Life betrays. Ex. with Art.
Manet Mutius.
In what encrease of Tempests I am tost,
Like those in storms afraid of any Coast:
Now every way to me unsafe appears,
Reason has left the Helm, and Love now steers:
Yet one Trick more I am resolv'd to try;
Love's Wisdom is compos'd of Treachery.
—Ho—Corbuio.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Your pleasure, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Fetch Verginia hither.
And send Titus to spy abroad:
And bring what News he can; however
Let him not stay, for I intend at his return,
To look my self after Sulpitius.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: This Fellow sits my humour;
Like Flies he feeds upon the foulest things,
And to the rugged'st places fastest clings.
—But—I forget my Business, I must now
With all that's gentle, smooth a rugged Brow,
And tempt her with feign'd Goodness to believe;
The shape of Vertue still can best deceive.
Those that in faithless Oceans take their way,
Sink in the Storms, but 'tis the Calms betray. Enter Corbulo with Verginia.
She comes.—Now leave us, Corbulo,
But stay within my call. Exit Corbulo.
Still drown'd in Sorrow? sure my Rage appears
As just, and far more gentle than your Tears;
You fear the Storms, yet make the Tempests rise,
While you retain soul Weather in your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Tempests by Show'rs sometimes are laid to peace.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: And when you weep for me, my Storms will cease.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: To shew my Gratitude, I shew my Fears,
And poorly pay the Debt of Life with Tears;
Secure me only this, that he shall live,
Or do not blame the Sorrow that you give.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Does not feign'd Gratitude true Passion hide?
But since only by this it can be try'd,
Here in a sacred Vow my self I tye,
By me, nor by my means he shall not dye.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Now you are gentle,
And as in Tears I paid to him his due,
Now with dry'd Eyes I'll pay my thanks to you.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Your Gratitude might find a better way,
And my kind Vow with one as gentle pay:
'Tis the same Oath which he has took before,
To avoid ever seeing of him more.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If he has swore, alas, what need I swear?
A Vow shou'd be as gentle as a Pray'r.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Can Pray'rs to all alike so gentle be,
Since all the World's Devotions disagree?
None beg the same, the Pray'rs of all the best

Are little more than Curses for the rest.
Enter Corbulo.
—How now—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Titus is return'd, Sir, and says, there is most noise
By Numa's Grove; another joyn'd to him
To scout on either side, might bring you full Intelligence.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: No, I will go my self.—In the mean time
Think, gentlest Maid, how little I deny;
Who ever you command, must live or dye. Ex. with Ver.
—Corbulo,—Come back.—
I have a Business that I dare commit
Unto no Care but thine.—Give out that I am gone,
And with a shew of pity offer Verginia,
To bring her to the Stranger; in the mean time,
I'll place my self to over-hear their Passions:
The Business will be easie.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.p: If 'twere hard, it were all one to me.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Dispatch then, my brave Corbulo,
And send Spurius along with Titus. Ex. Corbulo.
I will search out the Secret of her Heart,
And find that Passion which she hides with Art:
May be 'twas Charity that fear'd his harm,
But Charity does seldom shew so warm.
No, no, such deep Concerns appear above,
All taught Affections, 'tis unlessen'd Love:
When this Disease of Jealousie can find
A way to seize upon a crazy Mind;
Most things instead of help or giving ease,
The Humour feed and turn to the Disease. Exit. Enter Marcellina.
—Hark—
I listen still for Noise to be my Guide,
And want, yet have too much on every side.
—O Sertorius!—
How I pursue, with what uncertainty?
Yet though I lose my way, I follow thee:
Hurried along upon Love's Wings I move,
Pursuing Fate, and am pursu'd by Love.

div.stage: Enter Sulpitius, with Hersilia and others.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Be pleas'd to pardon me, Madam,
I was enforced to lead you a by-way,
Something about; we are nearer a place of safety now.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I wou'd not censure, but this seems to be
A mingle between Force and Courtesie.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Since 'tis so hard to gain your clear belief,
I must be innocent, though it gives you Grief.
Yet for your own sake do not wish to know,
Time is too hasty, and my Tongue too slow:
Why shou'd his Guilt and Mischief blemish me?
Yet Silence seems a vertuous Treachery.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Why do you shew such struglings in your Breast?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Nature and Friendship are at a Contest;
Know then, I wou'd you cou'd, and I not tell,
That Tiridates by Sertorius fell:
You were the Quarrel, and for you they strove
With equal Courage, and with equal Love;
Till Fortune blinder now than ever prov'd,
And deny'd Victory to what you lov'd.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Ha, Tiridates dead!

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: We have no time to talk, or to lament,
Lest we meet Dangers which we shou'd prevent.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Alas, my Grief's the greatest Dangers are:
Who wou'd flye Death, that cannot flye Despair?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Sorrow deceives, that bids you stay and dye;
'Tis from Sertorius, not from Death you flye;
Whose Rage had blown it self to such a height,
It stopp'd not at th' unhappy Princes Fate,
But presently your Father's Palace blaz'd
In circling Flames, which his Revenge had rais'd;
As if 'twere just he shou'd the Ruine prove
Of his own Hopes, that had destroy'd your Love.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Methinks my Love looks mean in Sorrow drest,
Sure 'twou'd shew greater by Revenge exprest.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Though nothing of your Heart you will resign
To me, let your Revenge at least be mine.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: O, Tiridates!
I have condemn'd my self to dye, and grieve;
Revenge does only my short Life reprieve. Enter Sertorius.
Ha, the horrid Monster comes! you Pow'rs above,
Revenge at once Death and an injur'd Love.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Have I o'er-took you Villain with your Prize?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: There's none is over-took but he that flies.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Defend me now, Sulpitius.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: —Ha, does Hersilia want such a •• ?
O Heavens! her Vertue's lost, or she's betray'd;
I will not trisle out my Cause with words.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Let my Revenge and Wrongs assist your Sword.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: What Riddle's this! she courts his Treachery?
Then through their Deaths I thus must haste to dye.

div.stage: Enter Marcellina, takes up his Sword, and hurts another that is running at Sertorius; he turns, and she and he fight, and Marcellina kills him, and then falls her self: In the mean time, Sulpitius and the rest wound Sertorius so, that they fall together.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: What, do I see? Marcellina!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hersilia!

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.l: Come, we must not stay,
All is unsafe, and pity will betray.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Hear my last words, have so much Charity;
My Life was yours, but here 'tis just I dye;
I feel new Fires, my ancient Flames appease,
And I own Health unto a new Disease.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Do'st thou not shrink at thy approaching Fate?
Are all my Sorrows and his Blood no weight?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: What Sorrows do you wear? Or what's my Crime?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: We trifle out our Safety with the Time.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Stay—let me tell him.—

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: ——'Tis in vain, • away.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: That Villain does betray you.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: ——Hold, I will stay • .
O, Marcellina! O, Tiridates!

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: ——What is the mystery?
Why do you call on them from whom you fly?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: What does he say?

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: ——He raves, • o matter what.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I'll hear him speak.

sp.speaker: Sulp.
sp.p: ——Away, it is too late.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: What can this mean?—farewel my unjust Fires,
New warmth grows in me, though my Life expires.
How slow I crawl? my Love would make more haste,
But weakned Nature cannot move so fast.
My sinking Soul this bleeding Current drowns;
How equal we are now in allout Wounds;
O speak, and tell me if you can forgive;
Or if that be too much, tell me yo • live.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I wou'd deny you nothing; shou'd I say
I live, Life while I tell it steal • away.
Be not concern'd; Death has the s • me event,
By Nature call'd, or brought by accident.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: Do not so willingly your Life resign;
Or if you must, let your Soul go with mine.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It will go softly, if it goes before,
And wait for yours, where they shall part no more.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: And shall we thus know one another there?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Else we shou'd want a Blessing we have here.

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.l: O guide your Hand to mine, 'tis almost Night.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Here, where is yours?

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: ——Searching to find yours out.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have it I now? Weakness and Love may doubt.
Hold fast,—farewel.—There's something— • id •• .

sp.speaker: Sert.
sp.p: 'Tis Death, that kindly thus it self divides.

div.head: ACT. V.
SCENE. I.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: WHY to our Bodies are the Gods more kind,
Than to the Place where Worship dwells, the Mind?
Nature provides Defence, and yi •• d • R • treat
From piercing Cold, and from th • se • rching Heat;
But for the Passions which about us wait,
There is no means allow'd prop •• tionate.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Are you busie, Sir?

sp.speaker: Art
sp.p: O wondrous busie.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Why I was thinking that the World's ill ballanc'd,
More Knaves than honest Men.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: An honest Man wou'd then be welcome sure.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Not to this place.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: To you, I hope.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Troth I have but little business for him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Do you not want a curtesie?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Yes, and one to do it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Pray try me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: With all my heart;—help me to a Sword.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: That's hard.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: So are most curtesies; prethee do me an easie one▪

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Be gone, and leave me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I wou'd first willingly do something for you,
And wou'd help you to a Sword too;
But they are too suspitious at this time,
Strict Spies are set on you;
Somewhat more liberty is allow'd the Lady.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: The Lady!—ha—didst thou not say the Lady?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes, I did.—It takes.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Cou'd you help me to speak with her, or see her,
Though but for a book or two?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Um'h.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That's too hard too.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No, I will do't.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Are you sure of it?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Stay there a little, and you shall see.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: This Fellow sure has inclinations to be honest.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 'Tis done; watch there.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: My best Corbulo.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: I have been thinking
Why those above, so full of tenderness,
Made ways so hard to good and happiness:
Through Graves we travel to felicity;
The road unto Religion's misery.
The ways might have been easier to find out,
Not left so rugged, and so far about:
To every object we submit our sense,
And call our accidents their providence.
There is no satisfaction here below,
But such as Chance or strange extreams bestow:
Secure Content can only be acquir'd
By bruitish minds, or such which are inspir'd,
Where Reason must not come, or can't encline,
Sunk unto Beasts, or rais'd to be divine.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Then, Sir, now believe.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: H'as don't indeed.
Just so when welcome light begins to rise,
An unknown Comfort steals on troubled Eyes.
Here let me kneel for ever in this place,
And cling like Ivy to my first embrace.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Alas, in sorrow shou'd we plant our Loves!
Prisons are barren Soils where nothing proves.
Joys may spring up and make a little shew;
But fastning roots in prosperous places grow.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Love may, like Vertue, starve in full content:
Misfortunes are their noblest punishment.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If Love fares well, do not his Feasts betray,
While Death stands ready to take all away:
Let rather Art and Wisdom act their parts,
And hide our Love from all things but our hearts.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Dull order takes from Love its edge and grace;
He stumbles in all steps but his own pace;
His sacred liberty is in Fetters tied,
When Art or Wisdom his loose steps wou'd guide.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Perhaps there is a way to set you free.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Can I be so, and you want liberty?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Do but at least comply with my design;
For here your Life's in danger more than mine.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Without your sight my Life is less secure;
Those wounds you gave your Eyes can only cure;
No Balm in absence will effectual prove,
Nature provides no Weapon-salve for Love.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Might you but live a Pris'ner still with me,
It were unkind to wish your liberty;
'Tis offer'd from my love,—and yet I find Sighs.
You that deny to take it seem more kind.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: 'Tis I must bring you freedom at the last.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: O hold, remember what a Vow you past,

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: It is thy falseness makes me call it back;
No Vows so strong but just revenge will crack.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Revenge will be no plea to those above.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: But they will hearken unto injur'd Love.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: The gods will hear no business comes from thee.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: I'll send you on my errand.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: —Oh through me
Guide your kind Sword:—Methinks your looks appear He pauses and studies.
To me at least more gentle than they were.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: O yes, I am grown very tame, and now
I think on't better, I will keep my Vow.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: The Gods reward what I can never pay.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Hold, hold, take all together when you pray;
For you shall see me take such wondrous care,
That neither of you both shall need to swear.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: —Without there, ho, Corbulo.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: O treacherous Slave.—

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: —Yes, y'are in the right;
Since you were squeamish to forswear her sight,
I will secure your Eyes without your Vow.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Oh Sir, by all—

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: —Nay, no dissembling now:
Take him away, and on his charming sight
With burning Irons fear eternal night.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: How, burn out his Eyes!

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Yes, burn out his Eyes.

Do ••
Corbulo demur at Cruelties?
No more, be gone.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: —O hold, he bids you stay.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: He stays to meet his death that dares delay.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Farewel, fair Vestal;
By my Soul's Eyes your Image shall be seen;
And when 'tis dark without, I'll gaze within.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O stay, I know you will relent, you must;
Need you be cruel, when you shou'd be just?
Preserve your Vow without your Cruelty;
And do not make your Sin your Piety.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Begone, I'll practise what you taught before.
I'll shew no pity, nor ask yours no more.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: But you may want pity from those above.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Not now, since they deny'd it in your Love.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: They'll make me pay, if you will make me owe.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: You are too cunning, and the gods too slow. Enter Corbulo.
How now, is't done?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.p: Ha!—the reason, Slave?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I think such horrid business was not in our bargain.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Pitiful Rascal, take that soft reward; Strikes him.
I'll trust such tender Slaves no more.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Am I thus paid?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Alas, what does he mean to do?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Mischief, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Look on my wrongs, or your own injury;
Revenge on him will prove pity to me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
