sp.p: And shou'd his Glories, Sir, spring from my shame?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Suppose your Father does my joys design.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wou'd he to purchase Honour, ruin mine?
Yet his Commands make not my guilt the less,
For Heaven allows no pious wickedness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy Father shall both Life, and Honours owe
Unto thy vertues; fair Maria, know
A miracle is done, I more admire,
And inlarg'd Love grows grows from confin'd desire.

div.stage: Enter the Duke of Medina gazing at them.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: What blasting sight is this? I must
Disturb him, with an unwelcome piece of Duty.
Sir,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh, my Uncle!

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I was afraid, Sir, that you were not well.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Not well?—wou'd you be a Physician?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: With all my heart, Sir, wou'd you let me practise,
And wou'd prescribe such wholsome Medicines to you
As should prevent this great Distemper
Growing on you and all the Nation.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The Nation!

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Yes, the Nation, Sir, that will of you
Demand their King, when you have lost him
In Lerma's Charms: Think of your Father, Sir,
Who did despise that any Favourite
Shou'd be a lawful Traytor by permission;
And usurp all the Power.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I mean Lerma, Sir, whose wicked hand
Grasps at your painted Scepter; that Lerma
That was to sink into the lowest banishment
Is creeping up into your Throne, and Power.
That he had never twisted with my Sister,
And like a Snake begotten such a Viper,
Whose sliding to your bosome will but leave
A sting upon your Conscience, and disturb
The ashes of her sleeping Mother.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Though your bold Duty might receive a pardon
For any large discourse; know yet,
(That ignorantly you may not snatch your Fate)
All injuries to Maria's virtues,
Shall be forgiven as I wou'd a malice
Studied to blast my Honour.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: My Life, Sir, is a thing you once believ'd;
I did despise to ballance with your service.
For her, Sir; Nature be my witness,
I wou'd preserve her full as vertuous
As I believe her wretched Mother was,
But then she must not, Sir, be the foul means
To charm your sacred Breast, to breath our Honours
On every thing that is but Lerma's Creature,
Whose hungry Poverties must eat as deep
As Famine to the Nation. Honours, might Sir,
When they meet Fortunes, are support's to Thrones,
But joyn'd to Poverty are the shakers of it▪
And wasting Crowns sink with such deep Consumptions.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I can give no greater Testimony
That all your former services to my Father
Are not forgotten, than to pardon you now.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: If this, Sir, that I say, be an offence,
That I wou'd have none to be King but you,
Take your forgiveness back; for I must live
A Traytor by your Mercy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: If you despise our Mercy.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Oh Sir, upon my Knees I beg it rather,
But 'tis for all your Kingdom, not for me:
Think, Sir, what 'tis to sit upon your Throne
Without your Thunder; only so much left
As a swell'd Favourite will please to lend you
sp.stage: Enter Lerma, whispers to the King.
sp.l: To hurl at honest Truths; so, he may speak,
And at this idle time sure you may hear. To Maria.
What is your Father turn'd your careful Bawd?
For his ambitious ends he wou'd have been
So to thy Mother too, but that her vertue
Had an unshaken soundness; thou art rotten
As he that did beget thee; only Nature
Painted thee over with a fair resemblance
Of her blest Image, wou'd it were blotted out.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha! she weeps, that insolent Man
That dares draw tears from fair Maria's Eyes,
Shall drop his blood as fast: Without there, my Guards.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let mine, Sir, drop, before you shed my Uncle's.
Think how the World would Curse me, when they hear
Medina's love to Vertue, lost his Life.
He talkt to me of nothing but of goodness;
And when he spoke of that, (as he must needs)
He nam'd my Mother, and by chance I wept.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy vertue is too excellent, let thy goodness
Punish him for the injuries he did thee,
Though I forgive him; and hence forward To Medina.
I will send for you when I want your Council,
Till then, forbear my sight.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Mighty Sir;
Perhaps his wild and unbecoming passions
Had their beginnings from an ill-tim'd Duty.
(If boldness to a Sovereign may be call'd so)
Yet I dare swear, his Loyalty is perfect,
Though my fond Nature is a partial surety
For what I love.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Oh, spare your partial kindness, good my Lord;
'Tis your old Craft to whet your sharpest Weapon
Upon pretended Friendship; and cut a Throat,
As smoothly, as if it were good manners.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No more, lest your rude breath raise an anger
More fatal than your snarling: from hence be
Duke of Lerma, and your next Friend, what you
Will call him—Come, Maria,
At thy fair sight my blushing anger shrinks
As if some Angel from above descended,
Whose powerful Vision made all passions cease
But only Love, still waited on by Peace.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: What a look was there
To out-stare honesty?
Sure he practises to set his eyes,
As some do Guns to make 'em carry right,
But he can take no aim, but at the fearful;
Those he may hit perhaps; his full-charg'd eyes
Will hardly carry level to brave minds.
I must do something, I think it is no Treason,
To snatch a King from falling down a precipice:
But in Maria's eyes, lies Lerma's power,
And I must find a way to put those Lights out.
Nor will I leave to help him one small spark,
Then let him grope for power in the dark.
sp.stage: Enter D' Alva, Alcar. and Bruchero.
sp.p: How now, my Lords, do you seek any thing?

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: The King, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: He's lost.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: Does not your Lordship know which way he went?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Wou'd you find the King?

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Look in his Father's Grave then; for his ashes
Do yet retain more Majesty than he.
If you look after him that shou'd be King.
You may perhaps find him in Lerma's pocket.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: We are miserable.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: It tamely adds to misery to talk on't,
Like hearts weaken'd with griefs, that spend
Faint sorrows on their dying friends,
When they should strive,
Rather to give them help; my worthy Lords,
Were all your Courages, and Wisdoms ready
To snatch at any honest opportunity
That fortune offers: keep near the King,
And cross him not, till you hear more of me:
Something I'll do to merit from you all,
At least, deserve your pity, if I fall.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.l: Heaven prosper and direct you;
This man's Soul is greater than his Title.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: We have new Titles.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: And likely to have more, all the Spawn
Of that poor slave, Caldroon, must be
Call'd Something, as well as he is now,
They say, a Marquis.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.l: The Queen! her looks are full of sorrow,
All is not well.

div.stage: Enter the Queen and Catalina with Ladies.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: Royal Lady.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Is your Majesty not well?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Ha! I was thinking of the King.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: What of him, Madam?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I know not what, but yet he lately seeks
Retirements from his Friends, and from himself.
A fatal sadness grows upon his youth
And makes him haste (before it comes) to age.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: He has ill Council, Madam.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: From Lerma too.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: I thought e'er now, he had been banish'd.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: He'll banish us all, if his power holds.
He hangs in the King's bosom like his Crucifix,
And with no less an Adoration.
He may be safe in power, that can beget
Those beauteous Charms that have subdu'd the King,
Power seems to grow, nay, grow his own Inheritance.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: We must quickly try to prevent
This growing danger to us all, and Spain.
Where's Medina?

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: Shall he be sent for?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Ha!—I feel a coldness creeping in my veins;
What haste it makes to my griev'd heart.—
Ah, me!

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Carry her in, this news The Queen is carried off.
Has troubled her.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I am suspicious of all Accidents.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.l: These fainting fits seem as if she were
With Child.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: With Death I fear.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: How now, how does the Queen?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: I fear there is as little hopes now left,
As signs of life; just as we laid her on the bed,
She fetcht a heavy groan mixt with a sigh,
I fear all the small stock of breath
That she had left.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: This is sudden.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: 'Tis sit your Lordship know all my suspicion;
I doubt, she's poyson'd, this fatal day:
There came a Fryer with a face unknown
To the Queen's Ante-chamber;
To all, a stranger, and to the Queen her self;
By him, a Letter was deliver'd to her,
Which had no name, but in its matter fair:
When she had half read o'er the fatal Paper,
Her eyes seem'd to grow weary, and pulse
Kept an uneven, and a heavy time, and then
Just as you saw her now, she fainted.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: What became of the Fryar?

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: 'Tis not yet known; for in this hurry,
While every one was careful of the Queen,
He vanisht.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: 'Twas poyson on my life.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.l: 'Tis evident, we must make further
Search into't.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: You must assist us, Madam; and by your faith
Revenge the murder of your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cata.
sp.l: Doubt not my Faith or Secrecy,
I must return, I fear, to a dead Woman.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: Here's a strange Relation:

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: It must be kept with secrecy:
We are hunted, and the toyls pitcht about us.

div.stage: Enter to them, Caldroon, the Archbishop of Toledo.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: See the new Indian Stars.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: Silence, he gapes; a Proclamation sure.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: The Duke of Lerma, Constable of Spain;
By Father Francisco late. Confessor to
His Majesty, now Archbishop of Toledo,
And me Roderigo del Caldroon, Marquiss
Of Mirida; and Treasurer of Spain;
Commands thee, Philip Duke D' Alva,
Don Pedro, Marquiss of Alcara;
And Don Bruchero, Great Major Domo;
Within an hour to meet in Council.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: Here's a Volley of Titles.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: We must inform you further, of
The Queen's Death.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: The Confessor should have told us that.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: The Archbishop, you forget your self:

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Markt ye that, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: Why, my Lords, the truth is nothing lessen'd
In my Report.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: No nor the sadness: we shall attend the Constable.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: I do not like that word of Alcara.

div.stage: Exeunt D' Alva, Alca. and Bru.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: Pish, 'tis a fond fear, who shou'd
Reveal it to him? he slept not since
'Twas done, and cou'd not dream it.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Wou'd 'twere undone.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: Oh, your treacherous Conscience
Wakes too late; who shou'd betray it?

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: The disguiz'd Fryer.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: He was ignorant of what he carry'd.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: I have some business that commands
Me hence, the rest your self can mannage.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: Be constant, or you loose us— Exit.
I like him not, this scrupulous Church-Man
Has a shrinking Liver, that stops the motion
Of his bloud sometimes, and such another
Fright, may like an Earthquake
Shake him into discoveries of all;
A blush, in such a case as this,
Is Evidence sufficient for a Jury.
But I'll confirm him, or send his faint
Contrition to th' other World, and he
Shall be the Messenger.
He must be held in use, or he will rust,
We must find mischiefs out to keep him busie,
Lest he have time to think how to be good;
Leisure begets relapses in his Blood:

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Caldroon, followed by Angelo, and Medina thrusts him by and Enters.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: STand by, Sir, methinks your well pac'd,
Greatness might move a little.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: For whom?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: For me, thou ill-drest Puppet of Authority;
Thou Stalking Property, that walk'st on Screws,
Which but laid by, thy Honour is unjoynted,
And grows as bedrid as the Impotent.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: You shall be answer'd.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Thou Mist, exhal'd from Dunghils,
Whose thick Breath poysons the purer Air
It mingles with.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: You are very bold.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I will be bolder, and knock your Greatness,
Without you study quickly a Set-form,
To ask Forgiveness in.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: My Honour can defend it self
From worse Opposers.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I'll mince your Honour.
And send your Lowsie Family the Shares
Of your divided Greatness.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: Hold, this place is not for Quarrels.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Nor for Wrongs.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: How was't?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Let met speak, that dare tell truth.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: When I relate the manner, it shall be
To those that have the power to punish.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Let me go.
There's nothing that has a lawful Birth,
That can endure this mongrel Greatness.

div.stage: Enter the Duke of Lerma, leading Maria Veil'd, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: What Hurry's here?

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: I know not, the Duke Medina thinks
His Greatness Entitles him to Injure
Any one.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: I'll blow him and his Storms quickly away.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Is your Breath so powerful, that it can
Puff Men off like tops of Thistles?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: I cannot now spare so much time
As to lose any on your Brawls.

sp.speaker: Caldroon.
sp.p: I have Employment for you.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: And for that piece of
Night-work too I take it.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: Pray peace, my Lord

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Let me go, I will but ask him
A civil Question.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Whether great Men, and Fathers too
Are not the best and closest Bawds?

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: Fye, fye, consider who they are.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: 'Tis that consider'd doubles every wrong:
Had I been sindg'd with Lightning, I had stood
With all my Wrongs hush'd as unwindy Night;
But to be scorch'd thus by a Candles Snuff,
A thing that only blazes in expiring,
And which must dye in its own noisomness:
Makes my Impatience swell above the Banks
Of common temper.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.l: You must restrain this Fury, whose effect
Turns to your own destruction.

div.stage: Enter the King, with a few.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: The King.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I will speak.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: Take heed, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Which way went Lerma?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Headlong, Sir, and 'twill be dangerous
To follow him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I was your Souldier once, Sir,
And had Commission to destroy your Enemies;
And I have done it with my Sword as boldly
As I will now attempt it with my Tongue:
And 'tis against a greater Enemy
Than ever Fortune brought me to oppose
In all your Battels.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What Enemy is this?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: So great a one, that he's now become
More Terrour to your Souldiers, than those Armies
They always met, with Noble hopes of Conquest.
Here Victory is lost already: for Lerma
Has took you Captive.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis boldness, and not duty, to question
Prince's Favours.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: But not to beg 'em, Sir, no more than 'tis
To pray, that Heav'n wou'd turn a Vengeance from us,
Threatning in Lerma's power: Do not forget,
Great Sir, the last Desires your Father made,
And force him to call louder from his Grave.
Turn, mighty Sir, your Looks the other way,
And see your widow'd People want their King,
Drooping like Days unlook'd on by the Sun.
Your Councel wither'd more with Care than Age,
Grown as much Strangers to your great Affairs,
As unto Lerma's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: Excellent! 'tis nobly honest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Must Prince's Favours then be limited,
Or judg'd by common Breaths?
'Tis restless Envy, that urges Mutinies
Shelter'd under duty.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: So the Lesson is learn'd perfect.
Oh Impudence! to make the Majesty of Kings
The Pawn of all their Villanies.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.l: Brave Lord, though I grieve to see you prest
Thus into needless dangers; yet I must
Joy, that our Country can yet boast such worth.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: O my Lord, so wretched are we growing,
I tremble to out-live our Happiness:
Those that wou'd always live among Diseases,
Ventures not more for Life than I for Death.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.l: Nay, my brave Lord,
You shall see all your Friends dare share
With equal Courage the worst Fate;
For wisely to go back is now too late.
My Jealousies are just, lend me your aid,
And we may dive into the heart of all.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: And into his that wrought these Mischiefs too,
In greater privacy I'll utter more;
Let us be firm, and like a mighty Weight,
Sinking our selves, press others to their Fate.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter the King and Maria, with two Papers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is a thing of great Concern Maria,
And I should have the Opinion of my Councel.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your Councel, Sir? are you their Sovereign,
Or wou'd you be a Slave to their Opinions?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But if▪

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If what?
Dull Majesty, is this the loudest Tune
Of a King's powerful Breath? If's and but's,
The timorous Language of the meanest people,
That are to give account of their low Actions
Unto Authority: Princes Determinations
Shou'd be as free as they design their Power;
Not shaken with the Aguish touch of Doubts:
What Tracts leave the great Ocean? Or, who questions
Why it is calm, or rages? Who shall chide
The Sun that warms one portion of the World,
More than another? When you are absolute
In Love or Power, then I'll beg again.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stay, I have resign'd my Reason to
My Love, give me the Warrants.—
—Now think, Maria, The King signs them▪
Whether you have not ask'd too much
Of one you love so little.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Have you done it, Sir?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: You see I have.

sp.speaker: Mra.
sp.l: Do you not repent it, Sir?
Nor hate me as an Instrument,
Of pressing you to Acts, unworthy of you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh Maria, 'tis hard for me to hate,
As 'tis for you to love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But have I not amaz'd you, Sir?
In pressing you so hastily unto an Act
Of such Importance?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: A little.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thus low I beg your pardon;
And by this measure see to what dangers
Princes expose themselves, and Crowns
By too much trust, and kindness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How's this?
Have you then acted, what you thought amiss?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have, Sir, by necessity, not choice;
My Father's violence had took another way.
More fatal, had I not gain'd from you
These Governments, as he designs to send
Away the Marquess of Alcara, and
Count Bruchero.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now have I set before you, Sir, a Mirrour,
That truly shows—
—How fatal 'tis for Princes,
To shine on any with contracted kindness.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Whither must all this tend?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For he that does engross your Beams
Robs others of your Light, and is a Cloud
That hangs upon your brightness; breeding
Ill weather to all the World be •• des; while he seems
To make you practise power unlimited;
Just then you have the least, obeying his.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Excellent Woman!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: From henceforth, Sir, be every body's King,
And then you are your self: lend equal ears
To what all say, and like a skilful Chymist
Draw the quick spirit off, from every Counsel,
And from your wise breast breath it as your own.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh, Maria! you set foundations for my
Love, upon my reason now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: One thing more I have to beg,
And then (my Father's Life only excepted)
It is the last I'll ask: these Warrants, Sir,
I will deliver to my Father; but in the mean time
Those Lords shall have private directions,
A little to defer their preparations;
If you dare trust me, Sir, it is your safety
I study now: pardon my foolish fears,
Your danger only nam'd, calls forth my tears.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh, do not waste the treasure of your eyes,
For such a life that you so much despise,
While I more justly disobey in this,
To dare be careless of the thing you wish.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Can you my heart for want of friendship blame,
That for your safety have expos'd my fame?
Love to your glories, shou'd his flames resign,
As fires their Light, when the bright Sun does shine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: If Thrones be Seats for Cares, in a King's Breast
Love has a Title sure among the rest:
My love, as a fair Vertue I proclaim;
When it grows foul, I will conceal my shame.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ah, 'tis some ease to love, to be confest,
But, 'tis a torment, when it is supprest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Do's cruelty, a sign of kindness, prove?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It is the greatest to deny the Love.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Both cannot suffer in one cruelty.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I sho'd confess too much, shou'd I deny.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Wou'd you more cruel than you are appear?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, be gone, I've said too much I fear.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Maria—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: —If you have pity, Sir, be gone,
Leave me to blush a little while alone.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Farewel, I'll love, though you shou'd still design
To hide your own, and ne'er to pity mine.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Among what Rocks I steer a dangerous course,
My duty to a King, and to a Father;
My Countries shaken honour, and my own,
Calling at once upon me to take heed:
There's something more than this, yet, shakes my heart,
But I will throw the Ague off, lest I
That to direct others their way design,
Shou'd my self want a friend, to show me mine.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: Have you prevail'd?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—but—

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: No matter for a Reason, or a Circumstance,
Give 'em me; and still maintain thy power,
That I may pay Allegiance to thy eyes;

So now retire, for the Court begins to fill. Exit Maria.
Enter Alcara and Bruchero.
They come, she was dispatcht in happy time.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: See the full sail of Spain.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: Strike, and pass by.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: The King by me salutes you.

div.stage: Lerma throws them the Warrants, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.l: This was a running Lottery,
Mine's a good prize, the Vice-Roy Ship of Naples.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Mine, of Navarre—

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.l: Why, this great man drops Kingdoms
As a full-plum'd Hawk mews her loose Feathers,
And never cares who stoops to take 'em up.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: He has some other meaning in't.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.l: 'Tis certain his bounty else had never
Showr'd on us.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: See, these are of his Council.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: And now come sweating with their fond complements.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: My Lords, you are much engag'd
Unto his Grace, the Duke of Lerma.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: We have the Bonds about us.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: Oh, such another friend as Lerma,
The Earth holds not.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: 'Tis believ'd.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Had you but seen, how he implor'd the King,
Pleaded your worths, and your abilities;
I think you wou'd have thought, as now you may,
Nature had ti'd him to you in some bond.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: The Duke is, as he ever was,
Covetous to scatter Favours, though unask'd.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I, and so careful of the Men he marks
To make Election of in his great Thoughts,
That when they sleep, he wakes to make 'em great.
As I dare swear you never thought of this.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: Not I, I vow to you.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: I hope, my Lord, it shall not be forgotten:

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: That were too foul Ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Oh, never, my Lord; and to assure the Duke—

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: 'Tis well, so may you prosper.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: What think you now?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Tis Rank—you and I, my Lord,
Are busie, and stand too much in his way;
Our remove will give his Actions scope.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.l: H'as wove his curst Inventions cunningly.
How he threw his guilty Favours to us;
And durst not stay to take our Thanks,
Here's more Intelligence, see the Duke. Enter Medina, leading Izabella veil'd.
He has got something too.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Your way's now clear: there's one
Will bring you to your Attendance—
Remember to bring Maria to the Garden
At the appointed time.

sp.speaker: Izab.
sp.p: I will not fail on my part.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: You have got a fair Charge, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: When you know all, you'll say so.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: We two, my Lord, are banish'd.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Banish'd?

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: But to honourable Employments.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: We have trifl'd then too long;
And suffer'd this black Cloud to grow too big,
Whose breaking will drown us all.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: See here the Sentence of our Banishments.

div.stage: Enter a Woman veil'd, puts a Letter into Alcara's hand, and Exit. Alcara reads, and seems amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: What's this that vanish'd?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Some secret Invitation.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: How now, man, what not impart
It to your Friends?

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: Yes, read.

div.p: To the Marquiss of Alcara.

YOU and your Friend Count Bruchero, will receive two Patents for your honourable Banishment, 'twill not be unpleasant to the King, if you pretend Sickness or Business to defer going to your Employments: This Advice admire not at, but follow.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: The Advice is good, no matter who sent it.
Nor could it come from any common hand,
The Business is too young to be acquainted
With any thing but one that knew its birth.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: 'Tis true, and we must put it off.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: And yet it may prove dangerous.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: The danger's only in accepting it.
If we disperse our selves, he'll catch us up,
Like a flowen Covey; besides, the Letter says,
The King will not be displeas'd: there is some Mole,
That heaves for us unseen; Count Bruchero,
You shall pretend, that to prevent all Rumours,
You'll perfect your Accounts before you go.
You, my Lord, must pretend sickness,
And seem to keep your Chamber;
Prescribing to your Doctors a Receipt,
To make them say as you do, and in hard words
Set forth a dangerous Distemper.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: Good; but what success attends on this?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: That we must wait for, honest designs
Justly resemble our Devotions,
Which we must pay, and wait for the Reward:
Yet this I'll add, to strengthen your resolves,
I have some designs, I think cann't fail me,
Shall shake the great foundation, Lerma laid;
We search deep Mines, and if the veins but hold,
We purchase all the Wealth we wish to have,
And if it fails, we dig a noble Grave.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: Mischiefs, with Plagues, engender every where,
And beget new Diseases; the Queen's Murder
Is more than whisper'd now; and the Duke's Daughter
Is Indian talk, the 'tother World is full on't,
And, which is more than all, the Messenger
That brought that fatal Letter to the Queen,
In which her death was seal'd; is by Medina
Sent for in private: whom we thought asleep,
But wak'd too soon, before our careful Friend
Cou'd stop him in his close attempt.
The Storm has overtook our greatest speed.
Nor can the Duke himself find out a shelter:
I'll instantly entomb my new got wealth
In a disguis'd Chappel which I've consecrated
To my dead Ancestors; that may save me yet;
'Tis pity to take ill pains to rake up wealth,
Which at the last can purchase us no more
Than a mean life, which we enjoy'd before. Enter Lerma and the Archbishop.
The Duke, and trouble in his face,
I'll step aside a little.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: Said he, he would not go?

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Till his Accounts were level'd.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: And Alcara is sick?

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: 'Tis so given out.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: They have me in the wind,
There is some secret trick in this, or else
They durst not slight me thus; it must be so,
My violent motion grows already slow:
I'll weather falls about me, every way
I try to take, proves heavy travelling.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: The peoples cries grow loud.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: The gaul'd Rascals wince at my oppressions,
They are like swarms of Bees, when up and buzzing
They light on any thing; Alcara, and Bruchero
That dare dispute their Sovereign's Command,
Give Language to their murmurs, I have striv'd
In Hunters toils like a fierce Lybian Lion,
And am grown weaker by my strugling.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: The King hears nothing of all this.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: No, Maria's Charms hang yet about his Senses;
But all this weight will stretch Love's bonds; whose ties
Are weakly twisted between gazing eyes.
A little distance or some new Object
May set his heart free and unravel al •

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: 'Tis dangerous.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Extreamly; besides, I fancy, she grows
Dark to my business, and has starts
As if she wou'd lose me before her Honour.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: No way but what we last resolv'd on,
And that out-does the soul of all invention.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: I'm ready for the Journey.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Your safety is included in my peace,
Which with like care, all my designs propose.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: The way for my departure's made already.
And the feign'd Letters from his Holiness,
Show'd and allow'd by the King's great Council.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: 'Tis well, this Pacquet then determins
All the rest, and now, my Lord, cut through
The tardy time, and let your expedition kill my doubts:
While I at home will fan away these fears,
Till this hot weather changes; so farewel.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Farewel, keep the storm off till then,
With the advantage of the Sun, you hold,
And my return shall be swift as your thought.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Farewel, and prosper. Enter Caldroon with Letters.
Ha! thy face is full of News.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: Such as I wish I had not:
Is the Archbishop gon—
I dare not show my Letters—

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: But now dispatcht.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: But now?—Humh!

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Thou fright'st me with thy Accents,
Why that Humh?

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: Nothing, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: Thou lyest.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Ha! dost thou swell, that art my creature?
Thy breath is nurtur'd from my bounty;
Why art thou then a Traitor to my trust.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: My Lord, you do amaze me.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Why dost thou hide such necessary truths,
And ruine all my Plots for want of knowledge?

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: I love your Peace so well, I dare not utter it▪

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Why, Caldroon?
What craven temper hast thou found in me?
What chill cold standing blood without a tide?
That thou shou'dst think I know what 'tis to fear:
Thou'st seen me sight against a destiny,
Which I have turn'd, by wise and bold designs;
Thou'st seen me poorer than the Cheeks of Famine,
Less lov'd and follow'd than infected Towns:
Could'st thou then witness once, in all these hazards,
That Fate could triumph in one sigh of mine.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: Alas, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Pitty me, if thou seest me tremble at it;
Come, I will know it all: and, tell it me,
In the most horridst Language thou canst study;
For I am skilful, and can tune all terrors.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: My Lord, this packet first is a sad witness
Of too much danger.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: His colour changes.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: Keep in, false Fear, he must not see thee:

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: His blood flies up and down, the storm has tost it.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, does this trouble thee?
Let 'em all like creeping Snakes hiss at me,
I have a charm yet left shall dead their stings;
Yet it was fit I should know all this:
What more is there?

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: Much, my Lord—for—

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Let it alone; Attend me in my Closet,
There I'll satisfie thee better.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: I'll attend your Grace—

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Now, heart, I give thee leave to sigh, and swell,
My thoughts must not be judg'd by these base Slaves
Who hang upon my Fortune, not on me;
Such Instruments, like flatter'd Princes,
Must never hear but of Prosperity;
Vertue can singly stand on its own trust,
But Passions must depend on truth of others.
Our hopes of Victory on mean Mens valours,
Ambition upon base and wretched Instruments,
On Women Love, more treacherous than all;
Yet in despight of my curst Enemies,
I'll find a Conquest in a safe retreat,
And though they rise, I'll sink to be as great.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: YOu're welcome, and I dare trust your goodness;
Since it can share with me in my condition,
Which is a bitterness well gilded only.

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: I never shall deceive you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Perhaps I may do you, and all the World
Who thinks I doat upon my splendid shame.

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The Character which I have had of you
Gives me a confidence I've found a Friend
That I may weep to; sorrow's like a Child
Which loves to be bemoan'd.

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: Sure she is Injur'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, sit down: see, Izabella,
These Flowers live without the sence of sorrows.

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.l: And yet they'll hang their heads in scorching heat,
When no kind drops fall on 'em.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis true, as if like me they wanted pitty,
But I'll stoop down upon their fragrant Beds,
And weep upon 'em. Oh, Izabella,
Wou'd any thing could prosper by my griefs.

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: I must believe her.—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Hark, What's that?

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: Nothing, Madam, 'tis but your fancy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis Harmony, and cannot be my fancy,
For that is out of tune. Enter Medina as a Genius, in a glittering Habit.
Ha! What's this? help, Izabella.

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.l: Sit still. Madam, 'tis only some design
To entertain you, the Musick shows it now.

div.stage: The Musick ceases; and the Genius speaks.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I am the Genius which does wait
Upon Spain's loose and shaken State;
I rule the Spirits of the Air,
Who, as their guide to me repair;
And then by me to every mind
A several genius is assign'd,
Who wait and whisper to their Souls,
But no Decree or Power controuls;
For every one their freedoms use▪
And all their Faults, and Vertues chuse.
The account of every deed and thought
Are by the winged Spirits brought:
We sit in Sun-beams, while they tell
The news of Mortals that do well;
But when they tell of Vice, they shrou'd
Their heads, and whisper't in a Cloud.
Some merit neither praise nor shame,
Who tempt not fate, nor trouble Fame;
Those Spirits that on such attend,
I'll charm, to show how time they spend. He Charms, an Entry of Spirits, imitating vain men dumb.
Now, from above, I'll call for one
That is the Genius of the Throne;
Next thine, whose sighs encrease the Air,
That thou art not so chast as fair:
'Tis those alone waste every hour,
That wait on Beauty, or on Power.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: See, I obey, and now am weary grown
Longer to wait upon a Throne,
Then let me take some rest
And flie to whisper to a common Breast;
Not fed with Luxury,
Nor flatter'd up to be a Deity.

div.stage: He waves his Wand, and enter the second Genius.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: I come, I come, fill'd with despair
To whisper longer, to the proud and fair.
Their own just Conquest they despise,
And please themselves with guilty Victories:
Against those Altars I in vain perswade
Where worship is by time decay'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: I oft have mingled with the thoughts
Of Kings, and told, they were not Deities,
And how all Princes faults
Made men have daring Tongues and Eyes.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: I told this Beauty too her fate,
That one soul Crime had such a weight,
That all must sink; and he that first does find
A Beauty, yet unblemisht, kind,
He is like one that does discover
An unknown World, by whose success
He makes a way for others to possess;
As she's made ready for another Lover.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Then set us free, that we may find,
In low Estates, a steady mind,
Whose harmless Life, and vertuous Love,
Is far above
The reach of Vice, or fear of Fate;
Let no good Genius henceforth wait
Upon such false, and such unsteady things
As ador'd Beauties, or as flatter'd Kings.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ha, Izabella, There is some
Further meaning, sure in this,
I do not like it.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: You must.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How must? what are you? I am betray'd,
Izabella, stay; what was all this meant for?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Truth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: These shapes spoke falshood.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I'll help you to one then, shall tell you Truths.
D'ye know me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My honour'd Uncle; brave Medina,
My wonder's greater than my doubts before.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: The greatest wonder is behind.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Thy Lust,
That does exceed all wicked Miracles.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Lord, for pitties sake.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: 'Tis pitty forces me to this Violence,
The pitty of thy Blood, I had a share in
Before it was infected with this Leprosie;
The pitty of thy Youth, thy beauteous Youth,
Like a fair Flower pluckt up by the Root
When 'twas but newly budding, before time
Could show it to the World, how sweet it was.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Do but hear me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Yes, if you'll speak Repentance with a Passion
As great as that which made you act your lewdness,
Then I will hearken like a doating Mother,
To hear her Children prais'd by flattering tongues.
But if it be to excuse or mitigate
Thy wretched Fathers, or thine own offence.
And Bawd for whorish Acts, by poor excuses;
The Ears of Cruelty shall not be deafer,
Nor storms to crying Seamen that must sink,
As thy drown'd Honour does, though not so deep.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Think of thy Mother now, that through some Star
Looks blushing down on thy Impieties;
And finds it harder to hold a wrath from thee
With all the Mediation of the Saints,
Than 'twas to purchase for her self, by Vertue,
That blest Eternity which she enjoys.
Oh, thou hadst been blest, Maria; if thy Father,
Like other Wolves, had been then torn to pieces
Before he knew what he begot in thee;
For thou hadst then wanted a powerful Pander:
Or, had Heaven blest thee with Deformity,
Thou hadst been safe in unattempted Vertue.
Oh, Maria, it is thy Beauty that has been
The fatal blazing Star that did foretel
The hot Contagion that has follow'd in thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Will you not hear me then, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Dost thou make way at all for me to
Hear thee? or hast thou yet let fall a tear?
To bribe me from pronouncing cruel Judgment.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: When I want Innocence, I'll weep, or beg
Of you and Heaven; But I that have preserv'd
My Virtue, as unstain'd as at the time
When my blest Mother (who now smiles upon me)
Gave me and that together to the World.
I will not stain it by a false Confession.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A Truth, which I am bound by tyes of Nature
And Honour, to tell you, and all the World,
Nay, on my Knees I thank you, that you take
The room of a lost Father up so kindly;
And question me, for all you do suspect:
And I will gladly tell you my true Story,
Like those that with a pleasure do repeat
The Tales of mighty Dangers they have past.
But if your foul Belief, like the World's Tongues,
Can only think all ill, as they can speak 'em,
Then I rise thus, and from my Vertue borrow
A Scorn, as great as such from their own Vices
Can borrow foul Opinions

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Why, what a Fool was I, I did expect
Repentance, and shou'd have look'd for Impudence▪
Perhaps you fool your self into this boldness,
And think there's no man that dares question
The Mistress of a King, but I wou'd sooner
Destroy a Traytor to my Prince's Soul,
Than to his Crown.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The King has as much Vertue as I wish him.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: That easily may be, but 'tis a question
Whether he will continue still so bad,
As thou desir'st him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I see that you are deaf to hear of goodness▪
And I must either have a guilt within,
To beg enough, or Vertue to despise you.
And when you know, which you shall quickly do,
How you have injur'd me, you will repent
Your bold Injustice:—so farewel.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Stay, stay, you must not go.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Must not?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: No, nor shall not: the Masquers that you saw
Are all my trusty Friends, 'tis in vain
To cry, or tear your Throat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: To shake you in your damn'd security,
Or set your Soul free from that gilded Frame,
Whose unseen rottenness corrupts it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Will you murder me?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I did not come with that intention.
But thou hast rais'd me to a vertuous anger,
That tempts me to prevent thy shame and mine.
Yet will you turn your Eyes in to your Breast,
And they must weep, for they will see thy heart
So very foul, that it needs pious washing.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.l: Nay, then
If your scorn'd Anger swell'd you to a Mountain
And were to fall upon me, I wou'd stand
Thus—and not shake, but wou'd despise
Your Ruine and mine own.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Yet repent, and do not force my Hand
To a swift Justice, that must send thy Soul
Where vitious Falseness dares not tell a Tale.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I had rather be judg'd there than here.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Then, Justice, I thus obey thy strict Command,
But powerful Nature stays my feeble Hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why do you pause? your Passion is more noble
Then your Vertue, one can make tryal of me,
T'other dares not; Strike, and all the while,
See what suspected Sin startles my Soul,
Or stirs me to a blush.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Dare you endure to dye?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Were't not a sin, perhaps I durst do more.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: What more?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Give my self what I wish, as easily
As I provoke your shaking hand to do't.

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.l: Oh, my Lord, undone, undone, the King's just
Coming, and searches for Maria.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: The King?—no matter—
I'll fall nobly, now you shall be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I cou'd weep now to see the great Medina
Believe all ill so easily; when you speak
Of my unhappy Father, his bare Name
Confirms you in your cruel censure of me:
But though you talk of my blest Mother to me
A thousand times, you have not power to think,
One drop of Vertue has descended to me
From that pure Fountain.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Oh Heaven! send peace to my distracted Soul,
And tell me which is truth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Heaven will tell you suddenly, but we forget,
Put on your Disguise, and leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: This Disguise may be more fatal
Than my own shape.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You must not for the World appear your self,
For then you will be thought, the Author
Of something I intend, which will be fatal to you.
Dare you trust me in nothing?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Well, in this I dare—Izabella,
Bid my Friends hide their Disguises,
And conceal themselves.

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You remember there was a Letter
Written to the Marquess of Alcara.
And Count Bruchero.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I do: Did you write it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No more Questions now.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: But I will ask something;
For I grow willing to believe thee good:
Pray tell me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Peace, I hear a Noise.—Look
If you see any coming.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: 'Tis the King; I trust you now, Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Do so always then.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Maria—How now, What's this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, do not look upon him,
'Twill make the poor man so out of Countenance,
That I shall have no more Diversion;
It seems that Izabella and the Gardiner
Contriv'd an Entertainment for me,
It was done just as your Majesty came.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: This is an odd Excuse.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I shou'd have been sorry to have
Interrupted your pleasures.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, do not look at him,
He'll be so asham'd.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I will look on nothing but thy brightness;
Come, Maria, I fell in love with thee,
Then with thy Vertue which was hard to find
In so much Beauty; th' other is so common
It bears no Rate, there's Poverty in Vice;
The hardest things to find bear greatest price.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: This is the likeliest thing Exeunt King, Maria, D'Alva.
To Vertue, I ever saw:
Besides, had she been vitious,
She would not have neglected her Revenge,
One of the pleasant'st Lusts ill Women have:
All may be Counterfeit—and yet—
There may be such a thing as a good Woman. Enter Izabella.
How now, What news?

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: All safe; I must hast after them.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Stay, and prethee tell me, my best Cozen,
Dost thou think Maria Vertuous?

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: By Heaven I do.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: By Heaven I have a mind to do so too.

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.l: I have observ'd things worthy of your knowledge.
Another time I will relate them to you.
Something she's resolv'd to do, I'll watch
To find it out: So farewel,
I dare not stay.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I know not what to think;
I wou'd believe, but yet my shaken Faith
Creeps to its growth but slowly, like an Infant
Forc'd to a hasty Birth before its time.
Our lives and our devotions are but sickly,
When Aguish doubts their growing health controuls;
A shaken Faith's the storm of tottering Souls. Enter D' Alva.
Ha! D' Alva? What has brought him back?

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.l: Here's the Apparition still, I must be satisfied,
What are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: One of Lerma's Angels.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: Lerma's Devils.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: See, my Lord, I meant his evil Angel.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.l: Oh, my dear Lord, Discovers himself.
Pardon my apprehension;
We tread upon such rough and narrow paths,
That any trick, or error, throws us down.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Fear not, my Lord, I have discovered
And broken, as I hope, the best foundation
That Lerma builds upon.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.l: Let us delay no time, but instantly
To Council with the Marquess of Alcara,
And Count Bruchero; they have something
To impart, that is of great Importance.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: To add to all, I have secur'd the Witnesses,
Antonio, and Catalina; we'll lose no time,
Whilst Lerma, as I hear, thinks I am fled,
And Joys in fullness of his growing power.
But let him swell, fate never durst deny
Bold Spirits, to dispose of destiny.
Unshaken Trees, that have the largest roots;
A bold, and well-arm'd hand as well may throw
As those, whose Roots do not so deeply grow.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: If my invention fail not, I have yet
Out-stript 'em all; if my wing'd Mercury
Keep touch in time: The Court looks odly,
And every brow wears mysteries about 'em:
The fawning Rascals of it (which like Cobwebs
Shou'd be swept off) methinks avoid me now,
Who us'd to crowd, and stop my way with cringes;
Their smiles look like the grins of anger'd Monkeys:
But I am safe, while my Maria's Charms
Hang on the King, and numb him to a Lethargy,
There's some that are too great, must be cut down,
Feign'd Accusations, and a little time
Will kill all wonder, which is shorter liv'd
Than dreams of Children, or old Womens tales.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Ha! Death on thee, I was serious.
Begon—this was a guilty start, Strikes him. Ex. Angelo.
This Slave too, will perhaps
Grow wise, and guess at something,
How hard it is, in slippery ways
To keep a steady Motion. Enter Caldroon.
How now? what news?—speak.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: I am too narrow to contain,
It is too great to keep or to let out.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Curse on this form in thy Relations.
For thou dost practise on me like an Advocate,
Whose splenetive exordiums are more horrid
Than the ill cause he wou'd make monstrous.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: Your Daughter, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Is sweeter than the Spring, wreath'd in the Arms
Of budding Flowers; what more of her?

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: There can't be Man enough in you to hear it,
And then out-live it; 'tis so great a weight,
I almost sink to bring it.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: And yet art such an Ass under thy burden
As not to throw it off: or tell it me,
And I have all thy weight.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: You cannot hear it.

sp.speaker: Ler
sp.p: Not if you do not tell it.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: 'Twill crush you.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: It must be heavier than all the weight
Of Peoples Curses, and the great Ones Envies:
Thou dost not know one thing, Caldroon;
Fortune and I did long ago agree,
I to make work for her, and she for me,
Tell it me boldly; and prethee now, Caldroon,
Do not like those that bring a bitter Potion,
Make scurvy Faces at it, as you give it.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: Oh, my Lord,
Dogs howlings, or the groans of Mandrakes,
Wou'd be a Consort of soft Musick,
To this harsh thing I have to utter.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Thou'st numb'd my Senses like a skilful Surgeon.
And now may'st strike, I shall not feel thy Hand.
But come, what of Maria?

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.l: She's gone, stole away,
Unknown by whom, or whither.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: This is a dangerous Wound indeed,
I know not where to search it.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: My Lord, I told you what 'twou'd come to.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Oh, Sir, you are a mighty Prophet,
Where was the King?

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: As they say, asleep.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Could he sleep? and his dull Soul without
A dreaming Whisper, that she was losing,
And when he wakes, and misses her, what then?

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: He will be troubled sure.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Troubles wear off from Kings, (they are too high
To grieve, and sorrow slides from them) like falling drops
From sides of houses,—they dare not hurt her sure.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: It cannot be imagin'd that they dare

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: She must appear again, our rapid Motions
Will bring us round again to that fair Sun.
If the King loves her too, (as sure he does)
Her Absence makes it Night with him.
I wonder what they meant by't.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: I cannot guess, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Thou'rt shallow then; they fondly think
The King will be uncharm'd, and hearken to their
Clamours, now she that stood between
Their Breath and him, is thus remov'd;
'Twas pollitically done;—
And yet they dare not tell him where she is,
Nor the bold Ravisher confess the Fact.
For yet, Caldroon, she hangs upon his Heart
Like hopes of Joy upon a troubled Soul;
I have a Plot to help us yet, at least
To give us time till I have search'd this further.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: What is't, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: I'll instantly to the half-soul-less King▪
For he must want his better part of Life
Now she is gone: and tell him she is retir'd
On purpose, till a hasty Vow be past:
And frame a Letter in her dearest Name,
Shall keep his Love from chilling.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: 'Tis excellent.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: He must not know she's lost.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: Not for the World.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: By that time, Fate will send her me again;
For those above, all know my Title to her;
She is my Child, Caldroon, but such a one
As can raise Sorrow above Nature's pitch.
Prethee observe, Caldroon, how other Fathers
Mourn for lost Children; then thou wou't see
I do not talk so idlely as thou think'st;
But in this loss, I must not lose my self,
And whine to nothing: I'll to the King.

div.stage: Enter the King and Medina, D' Alva, Alcara, and Bruchero, whispering to him and Medina shewing Papers: the King sad, and expressing Amazement angerly, and so passes over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: He comes.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: But with a Guard, I like not.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: We are undone.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: He wou'd not look upon me once,
While round about him, all my Enemies
Whisper'd Destruction to me.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: All's out, I fear.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Base Prince;
By Heaven, Caldroon, he has forgot her;
How easily his fond and childish Love
Threw the fine Thing away, that it so cry'd for.
The Memories of Princes are but Graves
Where Beauty, and where Merit lye forgotten.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: Think of your self, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: When the thick croud of Thoughts for lost Maria
Will leave the least way open, then I will;
Oh, she had Eyes, Caldroon, I hope she has,
That did, and may, yet look him into nothing.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: Cou'd we but find her.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: She cannot be conceal'd, she is too glorious,
Had she been coupl'd with some rough-hewn Slave,
Her Language wou'd have play'd upon his Soul,
And charm'd him into dotage, if she had griev'd
Like an Idolater, he wou'd have gather'd
Her Tears upon his Knees, for sacred Relicks.
But had he lost her thus, thus as she's lost,
He wou'd have search'd her out, or else destroy'd
All that he could suspect, and then himself.
But this sick shadow of a Lover
That whin'd, and pin'd away in passion for her,
Is like a School-boy, glad to be releas'd
From a hard Lesson.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: Here's more Company.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: The worst is come already, and the rest look'd for.

div.stage: Enter Medina, D' Alva, Alcara, Bruchero, with Angelo, led Prisoner by an Officer, with a white staff and a Guard attending.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: You shall have more Company,
Seignior Angelo—Do your Office, Algazil.

sp.speaker: Algaz.
sp.l: Roderigo del Caldroon, I Arrest thee
In the name of Philip, King of Spain.

sp.speaker: Cald.
sp.p: I obey it, we are o'er-taken.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: Medina, I will answer the Arrest.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Your case is not much better,
You will be summon'd, Lerma.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Why then I will appear, Medina;
You're a kind Brother.
Cou'd I turn all my Passions into Curses,
And make 'em as effectual as my sorrows,
They might, perhaps, destroy the proudest of 'em;
And yet my well-propt heart shall bear it all,
He only is above Envy and Fate,
Whose mind in sinking Fortunes keeps its height.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Lerma appears, as in his House, with a Letter in his hand; two Men bringing in a Coffer after him, opens a Door, and they place it in.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: HEre, set that Treasure in, for they are Reliques,
And will preserve their faithful Worshipper;
Why, here are mysteries Canonical,
That must not be searcht into by disputes;
'Twas a good purchace too, considering
The deep necessity; or if compar'd
To the vast sums I gave my Instruments
To turn them Fiends, and make my self a Devil,
For I am Sainted at a cheaper Rate,
Thanks to his Holiness, my pack of Councellors,
I have out-gone you all; but to my Letter.

body.p: THis Coffer holds your wishes, and the full salutes from Rome; your Money is return'd as promised: I have at Naples here, met news so fearful, has alter'd all my purposes: I have serv'd you faithfully, pay it to my memory; you are secure, and I preserv'd from shame, by a death of my own chusing, Poyson. So farewel, no more yours, nor any more

sp.l: Kind Man, that with such pious Charity
Sav'd me the labour; he knew I honour'd him,
And wou'd not have his Life laid to my charge,
But Piously he took it from himself;
Where's such another Churchman?
For Caldroon, by this time he is going after him,
I wou'd the Bishop had but taught the Slave,
His Wife, and charitable way of dying:
But where's Maria? I dare not ask my self,
For I, alas, can't tell, and Heaven will not;
Where is its Mercy then? for it ne'er had
Another way to Bless, but by Maria.
Could my prophane and passionate Revenge
Reach but the Hearts and Lips of the Religious;
No Incense evermore shou'd upward fly,
Of Prayer or Praise; I'd stop all Piety
Till they restor'd Maria to me—hark—
I hear some noise—ha? what's this?

div.stage: Enter Caldroon, going to Execution, led by two Fryars; a Fryer going before, carrying a Crucifix; after follow others of several Orders, every one with a wax Taper in his hand; they pass round the Stage, singing his Funeral Dirge.
After they go out, Medina enters with a Guard.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: Oh, are you come? what Tempest now?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: How do you like the sight you saw?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: What the Pageant? I did not like it.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I thought so.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: I was vext to see how the poor Slave
Hung down his head, he shou'd have laught at you.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: This heavy Spectacle was meant—

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: To frighten me?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: No, to prepare and touch thy Conscience
Before thy Summons which I here pronounce;
Charles Duke of Lerma, the Council do Command
In the King's Name, that you appear immediately
To answer Articles prefer'd against you.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p:
Philip, Duke of Medina,
〈◊〉 dare come.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Your impudence was never question'd.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Nor shall my confidence be shaken by you.
This was no kind Office for a Brother.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Where I find Vertue, there I own Alliance,
But I still persecute ignoble Acts, though
Against him that wou'd b • call'd my Brother.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Wou'd be call'd?
Take thy disdain'd Alliance back again,
I do despise to plead the chance of Nature
To give me Title or pretence to any thing.
And if you are such as you talk, your self,
You might more nobly have pursu'd those Actions,
That you count ill: I always wore a Sword,
And do so now.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I love not to be urg'd to draw my Sword,
Though that of Justice is much fitter now
To strike at thee, which is so sure and sudden,
That thy pretended Courage is despair.
Yet, now I think on't better, 'tis an Honour
To be thy Executioner.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: I did not think yet to have found Medina
A poor malicious Enemy, cou'd you believe
That I have lost my Courage with my Fortunes,
But to take off your mean ignoble scruple,
Know, Medina, that at this time, my Life
Is as secure as thine, by Heaven it is. Enter Alcara.
Thou rob'st not greedy Justice of a morsel.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: What's this? the Guard there, hoa?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: What, betray'd?

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.l: How now, my Lord? suffring a Traytor
With a Sword drawn upon you.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: My Lord, you are mistaken.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.l: The Council call for you, and are
Just going to Sit, and immediately expect
Your Prisoner's Appearance.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: My Lord, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: I must not leave him Arm'd.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Take my Honour, my Lord, there shall be
Nothing done, he is my Brother, and as far
As Justice gives me leave, I'd use him Nobly.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: The Guard, my Lord, must wait in sight.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: As you please; but he and I must have
Some words in private.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.l: Upon the engagement of your Honour.
Nothing but words shall pass, I leave you.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: My Lord, you have it, I'll follow presently.
You see we are prevented.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: You have dealt Nobly, and I am calm again;
Only, I wou'd beg leave to tell you a little tale
Before you go. There was a Man,
Whose Pious Love to Honour, made him forget
Friends and Alliance: such Chimera's
Have brought on Cruelties in your cousen'd mind
That Nature startles at, and the forc'd World
Who make advantage on your formal dotage,
Condemns you for that ruine which they wish;
And call it cruelty in you to bring it.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: You are a subtle Sophister, and might
Talk a believing Fool from his just ends.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Why, Did you never try in all this time
To teach my heart in private, and direct it;
And where you found a wound, like a good Chirurgeon,
Search it to Cure, and not to kill your Patient.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: The love of Vertue reaches not to Ruine,
And all will judge your course thus violent
(But such as flatter you for their own ends)
To be your hate to me, not love to Vertue.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: It's true, perhaps I am my self an Ocean,
And mingled something dangerously by Fortune,
And yet but only gently whisper'd to:
I am as calm as Nature undisturb'd
In sleeping Infants; but when loud breaths
Blow me to storms, I care not then who sinks.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I trifle time to hear thee:
The hour of your Appearing's come, make hast,
Or you'l be fetch'd by common Officers:
So farewel, I fear you fool your self with hopes.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: He's gone; he durst not stay to hear me;
He did begin to melt: good natur'd Gentleman.
I love to try Mens tempers to laugh at 'em;
For I shou'd hardly trust a promis'd kindness.
I will not beg, that can command my Peace;
He that secures himself well in the end,
Must destroy Foes, and never trust a Friend.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Medina, D' Alva, Alcara, and Bruchero, ready to sit as in Judgment.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: I hope, my Lords, I have deserv'd your thanks.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: And all the Nations.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Caldroon and Angelo did hardly thank you:
The Ants had pil'd a mighty heap of Treasure.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: No news, my Lord, yet of your Niece?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Not any.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.l: She has show'd a Vertue in this close retreat
Beyond all Story.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: I do confess I'm glad I was mistaken;
I thought her worse than she has prov'd.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.l: The King they say begins to have suspitions
That she's convey'd away by some of us.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: That fancy will be nourisht in his mind
By Lerma's Creatures, we must haste the Tryal.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.l: All's ready, see the King. Enter the King.
A Cloud of sadness gathers on his calmness;
He seems disturb'd.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What, you wou'd make excuses for the fact,
Or, wou'd you own it for a Politick Vertue?

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: What fact, Sir?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dare you ask me what? or do you think
I am too young, not grown up to a King?

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: We do beseech your Majesty—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To give you leave to be all Kings, and Tyrants
Of my Affections; you Ravishers of Vertue,
Either restore Maria to the World,
Or all go suddenly, and lose your selves.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Does your Majesty believe?—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes, I do, that all great Men
Have jealous envies, equal unto Rivals;
And all the courted Beauty is Ambition,
Hid under Justice, which, take heed you follow,
And closely too, or ye shall all feel mine:
So, you may sit, but I will watch your actions.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: This is unhappy.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: It will be more, unless we now embrace
The opportunity: Come, let us sit

And call the Witnesses.
Enter Izabella.
How now, What's the news with you?

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: I wou'd speak with the King.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: Maria.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: What's your business?

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: 'Tis only for his Ears.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: How, Izabella, are you grown her Servant?

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: I am a Servant to her Vertues.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: And so brought a vertuous Message?

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: My Lord, you may say what you please.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: But you must not go; unless you first.
Tell me the business—Where's Maria?

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: I must tell neither.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Ha, Did not I intrust you?

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.l: And so does she, and I'll be just to both:
Pray stop me not.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Sure, Izabella, you forget your self,
And what I am?

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: But not what I ought to be.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Go back, I say, and tell that counterfeit Maria,
She shall not save her Father, with the loss
Of her own Prince—go—Nay, no help.

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: Then I must speak.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Put her out, and from henceforth
I do disown my blood in thee too.

sp.speaker: Iza.
sp.p: This is Cruelty, not Justice.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Stop her mouth; out with her.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: What's the matter, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Nothing but a Tale-bearer dispatch'd
Away.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: I have seen her sure.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: It may be so: Come, we trifle time;
Sit, my Lords, and call the Witnesses.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Antonio, you are ready to averr
Your own Confession, made at several times.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: My Lords, I am.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: The Heads of your Confession made out
The Queen's Death, and your reward; and how
At last your own Death was design'd.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: All this I am ready at large to testifie,
And prove.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Your Father was a worthy Man,
And you were more unfortunate than safe;
Your proof's fair: Catalina,

I know, will be as steady as your Virtues. Enter a Messenger.
The King appears above.
Is Lerma come?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: He has refus'd to come the common way,
And is descending by the private Lobby.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: That private way is not for Traytors.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Envy him not, my Lords, 'tis the last time
That his proud humour shall be satisfied;
I do believe he knows not what he does,
But like a tir'd o'er-hunted Deer,
Treads fatal Paths offer'd by chance,
And not design'd by him. Enter Lerma in a Cardinal's Habit. They cry, Room.
Hark, he comes—ha—What's this?
A Vision?

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: A Mask, I think, not an Arraignment.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: He has o'er-reach'd us all.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: I see you are amaz'd, my worthy Lords,
To find your Loves to Vertue made so useless,
As not to practise your admir'd Justice:
Perhaps you are so fond of that fair Mistress,
As that it mingled Passion with your Actions,
But now you may discharge your manag'd Witnesses
That stand prepar'd against the Duke of Lerma,
Lerma the Cardinal cannot here be Try'd:
Be not so dull, my Lords, it shews uncharitable,
An envious Malice will be thought the Father
Of such a Sadness: nothing but Ruine please you?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: D'ye come hear to rail?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: No, to Preach, it is my Office.
I did no sooner touch this Sacred Habit,
But I was fill'd with Notions.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: The Devil helps thee to 'em.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: Still so uncharitable?

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: Dost thou name any thing that's good?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Are you so merry too?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Why, wou'd you have me whine, and beg from you
A thing you never had; and which I need not?
He that seeks Safety in a States-man's pity,
May as well run a Ship upon sharp Rocks,
And hope a Harbour: nay, if you are so dull,
You'll make me laugh again: 'tis not ill sport
To see your cruel Aims thus lost and cozen'd.
Cou'd you believe, I meant to dye so tamely,
And quench the Thirst of your ambitious Envies
With my desired Blood?
This holy Robe tells me, it is my duty,
And I forgive: but sure I may laugh at you.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Impudence, stand off. Let us consult.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Do, whistle out your Brains.
The Council will run mad; they are angry,
I wou'd not take their way to Heaven.
I must preach Patience to 'em: Now for an Oracle.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: You know 'tis in our power to Confine you.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: In that I have as well prevented you:
Here's the Assignment of a holy Prison
By my own choice, and granted by his Holiness,
In that fair Monastery I rais'd my self.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Subtle Devil.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: I will not longer trouble you, my Lords,
But leave you now to prey upon your selves.
He that devours the rest, in time may be
A Monster, more o'ergrown than e'er I was.
When you are low, and poor, you are all Friends,
And in one fair pretence together join,
While every one conceals his own design.
It is your Countreys cause until full grown
In long sought power, then it proves your own.
When you seem good, your Crimes are not the less,
Men have all new Creations by success.
Ambition like a wanton Womans hast,
Invites new Slaves, grown weary of the last.
Mankind each others stories do repeat,
And Man to Man is a succeeding cheat.
So to this fate I leave you, and shall joy,
To see those Crimes you blame, your selves destroy.
May you all sink in fates for me you meant,
And be too dull, your ruines to prevent;
That when you're lost in this ambitious toil,
I in my safe retreat may sit and smile.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: Here's a strange change: thanks to his Holiness.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: We may blush to be thus cozen'd.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Methinks the greatness of his Spirit stir'd me,
I cou'd almost forgive him. Enter Maria led by Nuns, and Izabella. She discovers.
What, More Masquerades; How, Maria?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Where, or to whom, shall I now bend
My almost worn out Knees? Alas the Deity,
From whom I shou'd hope mercy, is not here:
How short are Kings of gods? they'r every where.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Maria on her Knees?
Dare they suffer her to kneel Above, and Descends
To whom I bow?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How durst you to a King shut up the way?
Shou'd Saints deny a wretched Soul to pray?
Did I your safeties with such care design
For you to take the Life, that gave me mine.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Her sorrow moves.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: Her Vertue more; rise, fair Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Speak, must my Father dye? if it be so,
We'll both together to my Mother go.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: Fair vertuous Maid, your Father lives.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Ha! the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tell me the wretch, that ravisht thee from me,
That my Revenge, great as his crime may be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: When you your Sacred Word to me did give,
My Father by your Mercy still shou'd live,
I stole away that you might be left free
To be as just, as merciful to me:
And durst not else, but unto those above
In Prayers for you, confess my secret Love.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your Father is preserv'd from danger, free,
And sav'd himself that had been sav'd by me.
He in a Holy Robe is now retir'd,
By danger urg'd, by Heaven I hope inspir'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What an excess of Blessings Heaven can give?
Oh happy Father that does more than live!
With joy now to my Sacred Cell I'll go;
I shou'd not weep, but my fond tears will flow.
My Zeal it self has a temptation too,
I scarce shall pray for any thing but you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: If you, in leaving me so cruel prove,
Your Prayers will be as useless as your Love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Time, Sir, alas, will in a little space,
An Image drawn but faintly, quite deface.
Love, like a shadow, while youth shines, is shown,
But in old Ages darkness, there is none.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But all pure Love, like glow-worms heatless fires
Lives where it shines, and with that Life expires.
Beauty, like Time on Dials, moves so flow,
That they who always gaze, can't see it go.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But I must now leave Heaven, Sir, or you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The choice were easie, were the question true.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Is not Heaven then the best felicity?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But you as well may go to Heaven with me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis hard, thorow the World to find the way,
If I talk long, I shall my self betray;
Your Joys I study, and deny my own;
Shou'd Lerma's Daughter share your Bed and Throne;
Farewel, Sir, when you think of this, confess,
I lov'd you, far beyond my happiness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stay yet, and hear this Vow,
Spain's empty Throne,
Unless from you, shall want succession.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: Now, by my Sisters blessed Soul, I share
Between her Vertues, and my Kings Despair;
Maria, stay, you must to Duty bow.

sp.speaker: D' Alva.
sp.p: You sav'd us all, preserve your Nation now.

sp.speaker: Alca.
sp.p: That Vertue still may flow from you, their Spring.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: And make a Nation happy with their King.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What shou'd I do?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: —Defer your cruel thought,
Till by my grief you are more pitty taught.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This, Sir, is to o'ercome the easiest way,
My Forces will all lessen by delay,
Yet, Sir, in this I must submit to you,
And Heaven, to teach my heart what's best to do.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Till then—
Let all that love me, in my troubles join,
And let their griefs, Allegiance pay to mine.
Let not a smile upon a Face be seen,
Till fair Maria yields to be my Queen.

div.head: Epilogue
div.l: MUch injur'd Gentlemen, may you now please,
You true Committee of such Grievances,
Kindly to hear me now, and I will show it,
We have been all ill us'd, by this days Poet.
'Tis our joint Cause; I know you in your hearts
Hate serious Plays, as I do serious Parts,
To trouble us with Thoughts and State-designs,
A melancholy Plot ty'd with strong Lines,
I had not the least Part to day you see,
Troth, he has neither writ for you, nor me;
You are not hard to please; though a Poet scarce
Can make a Play, yet he might make a Farce,
With small ridiculous things to stuff it full,
And make you pay to laugh, not to be dull.
Henceforth, against all sad and grave intregues,
We'll make Offensive, and Defensive Leagues;
And for all those that dare write Tragedy,
We'll make a Law, with a huge Penalty;
And yet few Poets so much Wealth possess,
Or Wit, where you might levy a Distress;
Let the grave Poets then trouble but few,
Write Elegies on Men, which few Men knew,
And few perhaps will read; or let 'em write
Rhimes for the Bell-man, to be spoke at night.
This Poet may be pardon'd, lest it be said
You did condemn before the Law was made;
I mean, if's Play be good, I tell you True,
He thinks it is, but pray now, What think you?
